a:5:{s:1:"d";a:95:{i:0;O:8:"stdClass":48:{s:19:"article_category_id";s:5:"15012";s:10:"article_id";s:4:"7299";s:11:"category_id";s:3:"243";s:9:"short_des";N;s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:97:"the-asia-ccus-network-acn-knowledge-sharing-conference-direct-air-capture-the-opportunity-in-asia";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:102:"The Asia CCUS Network (ACN) Knowledge Sharing Conference 'Direct Air Capture: The Opportunity in Asia'";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2023-01-31";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2023";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"1";s:7:"content";s:5051:"<p><img src="http://www.eria.org/uploads/media/2023_Jan_Direct-Air-Capture-The-Opportunity-in-Asia_2.jpg" alt="" width="800" height="400" /></p><p>Carbon Capture, Utilisation and Storage (CCUS) technologies are expected to play an important role in supporting clean energy transitions across Asia as an emissions reductions pathway for fossil-fuel intensive power and industry sectors. Direct Air Capture (DAC) technology is expected to support the transition with carbon removals to counterbalance residual emissions through technologies.</p><p>Many countries around the world have committed to the energy transition as reflected in their NDCs although some countries have yet to pledge any specific target year for carbon neutrality.&nbsp; However, not only developed countries have committed to carbon neutrality, but many countries in the developing world also fully committed to making the energy transition from a fossil fuels-based energy system towards cleaner and greener energy systems in which more renewable energies such as wind, solar, hydropower, biomass, and other clean fuels will have a larger share in the energy mix.</p><p>Unlike capturing emissions from industrial flue stacks, DAC technology captures carbon dioxide (CO2) directly from the atmospheric air around us, through a series of chemical reactions, delivering it in a pure compressed stream suitable for storage or use. This can help counteract CO2&nbsp;emissions that are technologically challenging or prohibitively expensive to abate and address the large quantities of CO2&nbsp;emitted in the past that remains trapped in our atmosphere. Leading international organizations such as the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) and International Energy Agency (IEA) are highlighting the importance of high integrity, technology-based carbon removals in pursuit of these goals. The IPCC Sixth Assessment Report on mitigating climate change has stated that the direct removal of carbon dioxide from the atmosphere is now &ldquo;unavoidable&rdquo;; in order to reach our climate targets, we must both reduce emissions at source and also remove carbon dioxide from the atmosphere at large scale. The remaining emissions from fossil fuel combustion including power generation or industrial facilities that use fossil fuels, will need to be captured and transported to storage through CCUS technologies or through the Direct Air Capture technologies (around 2 Gt CO2 are removed in 2050 by technology-based CDR in the IEA&rsquo;s Net Zero Scenario).</p><p>The conference will promote knowledge-sharing on the DAC technology and the policy and regulation needed to support its large-scale deployment. It is co-hosted by ACN and Carbon Engineering, a Canadian climate solutions company, which has been focused since 2009 on developing DAC technology and commercializing it globally at large-scale, working alongside local partners. It will include presentation of the company&rsquo;s technology and business developments, and discussion of the opportunity that exists to deploy DAC in Asia as it accelerates its clean energy transition. The session will also explore possibilities for countries to pursue international and regional co-operation opportunities to be suppliers of high integrity CO2 removal, and to unlock associated economic and job opportunities.</p><h2>Event Details</h2><p>Date: Tuesday, 31 January 2023<br />Time: 9:00 AM to 10:30 AM (Jakarta | GMT+7)<br />Place: Online Event</p><h2>Agenda</h2><table><tr><td width="113"><p>09:00 &ndash; 09:15</p></td><td width="453"><p><strong>Opening and Welcoming remarks</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Shigeru Kimura, </strong>Special Advisor to the President on Energy Affairs, ERIA</li><li><strong>Paul Kennedy</strong>, Vice President of International Business Development, Carbon Engineering</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td width="113"><p>09:15 &ndash; 10:00</p></td><td width="453"><p><strong>Panel Discussion on &ldquo;Direct Air Capture&rdquo;</strong></p><p>Moderator:</p><ul><li><strong>Han Phoumin</strong>, Senior Energy Economist, ERIA</li></ul><p>Panelist:</p><ul><li><strong>Adam Baylin-Stern</strong>, Policy and Engagement Lead, Carbon Engineering</li></ul><p><strong>Presentation by the panelist</strong></p><p><strong>Discussion between the moderator and the panelist</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td width="113"><p>10:00 &ndash; 10:10</p></td><td width="453"><p><strong>Commentator </strong>by Dr Dadan Kusdiana, Directorate General of Renewable Energy and Energy Conservation, Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources (MEMR)</p></td></tr><tr><td width="113"><p>10:10 &ndash; 10:25</p></td><td width="453"><p><strong>Q&amp;A</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td width="113"><p>10:25 &ndash; 10:30</p></td><td width="453"><p>Closing Remarks by <strong>Han Phoumin</strong>, Senior Energy Economist, ERIA</p></td></tr></table><p><a class="bluebtn" href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/direct-air-capture-the-opportunity-in-asia-tickets-517242565437" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">REGISTER HERE</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:16:"Ms Dian Lutfiana";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2023-01-31";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2023-01-31";s:8:"keywords";s:8997:"The Asia CCUS Network (ACN) Knowledge Sharing Conference 'Direct Air Capture: The Opportunity in Asia' The Asia CCUS Network (ACN) Knowledge Sharing Conference 'Direct Air Capture: The Opportunity in Asia' Carbon Capture, Utilisation and Storage (CCUS) technologies are expected to play an important role in supporting clean energy transitions across Asia as an emissions reductions pathway for fossil-fuel intensive power and industry sectors. Direct Air Capture (DAC) technology is expected to support the transition with carbon removals to counterbalance residual emissions through technologies.
Many countries around the world have committed to the energy transition as reflected in their NDCs although some countries have yet to pledge any specific target year for carbon neutrality.&nbsp; However, not only developed countries have committed to carbon neutrality, but many countries in the developing world also fully committed to making the energy transition from a fossil fuels-based energy system towards cleaner and greener energy systems in which more renewable energies such as wind, solar, hydropower, biomass, and other clean fuels will have a larger share in the energy mix.
Unlike capturing emissions from industrial flue stacks, DAC technology captures carbon dioxide (CO2) directly from the atmospheric air around us, through a series of chemical reactions, delivering it in a pure compressed stream suitable for storage or use. This can help counteract CO2&nbsp;emissions that are technologically challenging or prohibitively expensive to abate and address the large quantities of CO2&nbsp;emitted in the past that remains trapped in our atmosphere. Leading international organizations such as the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) and International Energy Agency (IEA) are highlighting the importance of high integrity, technology-based carbon removals in pursuit of these goals. The IPCC Sixth Assessment Report on mitigating climate change has stated that the direct removal of carbon dioxide from the atmosphere is now &ldquo;unavoidable&rdquo;; in order to reach our climate targets, we must both reduce emissions at source and also remove carbon dioxide from the atmosphere at large scale. The remaining emissions from fossil fuel combustion including power generation or industrial facilities that use fossil fuels, will need to be captured and transported to storage through CCUS technologies or through the Direct Air Capture technologies (around 2 Gt CO2 are removed in 2050 by technology-based CDR in the IEA&rsquo;s Net Zero Scenario).
The conference will promote knowledge-sharing on the DAC technology and the policy and regulation needed to support its large-scale deployment. It is co-hosted by ACN and Carbon Engineering, a Canadian climate solutions company, which has been focused since 2009 on developing DAC technology and commercializing it globally at large-scale, working alongside local partners. It will include presentation of the company&rsquo;s technology and business developments, and discussion of the opportunity that exists to deploy DAC in Asia as it accelerates its clean energy transition. The session will also explore possibilities for countries to pursue international and regional co-operation opportunities to be suppliers of high integrity CO2 removal, and to unlock associated economic and job opportunities.
Event Details
Date: Tuesday, 31 January 2023Time: 9:00 AM to 10:30 AM (Jakarta | GMT+7)Place: Online Event
Agenda




09:00 &ndash; 09:15


Opening and Welcoming remarks

Shigeru Kimura, Special Advisor to the President on Energy Affairs, ERIA
Paul Kennedy, Vice President of International Business Development, Carbon Engineering





09:15 &ndash; 10:00


Panel Discussion on &ldquo;Direct Air Capture&rdquo;
Moderator:

Han Phoumin, Senior Energy Economist, ERIA

Panelist:

Adam Baylin-Stern, Policy and Engagement Lead, Carbon Engineering

Presentation by the panelist
Discussion between the moderator and the panelist




10:00 &ndash; 10:10


Commentator by Dr Dadan Kusdiana, Directorate General of Renewable Energy and Energy Conservation, Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources (MEMR)




10:10 &ndash; 10:25


Q&amp;A




10:25 &ndash; 10:30


Closing Remarks by Han Phoumin, Senior Energy Economist, ERIA

.seigolonhcet hguorht snoissime laudiser ecnalabretnuoc ot slavomer nobrac htiw noitisnart eht troppus ot detcepxe si ygolonhcet )CAD( erutpaC riA tceriD .srotces yrtsudni dna rewop evisnetni leuf-lissof rof yawhtap snoitcuder snoissime na sa aisA ssorca snoitisnart ygrene naelc gnitroppus ni elor tnatropmi na yalp ot detcepxe era seigolonhcet )SUCC( egarotS dna noitasilitU ,erutpaC nobraC 'aisA ni ytinutroppO ehT :erutpaC riA tceriD' ecnerefnoC gnirahS egdelwonK )NCA( krowteN SUCC aisA ehT 'aisA ni ytinutroppO ehT :erutpaC riA tceriD' ecnerefnoC gnirahS egdelwonK )NCA( krowteN SUCC aisA ehT";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2023-01-16 10:48:31";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2023-01-23 15:26:33";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"19";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:22:"dian.lutfiana@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:1;O:8:"stdClass":48:{s:19:"article_category_id";s:5:"14768";s:10:"article_id";s:4:"7204";s:11:"category_id";s:3:"243";s:9:"short_des";N;s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:98:"challenges-opportunities-of-indonesian-automotive-industry-development-in-the-era-of-case-and-maas";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"3";s:5:"title";s:100:"Challenges & Opportunities of Indonesian Automotive Industry Development in the Era of CASE and MaaS";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-12-12";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:2:"12";s:7:"content";s:27648:"<p data-key="203"></p><p data-key="203"><span data-key="204">Indonesia is a large country with a population of 270 million and accounts for about half of the GDP of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN). Among these, the automobile industry is the second largest production in ASEAN after Thailand, with annual sales of over 1 million vehicles. In Indonesia, a presidential decree in 2019 set out the promotion of electric vehicles (EVs), and the strengthening of automobile production, including EVs, is something that is largely positioned in the national development strategy. Currently, the Ministry of Industry of Indonesia sets a target of EV penetration, which will be 25 per cent of total vehicle sales in 2030. The government also tries to develop the EV battery Ecosystem by strengthening the battery production capacities within the country. This was also a major focus of the G20 under the Indonesian chairmanship this year. </span></p><p data-key="206" data-slate-fragment=""><span data-key="207">In 2023, Indonesia will be the chair of the ASEAN Summit. The development of the country's automotive industry is an important issue not only for Indonesia but also for the regional economic development of ASEAN. In particular, as new trends surrounding the automotive, such as CASE (Connected, Autonomous, Service/Sharing, and Electrified) and MaaS (Mobility as a Service) based on digitalisation, are growing, and there is an urgent need for all sectors involved in the automotive industry to formulate strategies to take advantage of these changes as an opportunity to make a big leap forward. The aim of this workshop is to stimulate discussion by inviting people from governments, academia and industries for the further development of the Indonesian automotive industry in the CASE and MaaS era.</span></p><h2 data-key="206" data-slate-fragment=""><span data-key="207">Event Details</span></h2><p data-key="206" data-slate-fragment=""><span data-key="207">Date: Thursday, 1 December 2022<br>Time: 9 AM to 12 PM (Jakarta time, UTC+7)<br>Place: </span><span data-key="207">Meeting Room 3-4, ERIA, Sentral Senayan II, 5th Floor, Jl Asia Afrika, Jakarta (limited space)<br><br><a class="bluebtn" title="RSVP for in-person attendance via Eventbrite" href="http://bit.ly/3tCW1O6" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">RSVP for in-person attendance</a></span></p><p data-key="206" data-slate-fragment=""><span data-key="207">Streamed via: Zoom<br><a class="bluebtn" title="RSVP for online attendance via Eventbrite" href="https://bit.ly/3Gh7WZy" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">RSVP for online attendance</a><br></span></p><h2 data-key="206" data-slate-fragment=""><span data-key="207">Agenda</span></h2><p data-key="206" data-slate-fragment="">Jakarta time (UTC+7)</p><table style="width: 722.047px;"><tbody><tr><td style="width: 177px;">9 AM to 9:10 AM</td><td style="width: 550.047px;"><p>Opening Remarks <br><strong>Dr Ala</strong><strong>d</strong><strong>din D. Rillo</strong>, Senior Economic Advisor, ERIA</p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 177px;">9 AM to 9:25 AM</td><td style="width: 550.047px;"><p>Special Remarks <br><strong>Mr Eko S. A. Cahyanto</strong>, Director General of Industrial Resilience, Regions and International Access, Ministry of Industry of Indonesia</p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 177px;">9:25 AM to 9:55 AM</td><td style="width: 550.047px;"><p>Keynote Lecture<br><strong>Mr Masao Suematsu</strong>, Senior Vice President of DENSO International Asia Co., Ltd. (DIAT)</p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 177px;">9:55 AM to 10:05 AM</td><td style="width: 550.047px;">Coffee Break</td></tr><tr><td style="width: 177px;">10:05 AM to 11:50 AM</td><td style="width: 550.047px;"><p>Panel Discussion</p><ul><li><strong>Prof. Seio Nakajima</strong>, Dean and Professor, Graduate School of Asia-Pacific Studies, Waseda University; Director, Research Institute of Auto Parts Industries, Waseda University, Japan</li><li><strong>Dr Yasushi Ueki</strong>, Senior Research Fellow, IDE-JETRO</li><li><strong>Dr Alloysius Joko Purwanto</strong>, Energy Economist, ERIA</li><li><strong>Mr R Hendro Martono</strong>, Director of Maritime Industry, Transportation and Defence Appliances (IMATAP)</li><li><strong>Prof. Sutanto Soehodho</strong>, Professor at the Faculty of Technology, University of Indonesia</li></ul><p>Moderator: <strong>Mr Fusanori Iwasaki</strong>, Director for Policy Research, ERIA</p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 177px;">11:50 AM to 12 PM</td><td style="width: 550.047px;"><p>Closing Remarks<br><strong>Prof. Yasuhiro Yamada</strong>, Special Assistant to the President on Mekong Affairs, ERIA</p></td></tr></tbody></table>";s:10:"image_name";s:37:"/uploads/events/logo6396b5495ec34.png";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:29:"automotive,industry,Indonesia";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:37:"Virtual Room and ERIA office, Jakarta";s:5:"major";s:4:"7274";s:16:"article_keywords";s:29:"automotive,industry,Indonesia";s:9:"organizer";s:4:"ERIA";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-12-01";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2022-12-01";s:8:"keywords";s:7021:"Challenges & Opportunities of Indonesian Automotive Industry Development in the Era of CASE and MaaS Challenges & Opportunities of Indonesian Automotive Industry Development in the Era of CASE and MaaS Indonesia is a large country with a population of 270 million and accounts for about half of the GDP of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN). Among these, the automobile industry is the second largest production in ASEAN after Thailand, with annual sales of over 1 million vehicles. In Indonesia, a presidential decree in 2019 set out the promotion of electric vehicles (EVs), and the strengthening of automobile production, including EVs, is something that is largely positioned in the national development strategy. Currently, the Ministry of Industry of Indonesia sets a target of EV penetration, which will be 25 per cent of total vehicle sales in 2030. The government also tries to develop the EV battery Ecosystem by strengthening the battery production capacities within the country. This was also a major focus of the G20 under the Indonesian chairmanship this year. 
In 2023, Indonesia will be the chair of the ASEAN Summit. The development of the country's automotive industry is an important issue not only for Indonesia but also for the regional economic development of ASEAN. In particular, as new trends surrounding the automotive, such as CASE (Connected, Autonomous, Service/Sharing, and Electrified) and MaaS (Mobility as a Service) based on digitalisation, are growing, and there is an urgent need for all sectors involved in the automotive industry to formulate strategies to take advantage of these changes as an opportunity to make a big leap forward. The aim of this workshop is to stimulate discussion by inviting people from governments, academia and industries for the further development of the Indonesian automotive industry in the CASE and MaaS era.
Event Details
Date: Thursday, 1 December 2022Time: 9 AM to 12 PM (Jakarta time, UTC+7)Place:&nbsp;Meeting Room 3-4, ERIA, Sentral Senayan II, 5th Floor, Jl Asia Afrika, Jakarta (limited space)RSVP for in-person attendance
Streamed via: ZoomRSVP for online attendance
Agenda
Jakarta time (UTC+7)



9 AM to 9:10 AM

Opening Remarks Dr Aladdin D. Rillo, Senior Economic Advisor, ERIA



9 AM to 9:25 AM

Special Remarks&nbsp;Mr Eko S. A. Cahyanto, Director General of Industrial Resilience, Regions and International Access, Ministry of Industry of Indonesia



9:25 AM to 9:55 AM

Keynote LectureMr Masao Suematsu, Senior Vice President of DENSO International Asia Co., Ltd. (DIAT)



9:55 AM to 10:05 AM
Coffee Break


10:05 AM to 11:50 AM

Panel Discussion

Prof. Seio Nakajima, Dean and Professor, Graduate School of Asia-Pacific Studies, Waseda University; Director, Research Institute of Auto Parts Industries, Waseda University, Japan
Dr Yasushi Ueki, Senior Research Fellow, IDE-JETRO
Dr Alloysius Joko Purwanto, Energy Economist, ERIA
Mr R Hendro Martono, Director of Maritime Industry, Transportation and Defence Appliances (IMATAP)
Prof. Sutanto Soehodho, Professor at the Faculty of Technology, University of Indonesia

Moderator: Mr Fusanori Iwasaki, Director for Policy Research, ERIA



11:50 AM to 12 PM

Closing RemarksProf.&nbsp;Yasuhiro Yamada, Special Assistant to the President on Mekong Affairs, ERIA       Virtual Room and ERIA office, Jakarta Devina Anglingdarma devina.anglingdarma@eria.org  ERIA 2022-12-01 0000-00-00 2022-12-01 1 December 2022 2202 rebmeceD 1 10-21-2202 00-00-0000 10-21-2202 AIRE  gro.aire@amradgnilgna.anived amradgnilgnA aniveD atrakaJ ,eciffo AIRE dna mooR lautriV       AIRE ,sriaffA gnokeM no tnediserP eht ot tnatsissA laicepS ,adamaY orihusaY;psbn&.forPskrameR gnisolC

MP 21 ot MA 05:11

AIRE ,tsimonocE ygrenE ,otnawruP okoJ suisyollA rD
ORTEJ-EDI ,wolleF hcraeseR roineS ,ikeU ihsusaY rD
napaJ ,ytisrevinU adesaW ,seirtsudnI straP otuA fo etutitsnI hcraeseR ,rotceriD ;ytisrevinU adesaW ,seidutS cificaP-aisA fo loohcS etaudarG ,rosseforP dna naeD ,amijakaN oieS .forP

noissucsiD lenaP

MA 05:11 ot MA 50:01

)TAID( .dtL ,.oC aisA lanoitanretnI OSNED fo tnediserP eciV roineS ,ustameuS oasaM rMerutceL etonyeK

sliateD tnevE
.are SaaM dna ESAC eht ni yrtsudni evitomotua naisenodnI eht fo tnempoleved rehtruf eht rof seirtsudni dna aimedaca ,stnemnrevog morf elpoep gnitivni yb noissucsid etalumits ot si pohskrow siht fo mia ehT .drawrof pael gib a ekam ot ytinutroppo na sa segnahc eseht fo egatnavda ekat ot seigetarts etalumrof ot yrtsudni evitomotua eht ni devlovni srotces lla rof deen tnegru na si ereht dna ,gniworg era ,noitasilatigid no desab )ecivreS a sa ytiliboM( SaaM dna )deifirtcelE dna ,gnirahS/ecivreS ,suomonotuA ,detcennoC( ESAC sa hcus ,evitomotua eht gnidnuorrus sdnert wen sa ,ralucitrap nI .NAESA fo tnempoleved cimonoce lanoiger eht rof osla tub aisenodnI rof ylno ton eussi tnatropmi na si yrtsudni evitomotua s'yrtnuoc eht fo tnempoleved ehT .timmuS NAESA eht fo riahc eht eb lliw aisenodnI ,3202 nI
 .raey siht pihsnamriahc naisenodnI eht rednu 02G eht fo sucof rojam a osla saw sihT .yrtnuoc eht nihtiw seiticapac noitcudorp yrettab eht gninehtgnerts yb metsysocE yrettab VE eht poleved ot seirt osla tnemnrevog ehT .0302 ni selas elcihev latot fo tnec rep 52 eb lliw hcihw ,noitartenep VE fo tegrat a stes aisenodnI fo yrtsudnI fo yrtsiniM eht ,yltnerruC .ygetarts tnempoleved lanoitan eht ni denoitisop ylegral si taht gnihtemos si ,sVE gnidulcni ,noitcudorp elibomotua fo gninehtgnerts eht dna ,)sVE( selcihev cirtcele fo noitomorp eht tuo tes 9102 ni eerced laitnediserp a ,aisenodnI nI .selcihev noillim 1 revo fo selas launna htiw ,dnaliahT retfa NAESA ni noitcudorp tsegral dnoces eht si yrtsudni elibomotua eht ,eseht gnomA .)NAESA( snoitaN naisA tsaehtuoS fo noitaicossA eht fo PDG eht fo flah tuoba rof stnuocca dna noillim 072 fo noitalupop a htiw yrtnuoc egral a si aisenodnI SaaM dna ESAC fo arE eht ni tnempoleveD yrtsudnI evitomotuA naisenodnI fo seitinutroppO & segnellahC SaaM dna ESAC fo arE eht ni tnempoleveD yrtsudnI evitomotuA naisenodnI fo seitinutroppO & segnellahC";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-11-18 08:40:59";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-11-18 16:01:15";s:11:"modified_by";s:1:"4";s:7:"old_url";s:22:"https://bit.ly/3Gh7WZy";s:10:"majorEmail";s:28:"devina.anglingdarma@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";s:184:"Dr Aladdin D. Rillo, Senior Economic Advisor, ERIA;Mr Eko S. A. Cahyanto, Director General of Industrial Resilience, Regions and International Access, Ministry of Industry of Indonesia";s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:2;O:8:"stdClass":48:{s:19:"article_category_id";s:5:"14416";s:10:"article_id";s:4:"7136";s:11:"category_id";s:3:"243";s:9:"short_des";N;s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:81:"asean-economic-outlook-building-strategies-for-resilient-and-sustainable-recovery";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:82:"ASEAN Economic Outlook: Building Strategies for Resilient and Sustainable Recovery";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-10-26";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:2:"10";s:7:"content";s:5100:"<p><img src="http://www.eria.org/uploads/media/Event%20banner_ASEAN%20Econ%20Outlook_Oct2022.jpg" alt="" width="800" height="450" /></p><p>The ASEAN region is mending strongly with growth expected to reach an average of 5% in the next two years. The growth recovery is predicated on widespread vaccination efforts, easing mobility restrictions, and opening of borders to tourism. Despite this sanguine outlook, the performance in the region also varies with bigger and resource-rich economies growing faster than smaller economies or those dependent on oil and food imports. Sectoral growth is also quite uneven with the nascent recovery in transport, accommodation, and tourism occurring in a protracted manner. This K-shape recovery puts at risk inclusive growth in the region. Global risks have also increased and could weaken the growth outlook through trade and supply chain disruptions, high-commodity prices, and rising financial stress. Last but not least: economic scarring could also slow productivity growth through destruction of human capital, rising trade costs and impediment, and higher interest costs which discourages innovation. The unprecedented scale and impact of COVID-19 pandemic has also put hard-won development progress at risk. For example, poverty estimates show that the number of people in extreme poverty in Southeast Asia has increased by an average of over 5 million in 2020 and 2021, compared to a no-COVID scenario. More so, with limited fiscal space and rising debt, delivering the SDGs and staying on a net-zero path becomes even more difficult.</p><p>The Asian Development Bank (ADB), in partnership with the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) and the United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific (UNESCAP) will hold a webinar on <strong><em>ASEAN Economic Outlook: Building Strategies for Resilient and Sustainable Recovery. </em></strong>The aim of the webinar is to provide the venue to discuss the implications of competing short-term, medium-term, and long-term challenges on the region&rsquo;s prospect for building a resilient and sustainable recovery.</p><p>Some of the questions that will be discussed are:</p><ol><li>There are many economic and social challenges confronting policymakers in Southeast Asia, namely: the K-shape recovery, numerous risks from global headwinds, potential economic scarring in the medium-term, long-term development impact of COVID-19, and the goal of delivering SDGs and net zero. Which among these challenges are the most important? And which among them should be prioritized by policymakers. And why? Are they related in some ways?</li><li>What are the policy instruments that can be used to address the: a) macroeconomic issues and challenges pose by global headwinds, K-shape recovery, and economic scarring; and b) social and development issues related to poverty and inequality, and accelerating SDG progress and achieving a net zero society?</li></ol><h2>Schedule</h2><ul><li>Date: Wednesday, 26 October 2022</li><li>Time: 10:00 AM &ndash; 11:30 AM (Manila/UTC+8)</li><li>Venue:&nbsp;Virtual Room</li></ul><h2>Agenda</h2><table><tr><td width="161"><p>10:00 - 10:05</p></td><td width="463"><p><strong>Start of the Webinar</strong></p><p>Moderator:</p><ul><li><strong>Anna Fink</strong>, Country Economist, Southeast Asia Department, Asian Development Bank</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td width="161"><p>10:05 - 10:15</p></td><td width="463"><p><strong>Opening Remarks</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Ramesh Subramaniam</strong>, Director General, Southeast Asia Department, ADB<strong><br /></strong></li></ul></td></tr><tr><td width="161"><p>10:15 &ndash; 10:20</p></td><td width="463"><p><strong>Video of Southeast Asia&rsquo;s Economic Performance plays</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td width="161"><p>10:20 -10:30</p></td><td width="463"><p><strong>Keynote Presentation </strong></p><ul><li><strong>Shuvojit Banerjee</strong>, Officer-in-charge, Macroeconomic Policy and Analysis Section, UNESCAP - presents the findings and key messages of their report on Economic and Social Survey of Asia and the Pacific 2022: Economic Policies for an Inclusive Recovery and Development</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td width="161"><p>10:30 - 11:15</p></td><td width="463"><p><strong>Panel Discussion </strong></p><ul><li><strong>TBD</strong>, Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas, Philippines</li><li><strong>Datuk Dr. Suhana Binti MD. Saleh</strong>, Director, Economic Planning Unit, Malaysia</li><li><strong>Aladdin D. Rillo, </strong>Senior Economic Advisor, Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA)</li><li><strong>James P. Villafuerte</strong>, Principal Economist, ADB</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td width="161"><p>11:15 - 11:30</p></td><td width="463"><p><strong>Moderated Q&amp;A</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td width="161"><p>11:30</p></td><td width="463"><p><strong>Closing</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Aladdin D Rillo</strong>, ERIA</li></ul></td></tr></table><p><a class="bluebtn" href="https://adb-org.zoom.us/webinar/register/WN_bwKq-JfDS1-OZenImBUL9w">REGISTER HERE</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:22:"ASEAN,economic outlook";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:17:"Ms Amelia Litania";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-10-26";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2022-10-26";s:8:"keywords";s:8693:"ASEAN Economic Outlook: Building Strategies for Resilient and Sustainable Recovery ASEAN Economic Outlook: Building Strategies for Resilient and Sustainable Recovery The ASEAN region is mending strongly with growth expected to reach an average of 5% in the next two years. The growth recovery is predicated on widespread vaccination efforts, easing mobility restrictions, and opening of borders to tourism. Despite this sanguine outlook, the performance in the region also varies with bigger and resource-rich economies growing faster than smaller economies or those dependent on oil and food imports. Sectoral growth is also quite uneven with the nascent recovery in transport, accommodation, and tourism occurring in a protracted manner. This K-shape recovery puts at risk inclusive growth in the region. Global risks have also increased and could weaken the growth outlook through trade and supply chain disruptions, high-commodity prices, and rising financial stress. Last but not least: economic scarring could also slow productivity growth through destruction of human capital, rising trade costs and impediment, and higher interest costs which discourages innovation. The unprecedented scale and impact of COVID-19 pandemic has also put hard-won development progress at risk. For example, poverty estimates show that the number of people in extreme poverty in Southeast Asia has increased by an average of over 5 million in 2020 and 2021, compared to a no-COVID scenario. More so, with limited fiscal space and rising debt, delivering the SDGs and staying on a net-zero path becomes even more difficult.
The Asian Development Bank (ADB), in partnership with the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) and the United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific (UNESCAP) will hold a webinar on ASEAN Economic Outlook: Building Strategies for Resilient and Sustainable Recovery. The aim of the webinar is to provide the venue to discuss the implications of competing short-term, medium-term, and long-term challenges on the region&rsquo;s prospect for building a resilient and sustainable recovery.
Some of the questions that will be discussed are:

There are many economic and social challenges confronting policymakers in Southeast Asia, namely: the K-shape recovery, numerous risks from global headwinds, potential economic scarring in the medium-term, long-term development impact of COVID-19, and the goal of delivering SDGs and net zero. Which among these challenges are the most important? And which among them should be prioritized by policymakers. And why? Are they related in some ways?
What are the policy instruments that can be used to address the: a) macroeconomic issues and challenges pose by global headwinds, K-shape recovery, and economic scarring; and b) social and development issues related to poverty and inequality, and accelerating SDG progress and achieving a net zero society?

Schedule

Date: Wednesday, 26 October 2022
Time: 10:00 AM &ndash; 11:30 AM (Manila/UTC+8)
Venue:&nbsp;Virtual Room

Agenda




10:00 - 10:05


Start of the Webinar
Moderator:

Anna Fink, Country Economist, Southeast Asia Department, Asian Development Bank





10:05 - 10:15


Opening Remarks

Ramesh Subramaniam, Director General, Southeast Asia Department, ADB





10:15 &ndash; 10:20


Video of Southeast Asia&rsquo;s Economic Performance plays




10:20 -10:30


Keynote Presentation 

Shuvojit Banerjee, Officer-in-charge, Macroeconomic Policy and Analysis Section, UNESCAP - presents the findings and key messages of their report on Economic and Social Survey of Asia and the Pacific 2022: Economic Policies for an Inclusive Recovery and Development





10:30 - 11:15


Panel Discussion 

TBD, Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas, Philippines
Datuk Dr. Suhana Binti MD. Saleh, Director, Economic Planning Unit, Malaysia
Aladdin D. Rillo, Senior Economic Advisor, Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA)
James P. Villafuerte, Principal Economist, ADB





11:15 - 11:30


Moderated Q&amp;A




11:30


Closing

Aladdin D Rillo, ERIA

detcepxe htworg htiw ylgnorts gnidnem si noiger NAESA ehT yrevoceR elbaniatsuS dna tneiliseR rof seigetartS gnidliuB :kooltuO cimonocE NAESA yrevoceR elbaniatsuS dna tneiliseR rof seigetartS gnidliuB :kooltuO cimonocE NAESA";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-10-13 15:09:47";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-10-24 17:11:09";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"19";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:23:"amelia.litania@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:3;O:8:"stdClass":48:{s:19:"article_category_id";s:5:"14296";s:10:"article_id";s:4:"7075";s:11:"category_id";s:3:"243";s:9:"short_des";N;s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:68:"pandemic-best-policy-strategies-part-ii-balancing-health-and-economy";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:69:"Pandemic Best Policy Strategies Part II: Balancing Health and Economy";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-10-13";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:2:"10";s:7:"content";s:3950:"<p><img src="/uploads/media/2022_Oct_Pandemic-Best-Policy-Strategies_800x450.jpg" alt="" width="678" height="339" /></p><p>Although many pandemic experts predicted the COVID-19 pandemic to follow the path of other pandemics in history and drizzle away after two years, the Omicron variants have pushed the timeline to now approach three. Inevitably, Governments across the globe have been hard-pressed to work alone within their borders as well as together across borders while striving to balance health and economy. Within the diverse community of ERIA Member States alone, a variety of measures have been tackled to survive through attempts to balance each nation&rsquo;s health and economy.</p><p>This webinar series offers the opportunity to share knowledge and experience from each ERIA Member State (EMS) about what they have learned to be most effective, in order to more smoothly exit this pandemic and if necessary, how to live with its endemicity as well as to better prepare for upcoming ones.</p><p>In the first part of this series, Indonesia, the Philippines, Thailand, India, Japan, and a senior economist from ERIA shared their notable policy experiences. Due to popular demand, this part two will invite six speakers from other EMSs (candidates are Cambodia, Malaysia, Myanmar, Singapore, Viet Nam, Australia, and China). The webinar will be conducted in English.</p><h2>Objectives</h2><ol><li>Enhance public awareness of pandemic best policy strategies that have been implemented and observed to balance health and economy successfully within the region.</li><li>Share actual innovative pandemic best practices from both developing and developed economies within the region.</li><li>Document pandemic best practices that can be referred to in preparation for and during upcoming pandemics and related health emergencies.</li><li>Build and strengthen collaborations by better understanding the situations of neighbors.</li><li>Explore the needs of collaborations in research and development within the region.</li></ol><h2>Event Details</h2><ul><li>Date: Thursday, 13 October 2022</li><li>Time: 2:00 PM - 4:00 PM (Jakarta/UTC+7)</li></ul><h2>Agenda</h2><table><tr><td width="118"><p>14:00-14:05</p></td><td width="486"><p><strong>Welcome Remarks:&nbsp;</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Dr Takuma Kato, </strong>Director of Healthcare Unit, ERIA</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td width="118"><p>14:05-14:50</p></td><td width="486"><p><strong>Part 1</strong></p><p><em>Moderator:</em></p><ul><li><strong>Dr Antonio Villanueva</strong>, Senior Advisor on Healthcare Policy, ERIA</li></ul><p><em>Experts:</em></p><ul><li><strong>Dr Sovann Ly</strong>, Advisor to Ministry of Health as Secretary of State, Phnom Penh, Cambodia</li><li><strong>Prof Kun Tang</strong>,&nbsp;Vanke School of Public Health, Tsinghua University, Beijing, China</li><li><strong>Dr Lili Yan Ing</strong>, Lead Advisor for Southeast Asia, ERIA</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td width="118"><p>14:50-14:55</p></td><td width="486"><p><strong>Break</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td width="118"><p>14:55-15:25</p></td><td width="486"><p><strong>Part 2</strong></p><p><em>Moderator:</em></p><ul><li><strong>Ms Asuka Nagatani</strong>, Senior Policy Officer of Healthcare Unit, ERIA</li></ul><p><em>Experts:</em></p><ul><li><strong>Prof Alex Cook</strong>, Vice Dean, Saw Swee Hock School of Public Health, National University of Singapore</li><li><strong>Dr Tran Mai Oanh</strong>, Director, Health Strategy and Policy Institute, Hanoi, Viet Nam</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td width="118">&nbsp;15:25-15:45</td><td width="486"><p><strong>Q&amp;A:</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Ms Isabella Italia Gentajaya,&nbsp;</strong>Information and Communications, ERIA</li></ul></td></tr></table><p><a class="bluebtn" href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/pandemic-best-policy-strategies-part-ii-balancing-health-and-economy-tickets-431502414337" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Register Now!</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:19:"healthcare,pandemic";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:14:"Ms Nanda Putri";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-10-13";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2022-10-13";s:8:"keywords";s:6333:"Pandemic Best Policy Strategies Part II: Balancing Health and Economy Pandemic Best Policy Strategies Part II: Balancing Health and Economy Although many pandemic experts predicted the COVID-19 pandemic to follow the path of other pandemics in history and drizzle away after two years, the Omicron variants have pushed the timeline to now approach three. Inevitably, Governments across the globe have been hard-pressed to work alone within their borders as well as together across borders while striving to balance health and economy. Within the diverse community of ERIA Member States alone, a variety of measures have been tackled to survive through attempts to balance each nation&rsquo;s health and economy.
This webinar series offers the opportunity to share knowledge and experience from each ERIA Member State (EMS) about what they have learned to be most effective, in order to more smoothly exit this pandemic and if necessary, how to live with its endemicity as well as to better prepare for upcoming ones.
In the first part of this series, Indonesia, the Philippines, Thailand, India, Japan, and a senior economist from ERIA shared their notable policy experiences. Due to popular demand, this part two will invite six speakers from other EMSs (candidates are Cambodia, Malaysia, Myanmar, Singapore, Viet Nam, Australia, and China). The webinar will be conducted in English.
Objectives

Enhance public awareness of pandemic best policy strategies that have been implemented and observed to balance health and economy successfully within the region.
Share actual innovative pandemic best practices from both developing and developed economies within the region.
Document pandemic best practices that can be referred to in preparation for and during upcoming pandemics and related health emergencies.
Build and strengthen collaborations by better understanding the situations of neighbors.
Explore the needs of collaborations in research and development within the region.

Event Details

Date: Thursday, 13 October 2022
Time: 2:00 PM - 4:00 PM (Jakarta/UTC+7)

Agenda

Dr Tran Mai Oanh, Director, Health Strategy and Policy Institute, Hanoi, Viet Nam

Ms Isabella Italia Gentajaya,&nbsp;Information and Communications, ERIA

cimednaP";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-09-28 09:32:23";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-10-13 12:07:50";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"13";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:20:"nanda.putri@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:4;O:8:"stdClass":48:{s:19:"article_category_id";s:5:"14210";s:10:"article_id";s:4:"7019";s:11:"category_id";s:3:"243";s:9:"short_des";N;s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:65:"digital-transformation-with-the-cloud-eria-aws-adb-webinar-series";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:66:"Digital Transformation with the Cloud: ERIA-AWS-ADB Webinar Series";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-10-06";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:2:"10";s:7:"content";s:3869:"<p><img src="/uploads/media/FN-Digital%20Transformation%20with%20the%20Cloud%20Webinar%20Poster%20%20(Instagram%20Post%20(Square)).pdf" alt="" /><img src="/uploads/media/FN-Digital%20Transformation%20with%20the%20Cloud%20Webinar%20Poster%20%20(Instagram%20Post%20(Square)).png" alt="" width="601" height="601" /><img src="/uploads/media/FN-Digital%20Transformation%20with%20the%20Cloud%20Webinar%20Poster%20%20(Instagram%20Post%20(Square)).pdf" alt="" /><img src="/uploads/media/FN-Digital%20Transformation%20with%20the%20Cloud%20Webinar%20Poster%20%20(Instagram%20Post%20(Square)).pdf" alt="" /></p><p>Over the past decade, cloud computing has revolutionized how people and organizations work around the world by democratizing access to technology, affording organizations of all sizes with access to a plethora of digital tools, as well as the security and sustainability benefits of the cloud. Cloud computing is the foundational enabler of the digital transformation of governments, businesses and organizations of all sizes; the default pathway for innovation. Today, governments, public sector organizations, not-for-profits, universities, small and medium enterprises, and enterprises of all sizes across Asia innovate better, faster, and more cost-efficiently through the cloud. Yet, many organizations, both in the public and private sector, have a rudimentary understanding of the cloud and the policies that can enable cloud adoption across different sectors.</p><p>&nbsp;<strong>Asian Development Bank (ADB), the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) and Amazon Web Services (AWS) are hosting a series of Policy Webinars centered around the theme of &ldquo;Digital Transformation with the Cloud&rdquo;. </strong>This Policy Webinar series is a multi-stakeholder dialogue that will bring together policymakers, regulators, think tanks, academia, industry, and other key stakeholders to explore how the cloud and forward-thinking, pro-innovation digital policies can accelerate the digital transformation journey of nations. It will focus on enhancing our collective understanding about the cloud, its benefits, and the policy best practices for digital transformation through the cloud. The Launch Webinar will be held on <strong>6 Oct 2022</strong> and will focus on the theme of digital inclusion in the Cloud with the theme<em> &ldquo;</em><strong>Building Blocks for a Cloud First Environment</strong>&rdquo;. The panel discussion will cover topics that lay the foundation for creating a Cloud First environment and the way forward for building a Cloud First mindset in the Asia-Pacific and beyond.</p><h2>Schedule</h2><ul><li>Date: Thursday, 6 October 2022</li><li>Time: 2:00 PM - 3:30 PM (Singapore Time/GMT+8)</li></ul><h2>Agenda</h2><p>Opening remarks:</p><ul><li>Alfredo Perdiguero, Director of the Regional Cooperation and Operations Coordination, Southeast Asia Department, Asian Development Bank</li></ul><p>Keynote speech:</p><ul><li>Agne Makauskaite, Head of Public Policy for Regulated Industries, Asia Pacific and Japan, AWS&nbsp;</li></ul><p>Panel discussion speakers:</p><ul><li>Thomas Abell, Advisor, Digital Technology for Development, ADB</li><li>Semuel A. Pangerapan, Director General of Application Informatics, Ministry of ICT, Indonesia</li><li>Mary Joy Abueg, President of the National ICT Confederation of the Philippines</li><li>Tahir Hashmi, SVP of Engineering atTokopedia and CTO at Dekara</li></ul><p>Moderator:</p><ul><li>Moderator: May-Ann Lim, Director, Fair Tech Institute &amp; Emeritus Director, Asia Cloud Computing Association</li></ul><p>Closing remarks:</p><ul><li>Lili Yan Ing,&nbsp;Lead Advisor on Southeast Asia Region, ERIA</li></ul><p><a class="bluebtn" href="https://adb-org.zoom.us/webinar/register/WN_VHvNCE80SB-plaGTZFsk0g" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">REGISTER HERE</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:29:"digital transformation,Policy";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:17:"Ms Amelia Litania";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-10-06";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2022-10-06";s:8:"keywords";s:6377:"Digital Transformation with the Cloud: ERIA-AWS-ADB Webinar Series Digital Transformation with the Cloud: ERIA-AWS-ADB Webinar Series Over the past decade, cloud computing has revolutionized how people and organizations work around the world by democratizing access to technology, affording organizations of all sizes with access to a plethora of digital tools, as well as the security and sustainability benefits of the cloud. Cloud computing is the foundational enabler of the digital transformation of governments, businesses and organizations of all sizes; the default pathway for innovation. Today, governments, public sector organizations, not-for-profits, universities, small and medium enterprises, and enterprises of all sizes across Asia innovate better, faster, and more cost-efficiently through the cloud. Yet, many organizations, both in the public and private sector, have a rudimentary understanding of the cloud and the policies that can enable cloud adoption across different sectors.
&nbsp;Asian Development Bank (ADB), the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) and Amazon Web Services (AWS) are hosting a series of Policy Webinars centered around the theme of &ldquo;Digital Transformation with the Cloud&rdquo;. This Policy Webinar series is a multi-stakeholder dialogue that will bring together policymakers, regulators, think tanks, academia, industry, and other key stakeholders to explore how the cloud and forward-thinking, pro-innovation digital policies can accelerate the digital transformation journey of nations. It will focus on enhancing our collective understanding about the cloud, its benefits, and the policy best practices for digital transformation through the cloud. The Launch Webinar will be held on 6 Oct 2022 and will focus on the theme of digital inclusion in the Cloud with the theme &ldquo;Building Blocks for a Cloud First Environment&rdquo;. The panel discussion will cover topics that lay the foundation for creating a Cloud First environment and the way forward for building a Cloud First mindset in the Asia-Pacific and beyond.
Schedule

Date: Thursday, 6 October 2022
Time: 2:00 PM - 3:30 PM (Singapore Time/GMT+8)

Agenda
Opening remarks:

Alfredo Perdiguero, Director of the Regional Cooperation and Operations Coordination, Southeast Asia Department, Asian Development Bank

Keynote speech:

Agne Makauskaite, Head of Public Policy for Regulated Industries, Asia Pacific and Japan, AWS&nbsp;

Panel discussion speakers:

Thomas Abell, Advisor, Digital Technology for Development, ADB
Semuel A. Pangerapan, Director General of Application Informatics, Ministry of ICT, Indonesia
Mary Joy Abueg, President of the National ICT Confederation of the Philippines
Tahir Hashmi, SVP of Engineering atTokopedia and CTO at Dekara

Moderator:

Moderator: May-Ann Lim, Director, Fair Tech Institute &amp; Emeritus Director, Asia Cloud Computing Association

Closing remarks:

Lili Yan Ing,&nbsp;Lead Advisor on Southeast Asia Region, ERIA

noitamrofsnarT latigiD";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-09-08 12:21:29";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-10-05 14:42:24";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"18";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:23:"amelia.litania@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:5;O:8:"stdClass":48:{s:19:"article_category_id";s:5:"13591";s:10:"article_id";s:4:"7012";s:11:"category_id";s:3:"243";s:9:"short_des";N;s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:73:"the-eus-carbon-border-adjustment-mechanism-implication-for-southeast-asia";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:75:"The EU's Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism: Implication for Southeast Asia";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-09-09";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"9";s:7:"content";s:1819:"<p><img src="/uploads/media/Webinar%20%20CBAM%20Poster.jpg" alt="" width="800" height="1132" /></p><p>As a region which trades heavily with the European Union, the bloc&rsquo;s planned Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM) is likely to have deep and meaningful effects on ASEAN economies. Beyond this, and as carbon pricing instruments proliferate, an increasing number of countries are likely to follow the EU&rsquo;s lead in implementing carbon border taxes in order to protect the competitiveness of local industries against competitors whose products originate from jurisdictions without domestic carbon pricing legislation, and to prevent carbon leakage. Border adjustment taxes can also spur countries towards enacting their own domestic carbon pricing instruments and in doing so, can be a tool towards the export of climate ambition. Serious consideration must be placed on how ASEAN economies respond to this changing climate policy landscape.</p><p>This discussion aims to unpack the EU&rsquo;s proposed CBAM; consider the role of carbon border taxes in international climate policy responses; and overviews the economic and strategic implications of these instruments on Southeast Asian economies and the EU-ASEAN relationship.</p><p>&nbsp;This discussion will feature commentaries from Dr Michael R. DiGregorio and Mr Darshan Joshi of The Asia Foundation; Dr Venkatachalam Anbumozhi of the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA); and Ms Melinda Martinus of the Institute of Southeast Asian Studies&ndash;Yusof Ishak Institute (ISEAS).</p><ul><li>Date: Friday, 9 September 2022</li><li>Time: 3:00 PM - 5:00 PM (Singapore/GMT+8)</li><li>Venue: Webinar (Zoom)</li></ul><p><a class="bluebtn" href="https://us02web.zoom.us/webinar/register/WN_dCctEqBbQb22tSBshQlTTw">Register Here</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:39:"Energy,Carbon Neutrality,Climate Change";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:20:"Ms Abigail Balthazar";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-09-09";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2022-09-09";s:8:"keywords";s:3771:"The EU's Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism: Implication for Southeast Asia The EU's Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism: Implication for Southeast Asia As a region which trades heavily with the European Union, the bloc&rsquo;s planned Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM) is likely to have deep and meaningful effects on ASEAN economies. Beyond this, and as carbon pricing instruments proliferate, an increasing number of countries are likely to follow the EU&rsquo;s lead in implementing carbon border taxes in order to protect the competitiveness of local industries against competitors whose products originate from jurisdictions without domestic carbon pricing legislation, and to prevent carbon leakage. Border adjustment taxes can also spur countries towards enacting their own domestic carbon pricing instruments and in doing so, can be a tool towards the export of climate ambition. Serious consideration must be placed on how ASEAN economies respond to this changing climate policy landscape.
This discussion aims to unpack the EU&rsquo;s proposed CBAM; consider the role of carbon border taxes in international climate policy responses; and overviews the economic and strategic implications of these instruments on Southeast Asian economies and the EU-ASEAN relationship.
&nbsp;This discussion will feature commentaries from Dr Michael R. DiGregorio and Mr Darshan Joshi of The Asia Foundation; Dr Venkatachalam Anbumozhi of the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA); and Ms Melinda Martinus of the Institute of Southeast Asian Studies&ndash;Yusof Ishak Institute (ISEAS).

Date: Friday, 9 September 2022
Time: 3:00 PM - 5:00 PM (Singapore/GMT+8)
Venue: Webinar (Zoom)

.epacsdnal ycilop etamilc gnignahc siht ot dnopser seimonoce NAESA woh no decalp eb tsum noitaredisnoc suoireS .noitibma etamilc fo tropxe eht sdrawot loot a eb nac ,os gniod ni dna stnemurtsni gnicirp nobrac citsemod nwo rieht gnitcane sdrawot seirtnuoc rups osla nac sexat tnemtsujda redroB .egakael nobrac tneverp ot dna ,noitalsigel gnicirp nobrac citsemod tuohtiw snoitcidsiruj morf etanigiro stcudorp esohw srotitepmoc tsniaga seirtsudni lacol fo ssenevititepmoc eht tcetorp ot redro ni sexat redrob nobrac gnitnemelpmi ni dael s;ouqsr&UE eht wollof ot ylekil era seirtnuoc fo tnemtsujdA redroB nobraC s'UE ehT";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-09-07 17:10:37";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-09-08 12:07:06";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"19";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:26:"abigail.balthazar@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:6;O:8:"stdClass":48:{s:19:"article_category_id";s:5:"13784";s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6986";s:11:"category_id";s:3:"243";s:9:"short_des";N;s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:47:"the-second-asia-ccus-network-forum-hybrid-forum";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:49:"The Second Asia CCUS Network Forum | Hybrid Forum";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-09-30";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"9";s:7:"content";s:7747:"<p><img src="/uploads/media/Events/The%20Second%20Asia%20CCUS%20Network%20Forum-new(2).png" alt="" width="800" height="400" /></p><p>After the COP26 held in Glasgow, United Kingdom, last autumn 2021, many Asian countries echoed western countries regarding the need to find pathways to achieving carbon neutrality by 2050 and beyond with international assistance. In trying to find such pathways, attention will need to be paid to the accessibility, availability, and affordability of energy supply to achieve reasonable economic growth continuously up until 2050. Therefore, in the energy transition period towards carbon neutrality beyond 2050, a gradual shift from coal to gas in power generation will be an important policy to reduce emissions. Co-firing of hydrogen and ammonia with gas and coal power plants is another important policy to move towards carbon neutrality together with maximising the share of variable renewable energy and minimising the share of electric storage. Besides, switching to cleaner fuels such as gas, ammonia, and hydrogen, and to clean technologies, an application of CCUS will be the most appropriate clean energy technologies for the Asian region to achieve net zero emissions. Current challenge to apply CCUS technology is due to geopolitical factors that affect international fossil fuel market. The significant increase of fossil fuels&rsquo; price will lead to an additional investment on fossil fuel that means its consumption and CO2 emissions will also increase.</p><p>Looking at the Asian region, Indonesia prepared a draft CCS/CCUS regulation, which is currently awaiting approval by the president. Moreover, PETRONAS is ready to start CCS projects with a Japanese company. Various activities have been organised by the Asia CCUS Network over the past year &ndash; knowledge sharing, research studies, and capacity building trainings.</p><p>The aim of the Second Asia CCUS Network Forum is to report the ACN&rsquo;s activities in 2021&ndash;2202 and the workplan of ACN&rsquo;s activities/milestones for 2022&ndash;2023, after the ministerial remarks, and the Second Forum will hold panel discussions to review the current CCUS situation and policies in the East Asia Summit (EAS) region concerning issues and challenges of CCUS deployment in the region. The Second Forum invites the CCS+ Initiative to introduce its activities regarding the calculation of carbon credit for CCS businesses</p><p>The Asia CCUS Network Forum is co-hosted by Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) as Secretariat of Asia CCUS Network (ACN) and Ministry of Economy, Trade, and Industry (METI), Japan.</p><h2>Event Details</h2><ul><li>Date: Friday, 30 September 2022</li><li>Time: 09:00 AM - 12:00 PM (Japan/JST)</li><li>Venue: Tokyo, Japan | Hybrid Forum</li></ul><h2>Agenda</h2><table style="width: 640.549px;"><tr style="height: 43px;"><td style="width: 176px; height: 43px;"><p>08:30 AM &ndash; 09:00 AM&nbsp;&nbsp;</p></td><td style="width: 448.549px; height: 43px;"><p><strong>Registration </strong></p></td></tr><tr style="height: 129px;"><td style="width: 176px; height: 129px;"><p>09:00 AM &ndash; 09:10 AM</p></td><td style="width: 448.549px; height: 129px;"><p><strong>Welcoming and Opening Remarks</strong></p><ul><li>Minister of Economy, Trade, and Industry (METI), Japan</li><li><strong>Prof Hidetoshi Nishimura</strong>, President of ERIA&nbsp;</li></ul><p><em>Followed by <strong>Group Photo</strong></em></p></td></tr><tr style="height: 132px;"><td style="width: 176px; height: 132px;"><p>09:10 AM &ndash; 10:10 AM</p></td><td style="width: 448.549px; height: 132px;"><p><strong>Ministerial remarks</strong></p><p>Congratulatory remarks by several EAS Energy Ministers</p><p>Brunei Darussalam, Cambodia, Indonesia, Lao PDR, Malaysia, India, Singapore, Thailand, Viet Nam, Australia, and the United States (TBC)</p><ul><li><strong>H.E. Arifin Tasrif</strong>, Minister of Energy and Mineral Resource, Indonesia</li><li><strong>H.E. Gas Upstream Unit,&nbsp;Japan Oil, Gas and Metals National Corporation (JOGMEC)&nbsp;</li><li><p><strong>Mr Patrick BÅ±rgi</strong>, Director Innovation, South Pole, and Co-Founder of the CCS+ Initiative&nbsp;</p></li></ul></td></tr><tr style="height: 109px;"><td style="width: 176px; height: 626px;"><p>11:00 AM &ndash; 11:55 AM</p><p><em>&nbsp;</em></p></td><td style="width: 448.549px; height: 626px;"><p><strong>Panel Session: &lsquo;</strong><strong>CCS Policies in EAS Countries&rsquo; &ndash; Issues and Challenges on CO2 Deployment and CO2 Value Chain</strong></p><p><em>Moderator:</em></p><ul><li><strong>Mr Shigeru Kimura</strong>, Special Advisor on Energy Affairs, ERIA</li></ul><p><strong>Panellists:</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Ms Ayaka Jones</strong>, International Technical Advisor, Strategic Engagement, Office of Clean Coal and Carbon Manage, Office of Fossil Energy and Carbon Management, Department of Energy (DOE), United States</li><li><strong>Mr Norihiro Saeki</strong>, Director of CCUS Policy, Agency of Natural Resources and Energy, METI, Japan</li><li><em>&nbsp;</em><strong>Ms Jocelyn Taylor</strong>, Manager, International CCUS Policy, Department of Industry, Science, Energy and Resources (DISER), Australia</li><li><strong>Dr. Ir. Muhammad Wafid A.N, M.Sc.</strong>, Senior Advisor for Environment and Spatial Planning, Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources, Indonesia</li><li><strong>Mr Zaharin Zulkifli, Deputy Director</strong>, Energy Data and Research Unit, Strategic Planning and Communication Department, Energy Commission of Malaysia</li><li><strong>Mr Jesus Tamang, </strong>Director, Energy Policy and Planning Bureau, Department of Energy, Philippines</li></ul><p><em>Followed by <strong>Questions and Answers</strong> </em></p></td></tr><tr style="height: 93.3999px;"><td style="width: 176px; height: 93.3999px;"><p>11:55 AM &ndash; 12:00 PM</p></td><td style="width: 448.549px; height: 93.3999px;"><p><strong>Closing Remarks</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Mr Yuki Sadamitsu</strong>, Director General, Natural Resources and Fuel Department, Agency for Natural Resources and Energy (ANRE), Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry (METI), Japan</li></ul><ul><li><strong>Mr Koji Hachiyama</strong>, Chief Operating Officer, ERIA</li></ul></td></tr></table><p><strong><a class="bluebtn" href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/411110782417" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">ONLINE REGISTRATION</a></strong></p><p><strong><a class="bluebtn" href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/the-second-asia-ccus-network-forum-in-person-tickets-411834256347" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">IN-PERSON REGISTRATION (limited seats)</a></strong></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:35:"CCUS,forum,hybrid,hybrid event,METI";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Tokyo, Japan";s:5:"major";s:16:"Ms Dian Lutfiana";s:16:"article_keywords";s:4:"CCUS";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-09-30";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2022-09-30";s:8:"keywords";s:11617:"The Second Asia CCUS Network Forum | Hybrid Forum The Second Asia CCUS Network Forum | Hybrid Forum After the COP26 held in Glasgow, United Kingdom, last autumn 2021, many Asian countries echoed western countries regarding the need to find pathways to achieving carbon neutrality by 2050 and beyond with international assistance. In trying to find such pathways, attention will need to be paid to the accessibility, availability, and affordability of energy supply to achieve reasonable economic growth continuously up until 2050. Therefore, in the energy transition period towards carbon neutrality beyond 2050, a gradual shift from coal to gas in power generation will be an important policy to reduce emissions. Co-firing of hydrogen and ammonia with gas and coal power plants is another important policy to move towards carbon neutrality together with maximising the share of variable renewable energy and minimising the share of electric storage. Besides, switching to cleaner fuels such as gas, ammonia, and hydrogen, and to clean technologies, an application of CCUS will be the most appropriate clean energy technologies for the Asian region to achieve net zero emissions. Current challenge to apply CCUS technology is due to geopolitical factors that affect international fossil fuel market. The significant increase of fossil fuels&rsquo; price will lead to an additional investment on fossil fuel that means its consumption and CO2 emissions will also increase.
Looking at the Asian region, Indonesia prepared a draft CCS/CCUS regulation, which is currently awaiting approval by the president. Moreover, PETRONAS is ready to start CCS projects with a Japanese company. Various activities have been organised by the Asia CCUS Network over the past year &ndash; knowledge sharing, research studies, and capacity building trainings.
The aim of the Second Asia CCUS Network Forum is to report the ACN&rsquo;s activities in 2021&ndash;2202 and the workplan of ACN&rsquo;s activities/milestones for 2022&ndash;2023, after the ministerial remarks, and the Second Forum will hold panel discussions to review the current CCUS situation and policies in the East Asia Summit (EAS) region concerning issues and challenges of CCUS deployment in the region. The Second Forum invites the CCS+ Initiative to introduce its activities regarding the calculation of carbon credit for CCS businesses
The Asia CCUS Network Forum is co-hosted by Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) as Secretariat of Asia CCUS Network (ACN) and Ministry of Economy, Trade, and Industry (METI), Japan.
Event Details

Date: Friday, 30 September 2022
Time: 09:00 AM - 12:00 PM (Japan/JST)
Venue: Tokyo, Japan | Hybrid Forum

Agenda




08:30 AM &ndash; 09:00 AM&nbsp;&nbsp;


Registration 




09:00 AM &ndash; 09:10 AM


Welcoming and Opening Remarks

Minister of Economy, Trade, and Industry (METI), Japan
Prof Hidetoshi Nishimura, President of ERIA&nbsp;

Followed by Group Photo




09:10 AM &ndash; 10:10 AM


Ministerial remarks
Congratulatory remarks by several EAS Energy Ministers
Brunei Darussalam, Cambodia, Indonesia, Lao PDR, Malaysia, India, Singapore, Thailand, Viet Nam, Australia, and the United States (TBC)

H.E. Arifin Tasrif, Minister of Energy and Mineral Resource, Indonesia
H.E. Raphael Perpetuo Mercado Lotilla, Secretary of&nbsp; &nbsp;Department of Energy, Philippines
Mr Kulit Sombatsiri, Permanent Secretary of Energy of Thailand
H.E. Brad Crabtree, Assistant Secretary for Fossil Energy and Carbon Management, Department of Energy, United States





10:10 AM &ndash; 10:50 AM


Keynote Speech&nbsp;

Mr Alex Zapantis, General Manager of Global CCS Institute (GCCSI)&nbsp;
Koji Yamamoto, PhD., Vice President, Oil &amp; Gas Upstream Unit,&nbsp;Japan Oil, Gas and Metals National Corporation (JOGMEC)&nbsp;

Mr Patrick BÅ±rgi, Director Innovation, South Pole, and Co-Founder of the CCS+ Initiative&nbsp;






10:50 AM &ndash; 11:00 AM


ACN Annual Report 2021&ndash;2022

Dr Han Phoumin, Senior Energy Economist, Energy Unit, ERIA and Senior Officer of ACN Secretariat&nbsp;





11:00 AM &ndash; 11:55 AM
&nbsp;


Panel Session: &lsquo;CCS Policies in EAS Countries&rsquo; &ndash; Issues and Challenges on CO2 Deployment and CO2 Value Chain
Moderator:

Mr Shigeru Kimura, Special Advisor on Energy Affairs, ERIA

Panellists:

Ms Ayaka Jones, International Technical Advisor, Strategic Engagement, Office of Clean Coal and Carbon Manage, Office of Fossil Energy and Carbon Management, Department of Energy (DOE), United States
Mr Norihiro Saeki, Director of CCUS Policy, Agency of Natural Resources and Energy, METI, Japan
&nbsp;Ms Jocelyn Taylor, Manager, International CCUS Policy, Department of Industry, Science, Energy and Resources (DISER), Australia
Dr. Ir. Muhammad Wafid A.N, M.Sc., Senior Advisor for Environment and Spatial Planning, Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources, Indonesia
Mr Zaharin Zulkifli, Deputy Director, Energy Data and Research Unit, Strategic Planning and Communication Department, Energy Commission of Malaysia
Mr Jesus Tamang, Director, Energy Policy and Planning Bureau, Department of Energy, Philippines

Followed by Questions and Answers 




11:55 AM &ndash; 12:00 PM

Mr Yuki Sadamitsu, Director General, Natural Resources and Fuel Department, Agency for Natural Resources and Energy (ANRE), Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry (METI), Japan


Mr Koji Hachiyama, Chief Operating Officer, ERIA

muroF dirbyH | napaJ ,oykoT :euneV
)TSJ/napaJ( MP 00:21 - MA 00:90 :emiT
2202 rebmetpeS 03 ,yadirF :etaD

sliateD tnevE
.napaJ ,)ITEM( yrtsudnI dna ,edarT ,ymonocE fo yrtsiniM dna )NCA( krowteN SUCC aisA fo tairaterceS sa )AIRE( aisA tsaE dna NAESA rof etutitsnI hcraeseR cimonocE yb detsoh-oc si muroF krowteN SUCC aisA ehT

muroF dirbyH | muroF krowteN SUCC aisA dnoceS ehT muroF dirbyH | muroF krowteN SUCC aisA dnoceS ehT";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-08-31 11:43:51";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-09-22 16:21:47";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"13";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:22:"dian.lutfiana@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:7;O:8:"stdClass":48:{s:19:"article_category_id";s:5:"13438";s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6984";s:11:"category_id";s:3:"243";s:9:"short_des";N;s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:48:"t20-advancing-the-global-circular-carbon-economy";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:48:"T20 Date: Friday, 2 September 2022
Time: 8:00 AM - 3:00 PM (Bali Time/GMT+8)
Venue:&nbsp;The Ritz-Carlton, Nusa Dua, Bali

Agenda




8:00 AM - 8:30 AM


Refreshments




8:30 AM - 9:00 AM


Welcome and Introduction

Fahad M. Alturki, Vice President, Knowledge and Analysis, KAPSARC
Bambang P.S. Brodjonegoro,&nbsp;Universitas Indonesia, Chair, T20 Indonesia





9:00 AM - 10:30 AM


T20, G20 and Global Climate Governance
Speakers:

Fahad Alturki&nbsp;&ndash;Vice President, Knowledge and Analysis, KAPSARC
Paolo Magri&nbsp;&ndash; National Coordinator and Chair, T20 Italy; Executive Vice President, Italian Institute for International Political Studies (ISPI)
Bambang S. Brodjonegoro, Universitas Indonesia, Chair, T20 Indonesia
Dongmei Chen&nbsp;&ndash; Fellow, Oil &amp; Gas, KAPSARC

Moderator:
Noura Y. Mansouri&nbsp;&ndash; Fellow, Climate &amp; Sustainability, KAPSARC; Co-Chair TF3, T20 Indonesia



&nbsp;10:30 AM - 11:00 AM

Coffee Break




11:00 AM - 12:30 AM


Towards a Just Energy Transition
Speakers:

Manal Shehabi&nbsp;&ndash; Independent Advisor, SHEER
Venkatachalam Anbumozhi&nbsp;&ndash; ERIA
Dina Azhgaliyeva &ndash;&nbsp;ADB Institute
Emre Hatipoglu &ndash;&nbsp;Fellow, Oil &amp; Gas, KAPSARC

Moderator:
Moekti Handajani Soejachmoen&nbsp;&ndash; Co-Founder &amp; Executive Director, Indonesia Research Institute for Decarbonization (IRID)




12:30 AM - 1:30 PM


Lunch Break




1:30 PM - 3:00 PM


Advancing Global Circular Carbon Economy for Meeting Net Zero Targets
Speakers:

Hasan Muslemani, Senior Research Fellow &amp; Head of Carbon Management Research, Oxford Institute for Energy Studies (OIES)

Puneet Kamboj&nbsp;&ndash; Associate, Climate &amp; Sustainability, KAPSARC

Moderator:
Noura Y. Mansouri &ndash;&nbsp;Fellow, Climate &amp; Sustainability, KAPSARC; Co-Chair TF3, T20 Indonesia



3:00 PM - 3:05 PM
