sliateD tnevE ymonocE nobraC ralucriC labolG eht gnicnavdA 02T ymonocE nobraC ralucriC labolG eht gnicnavdA 02T";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-08-29 14:59:53";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-08-29 14:59:53";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"19";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:26:"abigail.balthazar@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:8;O:8:"stdClass":48:{s:19:"article_category_id";s:5:"13437";s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6980";s:11:"category_id";s:3:"243";s:9:"short_des";N;s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:70:"g20-and-ai-connecting-the-dotted-lines-between-technology-and-humanity";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:71:"G20 and AI: Connecting the dotted lines between technology and humanity";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-09-04";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"9";s:7:"content";s:13590:"<p>The digital society must be built on trust among all stakeholders including governments, civil society, international organizations, academics and businesses through sharing common values and principles including equality, justice, transparency and accountability taking into account the global economy and interoperability. G20 encompasses world&rsquo;s most powerful political and economic powers and an ideal platform to deliberate, discuss, and debate key issues of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and the newly emerging technologies. Clearer and transparent concepts on AI systems would form the foundation for its development and implementation by addressing some of the growing concerns related to its safety and security as well as governance and ethics. The proposed international conference on &ldquo;G20 and AI: Connecting the dotted lines between technology and humanity&rdquo;, to be held on side lines of meeting of the G20 digital ministers from September 1-2, 2022 in Bali, Indonesia would be an excellent opportunity to support policies and initiatives undertaken by the G20 leadership under the Indonesian Presidency under Track 1.5 and Track 2.0 diplomacy.</p><h4>Session I: G20 and AI - Exploring a new horizon of opportunities and possibilities</h4><p>To build a better future, the G20 needs to raise the level of ambition and digital co-operation. This is particularly important for new technologies such as Artificial Intelligence (AI), quantum computing, blockchain, Internet of Things, among others. The responsible development and use of AI can be a driving force to help advance SDGs and to realize a sustainable and inclusive society while mitigating risks to wider societal values of equity, access, and fairness. Benefits brought by responsible use of AI can improve the work environment and quality of life, creating potential for realizing a human-centred future society with opportunities for everyone. The session will focus on adopting a multi-stakeholder approach towards AI adoption by supporting standards that help transition to an increasingly digital society. The successful incorporation of AI requires public administrations to redefine strategies based on emerging technologies and to develop a functional governance structure. It will exchange views on how G20 can help achieve an inclusive, sustainable, and innovative society through digitalization. The importance of international cooperation for harnessing full potential of emerging technologies like AI will also be discussed which includes enhanced research and development as well as policy formulation for the global citizenry.</p><h4>Session II: AI and digital ecosystem - A transformative experience in the making</h4><p>Digitalization is expected to continue creating benefits for economies and societies as a whole. The benefits brought by increased productivity through the use of emerging technologies such as artificial intelligence (AI), fifth-generation mobile telecommunication technologies (5G), the Internet of Things (IoT), Distributed Ledger Technologies (e.g. block chain) will empower the G20 nations by creating new opportunities and generating new services and employment, all of which can lead to greater well-being and further inclusiveness for both society and individuals. G20 is committed to promoting policies to share benefits from digitalization of economies and societies. This session would facilitate discussion on how the G20 can design and implement policies to maximize benefits and minimize risks from development of the digital ecosystem and how to overcome the resulting challenges. The key focus would be how to support development of a digital ecosystem that supports transition to novel way of thinking and working unleashed by AI. As human civilization leaps into a new frontier of technology enabled lifestyle and living, the challenge is to make the transformative experience rewarding and accessible to all.</p><h4>Session III: AI governance and ethics - The role of the G20 community</h4><p>Issues related to privacy and security in the digital economy are central concerns to the domain of public policy as citizens embrace introduction of big data collection related to artificial intelligence (AI). Citizens seek assurance that AI and automation will be introduced in a manner that respects human integrity and functions within a framework of accountability. While delivering productivity, key issues like safety and privacy need to be adequately addressed. The G20 is committed to promoting a free, open and secure internet that encourages the digital industry to work with stakeholders in fighting misuse of the internet and social media and also safeguarding against violent extremism and addressing content that incites terrorist acts. Against this background, this session would emphasize on recommendations and principles that G20 leaders could formulate in developing an accountability framework. The session would facilitate discussion on exploring potentials of digitalization and addressing concerns that it brings along, including adoption of international standardization on AI led by the G20.</p><h4>Session IV: AI and humans - Maximizing benefits and minimizing risks</h4><p>For G20, AI acts as a governable and interoperable technology that aims to eradicate or minimize inequalities. Like other emerging technologies, AI presents societal challenges, including transitions in the labour market and addressing issues related to privacy, security, ethics, and digital divides. In pursuing human-centred AI, G20 recognizes the importance of promoting protection of privacy and personal data. It also recognizes the need to promote AI capacity building and skills development. This session will explore how some of the international bodies that could serve as focal points to ensure a common framework to regulate the digital environment. As the human-machine interface enters a new phase, this session will look into how to navigate the delicate balance where human ingenuity is complemented and not upstaged by the machine driven efficiency</p><h2>Event Schedule</h2><ul><li>Date: Sunday, 4 September 2022</li><li>Time: 9:00 AM - 05:05 PM (Bali Time/GMT+8)</li><li>Venue:&nbsp;Hilton Hotel, Nusa Dua, Bali</li></ul><h2>Agenda</h2><table style="height: 296px; width: 685px;"><tr><td style="width: 669px; text-align: center;" colspan="2"><strong>Inaugural Session</strong></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 156.112px; text-align: left;">9:00 am &ndash; 9:30 am</td><td style="width: 512.888px; text-align: left;"><p><strong>Registration</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 156.112px;">9.30 am &ndash; 9.35 am</td><td style="width: 512.888px;"><p><strong>Welcome Note</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Prof. Dr Suhono Harso Supangkat</strong>, Lead Chair of Task Force 2, G20 Indonesia &amp; Head of Smart City and Community Innovation Center, Bandung Institute of Technology</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 156.112px;">9.35 am &ndash; 9.40 am</td><td style="width: 512.888px;"><p><strong>Opening Remarks</strong></p><p><strong>Prof. Syed Munir Khasru</strong>, Co-chair of Task Force 2 &amp; 9, G20 Indonesia &amp; Chairman, IPAG Asia Pacific</p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 156.112px;">9.40 am &ndash; 10.00 am</td><td style="width: 512.888px;"><p><strong>Address by Ministerial Panel</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 156.112px;">10.00 am &ndash; 10.30 am</td><td style="width: 512.888px;"><p><strong>Tea &amp; Coffee Break</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 669px; text-align: center;" colspan="2"><p style="text-align: left;"><strong>Session I:&nbsp;G20 and AI - Exploring a new horizon of opportunities and possibilities</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 156.112px;">10.30 am &ndash; 10:40 am</td><td style="width: 512.888px;"><p><strong>Keynote Presentation</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Prof. Syed Munir Khasru</strong>, Co-chair of Task Force 2 &amp; 9, G20 Indonesia &amp; Chairman, IPAG Asia Pacific</li></ul><p><strong>Moderator</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Ajar Edi</strong>, Director, Corporate Affairs at Microsoft Indonesia Member, B20 Indonesia Digitalization Task Force</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 156.112px;">10.40 am &ndash; 10.55 am</td><td style="width: 512.888px;"><p><strong>Panelists</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Dr. Venkatachalam Anbumozhi</strong>, Director of Research Strategy and Innovation, ERIA</li><li><strong>Dr. I Nyoman Sutarja</strong>, Faculty of Engineering, University of Udayana</li><li><strong>Dr. Toshio Obi</strong>, Waseda University - Professor Emeritus</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 156.112px;">10.55 am &ndash; 11.15am</td><td style="width: 512.888px;"><p><strong>Inter Panel Discussion</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 156.112px;">11.15 am &ndash; 11.30 am</td><td style="width: 512.888px;"><p><strong>Q&amp;A and Open Floor Discussion</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 156.112px;">11.30 am &ndash; 11.40 am</td><td style="width: 512.888px;"><p><strong>Break</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 669px; text-align: center;" colspan="2"><p style="text-align: left;"><strong>Session II:&nbsp;AI and the digital ecosystem - A transformative experience in the making</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 156.112px;">11.40 am &ndash; 11.50 am</td><td style="width: 512.888px;"><p><strong>Keynote Presentation</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Prof. Dr Suhono Harso Supangkat</strong>, Lead Chair of Task Force 2, G20 Indonesia &amp; Head of Smart City and Community Innovation Center, Bandung Institute of Technology</li></ul><p><strong>Moderator</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Ms. Arianne Santoso</strong>, Senior Analyst, Government Affairs and Public Policy, Google Indonesia</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 156.112px;">11.50 am &ndash; 12.25 pm</td><td style="width: 512.888px;"><p><strong>Inter Panel Discussion</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 156.112px;">12.25 pm &ndash; 12.40 pm</td><td style="width: 512.888px;"><p><strong>Q&amp;A and Open Floor Discussion</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 156.112px;">12.40 pm &ndash; 1.40 pm</td><td style="width: 512.888px;"><p><strong>Lunch</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 669px; text-align: center;" colspan="2"><p style="text-align: left;"><strong>Session III:&nbsp;AI and humans - Maximizing benefits and minimizing risks</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 156.112px;">1.40 pm &ndash; 2.05 pm</td><td style="width: 512.888px;"><p><strong>Panelists</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Mohan Belani</strong>, CEO, E27</li><li><strong>Dr. Ir. Heru Purboyo Hidayat Putro</strong>, Head of Regional and City Infrastructure System Contractors, Institute Technology of Bandung</li><li><strong>Dr. Arif Perdana</strong>, Assistant Professor, Data Science, Monash University, Indonesia</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 156.112px;">2.05 pm &ndash; 2.25 pm</td><td style="width: 512.888px;"><p><strong>Inter Panel Discussion</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 156.112px;">2.25 pm &ndash; 2.40 pm</td><td style="width: 512.888px;"><p><strong>Q&amp;A and Open Floor Discussion</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 156.112px;">2.40 pm &ndash; 3.05 pm</td><td style="width: 512.888px;"><p><strong>Tea &amp; Coffee Break</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 669px; text-align: center;" colspan="2"><p style="text-align: left;"><strong>Session IV:&nbsp;AI governance and ethics - The role of the G20 community</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 156.112px;">3.05 pm &ndash; 4.05 pm</td><td style="width: 512.888px;"><p><strong>Keynote Presentation</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Prof. Bambang Brodjonego</strong>, Lead Chair Task Force 9, G20 Indonesia &amp; Former Minister of Research and Technology</li></ul><p><strong>Moderator</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Prof. Sachin Chaturvedi</strong>, Director General, Research and Information System (RIS), New Delhi, India</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 156.112px;">4.15 pm &ndash; 4.30 pm</td><td style="width: 512.888px;"><p><strong>Panelists</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Dr. Ir. Lukas</strong>, MAI, CISA, IPM, Chairman, Indonesian Artificial Intelligence Society (IAIS)</li><li><strong>Dr. Muhamad Risqi U. Saputra</strong>, Assistant Professor, Data Science, Monash University, Indonesia</li><li><strong>Dr. Ngakan Putu Gede Suardana</strong>, Faculty of Engineering, University of Udayana</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 156.112px;">4.30 pm &ndash; 4.50 pm</td><td style="width: 512.888px;"><p><strong>Inter Panel Discussion</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 156.112px;">4.50 pm &ndash; 5.05 pm</td><td style="width: 512.888px;"><strong>Q&amp;A and Open Floor Discussion</strong></td></tr></table>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:10:"G20,T20,AI";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:15:"Bali, Indonesia";s:5:"major";s:27:"Ms Abigail Gracia Balthazar";s:16:"article_keywords";s:3:"G20";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-09-04";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2022-09-04";s:8:"keywords";s:20609:"G20 and AI: Connecting the dotted lines between technology and humanity G20 and AI: Connecting the dotted lines between technology and humanity The digital society must be built on trust among all stakeholders including governments, civil society, international organizations, academics and businesses through sharing common values and principles including equality, justice, transparency and accountability taking into account the global economy and interoperability. G20 encompasses world&rsquo;s most powerful political and economic powers and an ideal platform to deliberate, discuss, and debate key issues of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and the newly emerging technologies. Clearer and transparent concepts on AI systems would form the foundation for its development and implementation by addressing some of the growing concerns related to its safety and security as well as governance and ethics. The proposed international conference on &ldquo;G20 and AI: Connecting the dotted lines between technology and humanity&rdquo;, to be held on side lines of meeting of the G20 digital ministers from September 1-2, 2022 in Bali, Indonesia would be an excellent opportunity to support policies and initiatives undertaken by the G20 leadership under the Indonesian Presidency under Track 1.5 and Track 2.0 diplomacy.
Session I: G20 and AI - Exploring a new horizon of opportunities and possibilities
To build a better future, the G20 needs to raise the level of ambition and digital co-operation. This is particularly important for new technologies such as Artificial Intelligence (AI), quantum computing, blockchain, Internet of Things, among others. The responsible development and use of AI can be a driving force to help advance SDGs and to realize a sustainable and inclusive society while mitigating risks to wider societal values of equity, access, and fairness. Benefits brought by responsible use of AI can improve the work environment and quality of life, creating potential for realizing a human-centred future society with opportunities for everyone. The session will focus on adopting a multi-stakeholder approach towards AI adoption by supporting standards that help transition to an increasingly digital society. The successful incorporation of AI requires public administrations to redefine strategies based on emerging technologies and to develop a functional governance structure. It will exchange views on how G20 can help achieve an inclusive, sustainable, and innovative society through digitalization. The importance of international cooperation for harnessing full potential of emerging technologies like AI will also be discussed which includes enhanced research and development as well as policy formulation for the global citizenry.
Session II: AI and digital ecosystem - A transformative experience in the making
Digitalization is expected to continue creating benefits for economies and societies as a whole. The benefits brought by increased productivity through the use of emerging technologies such as artificial intelligence (AI), fifth-generation mobile telecommunication technologies (5G), the Internet of Things (IoT), Distributed Ledger Technologies (e.g. block chain) will empower the G20 nations by creating new opportunities and generating new services and employment, all of which can lead to greater well-being and further inclusiveness for both society and individuals. G20 is committed to promoting policies to share benefits from digitalization of economies and societies. This session would facilitate discussion on how the G20 can design and implement policies to maximize benefits and minimize risks from development of the digital ecosystem and how to overcome the resulting challenges. The key focus would be how to support development of a digital ecosystem that supports transition to novel way of thinking and working unleashed by AI. As human civilization leaps into a new frontier of technology enabled lifestyle and living, the challenge is to make the transformative experience rewarding and accessible to all.
Session III: AI governance and ethics - The role of the G20 community
Issues related to privacy and security in the digital economy are central concerns to the domain of public policy as citizens embrace introduction of big data collection related to artificial intelligence (AI). Citizens seek assurance that AI and automation will be introduced in a manner that respects human integrity and functions within a framework of accountability. While delivering productivity, key issues like safety and privacy need to be adequately addressed. The G20 is committed to promoting a free, open and secure internet that encourages the digital industry to work with stakeholders in fighting misuse of the internet and social media and also safeguarding against violent extremism and addressing content that incites terrorist acts. Against this background, this session would emphasize on recommendations and principles that G20 leaders could formulate in developing an accountability framework. The session would facilitate discussion on exploring potentials of digitalization and addressing concerns that it brings along, including adoption of international standardization on AI led by the G20.
Session IV: AI and humans - Maximizing benefits and minimizing risks
For G20, AI acts as a governable and interoperable technology that aims to eradicate or minimize inequalities. Like other emerging technologies, AI presents societal challenges, including transitions in the labour market and addressing issues related to privacy, security, ethics, and digital divides. In pursuing human-centred AI, G20 recognizes the importance of promoting protection of privacy and personal data. It also recognizes the need to promote AI capacity building and skills development. This session will explore how some of the international bodies that could serve as focal points to ensure a common framework to regulate the digital environment. As the human-machine interface enters a new phase, this session will look into how to navigate the delicate balance where human ingenuity is complemented and not upstaged by the machine driven efficiency
Event Schedule

Time: 9:00 AM - 05:05 PM (Bali Time/GMT+8)
Venue:&nbsp;Hilton Hotel, Nusa Dua, Bali

eludehcS tnevE
ycneiciffe nevird enihcam eht yb degatspu ton dna detnemelpmoc si ytiunegni namuh erehw ecnalab etaciled eht etagivan ot woh otni kool lliw noisses siht ,esahp wen a sretne ecafretni enihcam-namuh eht sA .tnemnorivne latigid eht etaluger ot krowemarf nommoc a erusne ot stniop lacof sa evres dluoc taht seidob lanoitanretni eht fo emos woh erolpxe lliw noisses sihT .tnempoleved slliks dna gnidliub yticapac IA etomorp ot deen eht sezingocer osla tI .atad lanosrep dna ycavirp fo noitcetorp gnitomorp fo ecnatropmi eht sezingocer 02G ,IA dertnec-namuh gniusrup nI .sedivid latigid dna ,scihte ,ytiruces ,ycavirp ot detaler seussi gnisserdda dna tekram ruobal eht ni snoitisnart gnidulcni ,segnellahc lateicos stneserp IA ,seigolonhcet gnigreme rehto ekiL .seitilauqeni eziminim ro etacidare ot smia taht ygolonhcet elbareporetni dna elbanrevog a sa stca IA ,02G roF
sksir gniziminim dna stifeneb gnizimixaM - snamuh dna IA :VI noisseS
.02G eht yb del IA no noitazidradnats lanoitanretni fo noitpoda gnidulcni ,gnola sgnirb ti taht snrecnoc gnisserdda dna noitazilatigid fo slaitnetop gnirolpxe no noissucsid etatilicaf dluow noisses ehT .krowemarf ytilibatnuocca na gnipoleved ni etalumrof dluoc sredael 02G taht selpicnirp dna snoitadnemmocer no ezisahpme dluow noisses siht ,dnuorgkcab siht tsniagA .stca tsirorret seticni taht tnetnoc gnisserdda dna msimertxe tneloiv tsniaga gnidraugefas osla dna aidem laicos dna tenretni eht fo esusim gnithgif ni sredlohekats htiw krow ot yrtsudni latigid eht segaruocne taht tenretni eruces dna nepo ,eerf a gnitomorp ot dettimmoc si 02G ehT .desserdda yletauqeda eb ot deen ycavirp dna ytefas ekil seussi yek ,ytivitcudorp gnireviled elihW .ytilibatnuocca fo krowemarf a nihtiw snoitcnuf dna ytirgetni namuh stcepser taht rennam a ni decudortni eb lliw noitamotua dna IA taht ecnarussa kees snezitiC .)IA( ecnegilletni laicifitra ot detaler noitcelloc atad gib fo noitcudortni ecarbme snezitic sa ycilop cilbup fo niamod eht ot snrecnoc lartnec era ymonoce latigid eht ni ytiruces dna ycavirp ot detaler seussI
ytinummoc 02G eht fo elor ehT - scihte dna ecnanrevog IA :III noisseS
.lla ot elbissecca dna gnidrawer ecneirepxe evitamrofsnart eht ekam ot si egnellahc eht ,gnivil dna elytsefil delbane ygolonhcet fo reitnorf wen a otni spael noitazilivic namuh sA .IA yb dehsaelnu gnikrow dna gnikniht fo yaw levon ot noitisnart stroppus taht metsysoce latigid a fo tnempoleved troppus ot woh eb dluow sucof yek ehT .segnellahc gnitluser eht emocrevo ot woh dna metsysoce latigid eht fo tnempoleved morf sksir eziminim dna stifeneb ezimixam ot seicilop tnemelpmi dna ngised nac 02G eht woh no noissucsid etatilicaf dluow noisses sihT .seiteicos dna seimonoce fo noitazilatigid morf stifeneb erahs ot seicilop gnitomorp ot dettimmoc si 02G .slaudividni dna yteicos htob rof ssenevisulcni rehtruf dna gnieb-llew retaerg ot dael nac hcihw fo lla ,tnemyolpme dna secivres wen gnitareneg dna seitinutroppo wen gnitaerc yb snoitan 02G eht rewopme lliw )niahc kcolb .g.e( seigolonhceT regdeL detubirtsiD ,)ToI( sgnihT fo tenretnI eht ,)G5( seigolonhcet noitacinummocelet elibom noitareneg-htfif ,)IA( ecnegilletni laicifitra sa hcus seigolonhcet gnigreme fo esu eht hguorht ytivitcudorp desaercni yb thguorb stifeneb ehT .elohw a sa seiteicos dna seimonoce rof stifeneb gnitaerc eunitnoc ot detcepxe si noitazilatigiD
gnikam eht ni ecneirepxe evitamrofsnart A - metsysoce latigid dna IA :II noisseS
.yrnezitic labolg eht rof noitalumrof ycilop sa llew sa tnempoleved dna hcraeser decnahne sedulcni hcihw dessucsid eb osla lliw IA ekil seigolonhcet gnigreme fo laitnetop lluf gnissenrah rof noitarepooc lanoitanretni fo ecnatropmi ehT .noitazilatigid hguorht yteicos evitavonni dna ,elbaniatsus ,evisulcni na eveihca pleh nac 02G woh no sweiv egnahcxe lliw tI .erutcurts ecnanrevog lanoitcnuf a poleved ot dna seigolonhcet gnigreme no desab seigetarts enifeder ot snoitartsinimda cilbup seriuqer IA fo noitaroprocni lufsseccus ehT .yteicos latigid ylgnisaercni na ot noitisnart pleh taht sdradnats gnitroppus yb noitpoda IA sdrawot hcaorppa redlohekats-itlum a gnitpoda no sucof lliw noisses ehT .enoyreve rof seitinutroppo htiw yteicos erutuf dertnec-namuh a gnizilaer rof laitnetop gnitaerc ,efil fo ytilauq dna tnemnorivne krow eht evorpmi nac IA fo esu elbisnopser yb thguorb stifeneB .ssenriaf dna ,ssecca ,ytiuqe fo seulav lateicos rediw ot sksir gnitagitim elihw yteicos evisulcni dna elbaniatsus a ezilaer ot dna sGDS ecnavda pleh ot ecrof gnivird a eb nac IA fo esu dna tnempoleved elbisnopser ehT .srehto gnoma ,sgnihT fo tenretnI ,niahckcolb ,gnitupmoc mutnauq ,)IA( ecnegilletnI laicifitrA sa hcus seigolonhcet wen rof tnatropmi ylralucitrap si sihT .noitarepo-oc latigid dna noitibma fo level eht esiar ot sdeen 02G eht ,erutuf retteb a dliub oT
seitilibissop dna seitinutroppo fo noziroh wen a gnirolpxE - IA dna 02G :I noisseS
.ycamolpid 0.2 kcarT dna 5.1 kcarT rednu ycnediserP naisenodnI eht rednu pihsredael 02G eht yb nekatrednu sevitaitini dna seicilop troppus ot ytinutroppo tnellecxe na eb dluow aisenodnI ,ilaB ni 2202 ,2-1 rebmetpeS morf sretsinim latigid 02G eht fo gniteem fo senil edis no dleh eb ot ,;ouqdr&ytinamuh dna ygolonhcet neewteb senil dettod eht gnitcennoC :IA dna 02G;ouqdl& no ecnerefnoc lanoitanretni desoporp ehT .scihte dna ecnanrevog sa llew sa ytiruces dna ytefas sti ot detaler snrecnoc gniworg eht fo emos gnisserdda yb noitatnemelpmi dna tnempoleved sti rof noitadnuof eht mrof dluow smetsys IA no stpecnoc tnerapsnart dna reraelC .seigolonhcet gnigreme ylwen eht dna )IA( ecnegilletnI laicifitrA fo seussi yek etabed dna ,ssucsid ,etarebiled ot mroftalp laedi na dna srewop cimonoce dna lacitilop lufrewop tsom s;ouqsr&dlrow sessapmocne 02G .ytilibareporetni dna ymonoce labolg eht tnuocca otni gnikat ytilibatnuocca dna ycnerapsnart ,ecitsuj ,ytilauqe gnidulcni selpicnirp dna seulav nommoc gnirahs hguorht sessenisub dna scimedaca ,snoitazinagro lanoitanretni ,yteicos livic ,stnemnrevog gnidulcni sredlohekats lla gnoma tsurt no tliub eb tsum yteicos latigid ehT ytinamuh dna ygolonhcet neewteb senil dettod eht gnitcennoC :IA dna 02G ytinamuh dna ygolonhcet neewteb senil dettod eht gnitcennoC :IA dna 02G";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-08-29 12:41:20";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-08-29 14:46:00";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"19";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:26:"abigail.balthazar@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:9;O:8:"stdClass":48:{s:19:"article_category_id";s:5:"13492";s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6971";s:11:"category_id";s:3:"243";s:9:"short_des";N;s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:73:"circular-economy-for-a-stronger-recovery-a-just-transition-agenda-for-g20";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:75:"Circular Economy for a Stronger Recovery:  A Just Transition Agenda for G20";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-09-03";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"9";s:7:"content";s:6500:"<p><img src="/uploads/media/2022_September_Circular-Economy-for-a-Stronger-Recovery_Photo-Flyer_1.jpg" alt="" width="812" height="406" /></p><p>Economic disruptions during the pandemic have brought to light the urgency of the transition to more sustainable consumption and production. The circular economy comes from the idea that resources, when adequately treated and regenerated, can become a source of sustainable economic growth, aided by eco-innovations while preserving the natural capital. Compared to a linear economy, a circular economy encourages greater collaboration between economic actors and can become a powerful force for climate change mitigation, biodiversity conservation, and reducing local pollution impacts. This is critical to identify opportunities to shift swiftly toward a more just, equal, and circular society, instead of going back to linear, wasteful, and inherently fragile supply chains.</p><p>Innovative and context-sensitive technology, the transfer, uptake, and scaling of the use of technology together with adequate public financial mechanisms and mobilizing private capital are fundamental to ensuring a transformative, inclusive, and sustainable recovery that unleashes the transition to circular economies. The technological solutions for and reorienting financial institutions to embed circularity can change the way we produce, consume, and address the issues ranging from carbon emissions, resource scarcity, and the use of hazardous chemicals and fossil fuels, while increasing resilience. Also, international cooperation can facilitate the successful transfer and implementation of established technology keeping materials in the loop.</p><p>This high-level event brings together emerging ideas, practices, and policy pathways to accelerate the shift away from a take-make-waste model of resource use and pollution to a circular green recovery, and the practical steps G20 economies could consider embedding circularity into their economies. The insights from the keynotes and panel discussion can guide policymakers to address the opportunities and barriers, providing recommendations for a common framework to accelerate just transition, with examples of measures that have proven effective around the world.</p><p>Organized by the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) and in cooperation with Deutsche Gesellschaft f&uuml;r Internationale Zusammenarbeit (GIZ)</p><h2><span style="font-size: 17px;">Event Details</span></h2><ul><li>Date: Saturday, 3 September 2022</li><li>Time: 3:00PM - 6:00PM (Bali Time/GMT+8)</li><li>Venue: Hilton Hotel Bali, in Graha Paruman 4 5 room meeting</li></ul><h2><span style="font-size: 17px;">Agenda</span></h2><table style="height: 291px; width: 605.706px;"><tr><td style="width: 138px;">2:30 PM - 3:00 PM</td><td style="width: 452.706px;"><p><strong>Registration</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 138px;">3:00 PM - 3:05 PM</td><td style="width: 452.706px;"><p><strong>Welcoming Remarks</strong></p><ul><li><span style="font-size: 14px;"><strong>Koji Hachiyama</strong>,&nbsp;Chief Operating Officer, Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA)</span></li></ul></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 138px;">3:05 PM - 3:10 PM</td><td style="width: 452.706px;"><p><strong>Opening Remarks</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Moekti Handajani Soejachmoen</strong>, Lead Co-Chair of the T20-Task Force 3: Governing Climate Target, Energy Transition and environmental Protection</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 138px;">3:10 PM - 3:15 PM</td><td style="width: 452.706px;"><p><strong>Special Address</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Anies Baswedan</strong>, Governor of Jakarta <strong>(TBC)</strong></li></ul></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 138px;">3:15 PM - 3:45 PM</td><td style="width: 452.706px;"><p><strong>Key Note Speeches</strong></p><p>Green and Circular Ideas for a Stronger Economic Recovery</p><ul><li><strong>Izabella Teixeira</strong>, Co-Chair International Resource Panel, Former Minister of Environment, Brazil)</li></ul><p>Bending the Supply Chains towards Net Zero Targets</p><ul><li><strong>Venkatachalam Anbumozhi</strong>, Director of Research Strategy and Innovation, Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA)</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 138px;">3:45 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td style="width: 452.706px;"><p><strong>Panel Session:</strong> Innovative Technologies and Financial Innovations or a Circular Low-Carbon Economy: Opportunities for G20</p><p>Moderator:</p><p><strong>Nicholas Buchoud</strong>, Fellow, Global Solutions Initiative, Berlin, Germany</p><p>Panelists:</p><ul><li><strong>Konstantinos Karampourniotis</strong>, Circular Economy Solutions Advocate, European Union</li><li><strong>Noura Monsurri</strong>, Senior Fellow, King Abdullah Petroleum Studies and Research Center</li><li><strong>Anouj Mehta</strong>, Director &nbsp;Southeast Asia Department, Asian Development Bank</li><li><strong>Caroline Chal</strong>, Director of institutional relations, Syctom, Paris, France&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</li><li><strong>Tadahiro KANEKO</strong>,&nbsp; Head of Sustainability, Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation</li><li><strong>Kari Herlevi</strong>, Project Director, Circular Economy, Finnish Innovation Fund, Sitra.</li></ul><p><em>Followed by&nbsp;<strong>Q &amp; A session</strong></em></p></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 138px;">5:30 PM - 5:50 PM</td><td style="width: 452.706px;"><p><strong>Tripartite G20 Insights:</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Sigit Relianto</strong>, Co-Chair of Environmental Deputies Meeting G20 Indonesia</li><li><strong>Antonio Villafranca</strong>, Director of Research, Italian Institute for International Political Studies (ISPI)</li><li><strong>Sachin Chaturvedi</strong>, Director General, Research and Information System for Developing Countries (RIS)</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 138px;">&nbsp;5:50 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td style="width: 452.706px;"><p><strong>Closing Remarks:</strong></p><p><strong>Khule Holger</strong>, Advisor. Strategic Knowledge Partnerships, GIZ</p></td></tr></table><p><a class="bluebtn" href="https://bit.ly/CESR-G20" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">ONLINE REGISTRATION</a></p><p><a class="bluebtn" href="https://bit.ly/CESR-G20-IP" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">IN-PERSON REGISTRATION (limited seats)</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:15:"Bali, Indonesia";s:5:"major";s:16:"Ms Dian Lutfiana";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-09-03";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2022-09-03";s:8:"keywords";s:10035:"Circular Economy for a Stronger Recovery:  A Just Transition Agenda for G20 Circular Economy for a Stronger Recovery:  A Just Transition Agenda for G20 Economic disruptions during the pandemic have brought to light the urgency of the transition to more sustainable consumption and production. The circular economy comes from the idea that resources, when adequately treated and regenerated, can become a source of sustainable economic growth, aided by eco-innovations while preserving the natural capital. Compared to a linear economy, a circular economy encourages greater collaboration between economic actors and can become a powerful force for climate change mitigation, biodiversity conservation, and reducing local pollution impacts. This is critical to identify opportunities to shift swiftly toward a more just, equal, and circular society, instead of going back to linear, wasteful, and inherently fragile supply chains.
Innovative and context-sensitive technology, the transfer, uptake, and scaling of the use of technology together with adequate public financial mechanisms and mobilizing private capital are fundamental to ensuring a transformative, inclusive, and sustainable recovery that unleashes the transition to circular economies. The technological solutions for and reorienting financial institutions to embed circularity can change the way we produce, consume, and address the issues ranging from carbon emissions, resource scarcity, and the use of hazardous chemicals and fossil fuels, while increasing resilience. Also, international cooperation can facilitate the successful transfer and implementation of established technology keeping materials in the loop.
This high-level event brings together emerging ideas, practices, and policy pathways to accelerate the shift away from a take-make-waste model of resource use and pollution to a circular green recovery, and the practical steps G20 economies could consider embedding circularity into their economies. The insights from the keynotes and panel discussion can guide policymakers to address the opportunities and barriers, providing recommendations for a common framework to accelerate just transition, with examples of measures that have proven effective around the world.
Organized by the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) and in cooperation with Deutsche Gesellschaft f&uuml;r Internationale Zusammenarbeit (GIZ)
Event Details

Date: Saturday, 3 September 2022
Time: 3:00PM - 6:00PM (Bali Time/GMT+8)
Venue: Hilton Hotel Bali, in Graha Paruman 4 5 room meeting

Agenda



2:30 PM - 3:00 PM

Registration



3:00 PM - 3:05 PM

Welcoming Remarks

Koji Hachiyama,&nbsp;Chief Operating Officer, Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA)




3:05 PM - 3:10 PM

Opening Remarks

Moekti Handajani Soejachmoen, Lead Co-Chair of the T20-Task Force 3: Governing Climate Target, Energy Transition and environmental Protection




3:10 PM - 3:15 PM

Special Address

Anies Baswedan, Governor of Jakarta (TBC)




3:15 PM - 3:45 PM

Key Note Speeches
Green and Circular Ideas for a Stronger Economic Recovery

Izabella Teixeira, Co-Chair International Resource Panel, Former Minister of Environment, Brazil)

Bending the Supply Chains towards Net Zero Targets

Venkatachalam Anbumozhi, Director of Research Strategy and Innovation, Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA)




3:45 PM - 5:30 PM

Panel Session: Innovative Technologies and Financial Innovations or a Circular Low-Carbon Economy: Opportunities for G20
Moderator:
Nicholas Buchoud, Fellow, Global Solutions Initiative, Berlin, Germany
Panelists:

Konstantinos Karampourniotis, Circular Economy Solutions Advocate, European Union
Noura Monsurri, Senior Fellow, King Abdullah Petroleum Studies and Research Center
Anouj Mehta, Director &nbsp;Southeast Asia Department, Asian Development Bank
Caroline Chal, Director of institutional relations, Syctom, Paris, France&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Tadahiro KANEKO,&nbsp; Head of Sustainability, Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation
Kari Herlevi, Project Director, Circular Economy, Finnish Innovation Fund, Sitra.

Followed by&nbsp;Q &amp; A session



5:30 PM - 5:50 PM

Tripartite G20 Insights:

Sigit Relianto, Co-Chair of Environmental Deputies Meeting G20 Indonesia
Antonio Villafranca, Director of Research, Italian Institute for International Political Studies (ISPI)
Sachin Chaturvedi, Director General, Research and Information System for Developing Countries (RIS)




&nbsp;5:50 PM - 6:00 PM

Closing Remarks:
Khule Holger, Advisor. Strategic Knowledge Partnerships, GIZ




ONLINE REGISTRATION

)ZIG( tiebranemmasuZ elanoitanretnI r;lmuu&f tfahcslleseG ehcstueD htiw noitarepooc ni dna )AIRE( aisA tsaE dna NAESA rof etutitsnI hcraeseR cimonocE eht yb dezinagrO
.dlrow eht dnuora evitceffe nevorp evah taht serusaem fo selpmaxe htiw ,noitisnart tsuj etarelecca ot krowemarf nommoc a rof snoitadnemmocer gnidivorp ,sreirrab dna seitinutroppo eht sserdda ot srekamycilop ediug nac noissucsid lenap dna setonyek eht morf sthgisni ehT .seimonoce rieht otni ytiralucric gniddebme redisnoc dluoc seimonoce 02G spets lacitcarp eht dna ,yrevocer neerg ralucric a ot noitullop dna esu ecruoser fo ledom etsaw-ekam-ekat a morf yawa tfihs eht etarelecca ot syawhtap ycilop dna ,secitcarp ,saedi gnigreme rehtegot sgnirb tneve level-hgih sihT
.pool eht ni slairetam gnipeek ygolonhcet dehsilbatse fo noitatnemelpmi dna refsnart lufsseccus eht etatilicaf nac noitarepooc lanoitanretni ,oslA .ecneiliser gnisaercni elihw ,sleuf lissof dna slacimehc suodrazah fo esu eht dna ,yticracs ecruoser ,snoissime nobrac morf gnignar seussi eht sserdda dna ,emusnoc ,ecudorp ew yaw eht egnahc nac ytiralucric debme ot snoitutitsni laicnanif gnitneiroer dna rof snoitulos lacigolonhcet ehT .seimonoce ralucric ot noitisnart eht sehsaelnu taht yrevocer elbaniatsus dna ,evisulcni ,evitamrofsnart a gnirusne ot latnemadnuf era latipac etavirp gnizilibom dna smsinahcem laicnanif cilbup etauqeda htiw rehtegot ygolonhcet fo esu eht fo gnilacs dna ,ekatpu ,refsnart eht ,ygolonhcet evitisnes-txetnoc dna evitavonnI
.sniahc ylppus eligarf yltnerehni dna ,lufetsaw ,raenil ot kcab gniog fo daetsni ,yteicos ralucric dna ,lauqe ,tsuj erom a drawot yltfiws tfihs ot seitinutroppo yfitnedi ot lacitirc si sihT .stcapmi noitullop lacol gnicuder dna ,noitavresnoc ytisrevidoib ,noitagitim egnahc etamilc rof ecrof lufrewop a emoceb nac dna srotca cimonoce neewteb noitaroballoc retaerg segaruocne ymonoce ralucric a ,ymonoce raenil a ot derapmoC .latipac larutan eht gnivreserp elihw snoitavonni-oce yb dedia ,htworg cimonoce elbaniatsus fo ecruos a emoceb nac ,detareneger dna detaert yletauqeda nehw ,secruoser taht aedi eht morf semoc ymonoce ralucric ehT .noitcudorp dna noitpmusnoc elbaniatsus erom ot noitisnart eht fo ycnegru eht thgil ot thguorb evah cimednap eht gnirud snoitpursid cimonocE 02G rof adnegA noitisnarT tsuJ A  :yrevoceR regnortS a rof ymonocE ralucriC 02G rof adnegA noitisnarT tsuJ A  :yrevoceR regnortS a rof ymonocE ralucriC";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-08-25 11:49:25";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-09-02 12:38:25";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"18";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:22:"dian.lutfiana@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:10;O:8:"stdClass":48:{s:19:"article_category_id";s:5:"13356";s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6940";s:11:"category_id";s:3:"243";s:9:"short_des";N;s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:111:"exploring-short-term-solutions-to-the-global-gas-crisis-g20-energy-transition-working-group-etwg-parallel-event";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:124:"'Exploring Short-term Solutions to the Global Gas Crisis' â€“ G20 Energy Transition Working Group (ETWG) parallel event";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-08-29";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"8";s:7:"content";s:4549:"<p><img src="/uploads/media/2022_Aug_Exploring-Short-Term-Solutions-to-the-Global-Gas-Crisis_2.jpg" alt="" width="847" height="476" /></p><p>The world is going through a complex energy crisis, and natural gas is just a single dimension. Energy trade is now on a global level and is more interrelated and intertwined than ever before. Therefore, the consequences of the energy crisis are being felt across countries and industries in more acute ways.</p><p>First, natural gas markets were already tight before the outbreak of the Russian&ndash;Ukrainian conflict on 24 February 2022 due to underinvestment since 2015, the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) in 2020, the rapid albeit uneven post-COVID-19 recovery, and disrupted supply chains, primarily commodity supply chains. As a result, the supply of energy could not catch up with robust resilient demand recovery. There is an ongoing mismatch of supply and continuous, more responsive, and elastic energy demand.</p><p>Second, the situation was exacerbated afterwards by further elevated energy price levels and volatility.</p><p>The current gas crisis could seriously affect not only the world energy security but also the world energy transition progress.</p><p>A workshop is held with the aim of finding short-term solutions to stabilise the global gas market, so that the world can continue to recover together and strongly, amidst the geopolitical crisis.</p><p>On behalf of the Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources of the Republic of Indonesia, as the host of the G20 Presidency, ERIA is pleased to invite you to participate virtually in the upcoming Hybrid Workshop as a G20 ETWG III Parallel Event entitled &#039;Exploring Short-term Solutions to the Global Gas Crisis&#039; to be organised back-to-back to the 3rd Energy Transition Working Group Meeting and the G20 Energy Transition Ministerial Meeting.</p><h2>Event Details</h2><p>Date: Monday, 29 August 2022 Time: 9 AM &ndash; 12.30 PM (Bali Time; UTC+8)</p><h2>Agenda*</h2><p><strong>Opening Remarks</strong></p><ul><li>Mr Yudo Dwinanda Priaadi, Chair of the Energy Transition Working Group G20 ETWG</li></ul><p><strong>Keynote Speeches</strong></p><ul><li>Prof Tutuka Ariadji, Director General of Oil and Gas, Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources, Republic of Indonesia</li><li>HE Eng. Mohamed Hamel, Secretary General of the Gas Exporting Countries Forum (GECF)</li><li>Prof Hidetoshi Nishimura, President of the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA)</li></ul><p><strong>Main presentation: Proposed Short-term Solutions for the Current Gas Crisis</strong></p><p>Main speaker:</p><ul><li>Mr Hiroshi Hashimoto, Senior Analyst, Head of Gas Group, Fossil Energies &amp; International Cooperation Unit, The Institute of Energy Economics Japan</li></ul><p><strong>Panel Discussion I: Importing and Exporting Countries&rsquo; Perspectives and Reactions on the Proposed Solutions</strong></p><p>Moderator: Mr Nanang Untung, Expert Staff for Minister of Energy &amp; Mineral Resources of the Republic of Indonesia</p><p>Panellists:</p><ul><li>Mr Jonathan Goh, Director of External Relations, Energy Market Authority, Singapore</li><li><span lang="nl-BE">Mr Takahiro Hirai,&nbsp;</span><span lang="en-GB">Deputy Director Oil and Gas Division, Agency for Natural Resources and Energy Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry, Japan</span></li><li>Ms <span lang="en-GB">Lamiaa Abo Shahba PhD,&nbsp;General Manager of Gas Market Activities, Operations and Networks, Egyptian Natural Gas Holding Company &ndash; EGAS</span></li><li>Mr Martin Squire, Head of International Energy Area, Ministry of Energy, Australia</li><li>Dr Philip Mshelbila, Managing Director, Nigeria LNG Ltd. (NLNG)</li></ul><p><strong>Panel Discussion II: Market Effects of Possible Short-term Solutions</strong></p><p>Moderator: Prof. Jun Arima, Senior Policy Fellow for Energy and Environment, ERIA</p><p>Panellists:</p><ul><li>Mr Christof van Agt, Director, Energy Dialogue, International Energy Forum (IEF)</li><li>Dr Aydar Shakirov, Head of the Gas Market Analysis Department, Gas Exporting Countries Forum (GECF)</li><li>Mr Edito Barcelona, Senior Research Fellow, Asia Pacific Energy Research Centre (APERC)</li><li>Mr Chong Zhi Xin, Director, South and Southeast Asia Gas, S&amp;P Global</li></ul><p><strong>Conclusions and the Way Forward</strong></p><ul><li>Mr Koji Hachiyama, COO of ERIA</li></ul><p><strong><a class="bluebtn" href="https://bit.ly/ESSGGCSeminar" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Register Now!</a></strong></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:15:"Bali, Indonesia";s:5:"major";s:20:"Ms Tri Muliani Manik";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-08-29";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:8439:"'Exploring Short-term Solutions to the Global Gas Crisis' â€“ G20 Energy Transition Working Group (ETWG) parallel event 'Exploring Short-term Solutions to the Global Gas Crisis' â€“ G20 Energy Transition Working Group (ETWG) parallel event The world is going through a complex energy crisis, and natural gas is just a single dimension. Energy trade is now on a global level and is more interrelated and intertwined than ever before. Therefore, the consequences of the energy crisis are being felt across countries and industries in more acute ways.
First, natural gas markets were already tight before the outbreak of the Russian&ndash;Ukrainian conflict on 24 February 2022 due to underinvestment since 2015, the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) in 2020, the rapid albeit uneven post-COVID-19 recovery, and disrupted supply chains, primarily commodity supply chains. As a result, the supply of energy could not catch up with robust resilient demand recovery. There is an ongoing mismatch of supply and continuous, more responsive, and elastic energy demand.
Second, the situation was exacerbated afterwards by further elevated energy price levels and volatility.
The current gas crisis could seriously affect not only the world energy security but also the world energy transition progress.
A workshop is held with the aim of finding short-term solutions to stabilise the global gas market, so that the world can continue to recover together and strongly, amidst the geopolitical crisis.
On behalf of the Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources of the Republic of Indonesia, as the host of the G20 Presidency, ERIA is pleased to invite you to participate virtually in the upcoming Hybrid Workshop as a G20 ETWG III Parallel Event entitled 'Exploring Short-term Solutions to the Global Gas Crisis' to be organised back-to-back to the 3rd Energy Transition Working Group Meeting and the G20 Energy Transition Ministerial Meeting.
Event Details
Date: Monday, 29 August 2022 Time: 9 AM &ndash; 12.30 PM (Bali Time; UTC+8)
Agenda*
Opening Remarks

Mr Yudo Dwinanda Priaadi, Chair of the Energy Transition Working Group G20 ETWG

Keynote Speeches

Prof Tutuka Ariadji, Director General of Oil and Gas, Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources, Republic of Indonesia
HE Eng. Mohamed Hamel, Secretary General of the Gas Exporting Countries Forum (GECF)
Prof Hidetoshi Nishimura, President of the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA)

Main presentation: Proposed Short-term Solutions for the Current Gas Crisis
Main speaker:

Mr Hiroshi Hashimoto, Senior Analyst, Head of Gas Group, Fossil Energies &amp; International Cooperation Unit, The Institute of Energy Economics Japan

Panel Discussion I: Importing and Exporting Countries&rsquo; Perspectives and Reactions on the Proposed Solutions
Moderator: Mr Nanang Untung, Expert Staff for Minister of Energy &amp; Mineral Resources of the Republic of Indonesia
Panellists:

Mr Jonathan Goh, Director of External Relations, Energy Market Authority, Singapore
Mr Takahiro Hirai,&nbsp;Deputy Director Oil and Gas Division, Agency for Natural Resources and Energy Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry, Japan
Ms Lamiaa Abo Shahba PhD,&nbsp;General Manager of Gas Market Activities, Operations and Networks, Egyptian Natural Gas Holding Company &ndash; EGAS
Mr Martin Squire, Head of International Energy Area, Ministry of Energy, Australia
Dr Philip Mshelbila, Managing Director, Nigeria LNG Ltd. (NLNG)

Panel Discussion II: Market Effects of Possible Short-term Solutions
Moderator: Prof. Jun Arima, Senior Policy Fellow for Energy and Environment, ERIA
Panellists:

Mr Christof van Agt, Director, Energy Dialogue, International Energy Forum (IEF)
Dr Aydar Shakirov, Head of the Gas Market Analysis Department, Gas Exporting Countries Forum (GECF)
Mr Edito Barcelona, Senior Research Fellow, Asia Pacific Energy Research Centre (APERC)
Mr Chong Zhi Xin, Director, South and Southeast Asia Gas, S&amp;P Global

Conclusions and the Way Forward

Mr Koji Hachiyama, COO of ERIA

)8+CTU ;emiT ilaB( MP 03.21 ;hsadn& MA 9 :emiT 2202 tsuguA 92 ,yadnoM :etaD
sliateD tnevE
.gniteeM lairetsiniM noitisnarT ygrenE 02G eht dna gniteeM puorG gnikroW noitisnarT ygrenE dr3 eht ot kcab-ot-kcab desinagro eb ot 'sisirC saG labolG eht ot snoituloS mret-trohS gnirolpxE' deltitne tnevE lellaraP III GWTE 02G a sa pohskroW dirbyH gnimocpu eht ni yllautriv etapicitrap ot uoy etivni ot desaelp si AIRE ,ycnediserP 02G eht fo tsoh eht sa ,aisenodnI fo cilbupeR eht fo secruoseR lareniM dna ygrenE fo yrtsiniM eht fo flaheb nO
.sisirc lacitilopoeg eht tsdima ,ylgnorts dna rehtegot revocer ot eunitnoc nac dlrow eht taht os ,tekram sag labolg eht esilibats ot snoitulos mret-trohs gnidnif fo mia eht htiw dleh si pohskrow A
.ssergorp noitisnart ygrene dlrow eht osla tub ytiruces ygrene dlrow eht ylno ton tceffa ylsuoires dluoc sisirc sag tnerruc ehT
.ytilitalov dna slevel ecirp ygrene detavele rehtruf yb sdrawretfa detabrecaxe saw noitautis eht ,dnoceS
.dnamed ygrene citsale dna ,evisnopser erom ,suounitnoc dna ylppus fo hctamsim gniogno na si erehT .yrevocer dnamed tneiliser tsubor htiw pu hctac ton dluoc ygrene fo ylppus eht ,tluser a sA .sniahc ylppus ytidommoc yliramirp ,sniahc ylppus detpursid dna ,yrevocer 91-DIVOC-tsop nevenu tiebla dipar eht ,0202 ni )91-DIVOC( esaesid surivanoroc eht ,5102 ecnis tnemtsevnirednu ot eud 2202 yraurbeF 42 no tcilfnoc nainiarkU;hsadn&naissuR eht fo kaerbtuo eht erofeb thgit ydaerla erew stekram sag larutan ,tsriF
.syaw etuca erom ni seirtsudni dna seirtnuoc ssorca tlef gnieb era sisirc ygrene eht fo secneuqesnoc eht ,eroferehT .erofeb reve naht deniwtretni dna detalerretni erom si dna level labolg a no won si edart ygrenE .noisnemid elgnis a tsuj si sag larutan dna ,sisirc ygrene xelpmoc a hguorht gniog si dlrow ehT tneve lellarap )GWTE( puorG gnikroW noitisnarT ygrenE 02G “€â 'sisirC saG labolG eht ot snoituloS mret-trohS gnirolpxE' tneve lellarap )GWTE( puorG gnikroW noitisnarT ygrenE 02G “€â 'sisirC saG labolG eht ot snoituloS mret-trohS gnirolpxE'";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-08-02 14:56:50";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-08-24 15:42:47";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"18";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:18:"tri.manik@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:11;O:8:"stdClass":48:{s:19:"article_category_id";s:5:"13205";s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6862";s:11:"category_id";s:3:"243";s:9:"short_des";N;s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:118:"the-high-level-forum-on-trade-investment-and-industry-hlf-on-tii-g20-trade-investment-and-industry-working-group-tiiwg";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:127:"The High-Level Forum on Trade, Investment, and Industry (HLF on TII): G20 Trade, Investment, and Industry Working Group (TIIWG)";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-07-26";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"7";s:7:"content";s:7782:"<p><img src="/uploads/media/2022_July_G20-High-Level_800x450_2.jpg" alt="" width="480" height="679" /></p><p>The High-Level Forum on Trade, Investment, and Industry (The HLF on TII) is a side event that will support the discussion on the priority issues of the G20 Trade, Investment, and Industry Working Group (TIIWG) Indonesia. Under the G20 Indonesia Presidency, the G20 Members hold the privilege to shape global trade policies for sustainable and inclusive recovery and growth, representing interests within and beyond its member countries. As reflected in Indonesia presidency theme of &#039;Recover Together, Recover Stronger&#039;, we must ensure that the achievement of Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) is the forefront agenda for G20 members.</p><p>In the two years after the pandemic, the global economy has continued to recover, but many factors are impacting the pace of the recovery. This includes the rising food and energy prices, the spread of COVID-19 variants, supply chain disruptions, and growing geopolitical tensions. Moreover, the COVID-19 pandemic has wiped-out years of progress in achieving the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). While global recovery continues, it remains uneven and insufficient to reverse the economic and social consequences of the pandemic, especially for people living in vulnerable situations.</p><p>As the foundation of collective economic recovery, this event will take the opportunity to cooperate and discuss in a fruitful way with all G20 Members to align the Trade, Investment, and Industry agenda with the achievement of Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).</p><p>The event will gather prominent people from the government and business sector including leading international organizations that will promote constructive discussion on better strategies to promote economic recovery by aligning trade, investment, and industry policies. The outcome of the discussion will strengthen the achievement of G20 TIIWG Indonesia deliverables this year.</p><p>Aside from discussing future economic challenges, the HLF on TII will also discuss enhancing the role of the WTO and Multilateral Trading System (MTS) in achieving Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Additionally, it will discuss on how sustainable investment supports the resilience of the global economic recovery as well as how Industry 4.0 can lead to more inclusive and sustainable industrialization. The forum will also highlight the importance of digital transformation and sustainable development.&nbsp;</p><h2>Event Details</h2><ul><li>Date &amp; Time : Tuesday, 26 July&nbsp; 2022, 19:00 - 20:50 PM and Wednesday, 27 July 2022, 9:00 AM - 13:15 PM (Jakarta time, UTC+7)</li></ul><h2>YouTube Livestream</h2><p><strong>Day 1</strong></p><p><iframe src="//www.youtube.com/embed/7GP_ySMoBoY" width="560" height="314" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe></p><p><strong>Day 2</strong></p><p><iframe src="//www.youtube.com/embed/7xYAQQ3ITaQ" width="560" height="314" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe></p><h2>Agenda</h2><p><strong>DAY 1 : Tuesday, 26 July&nbsp; 2022</strong></p><table><tr><td width="104"><p>19:00 &ndash; 19:10</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Keynote Speeches</strong></p><ul><li>Airlangga Hartarto, Coordinating Minister for Economic Affairs of the Republic of Indonesia</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td width="104"><p>19:10 - 19:20</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Opening Remarks</strong></p><ul><li>Hidetoshi Nishimura, President of Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA)</li></ul></td></tr></table><table><tr><td width="104"><p>19:20 &ndash; 19:35</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Remarks</strong></p><ul><li>Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala, Director General of WTO: &#039;The outcome of WTO&rsquo;s 12th Ministerial Conference&#039; (TBC)</li></ul></td></tr></table><table><tr><td width="104"><p>19:35 &ndash; 19:50</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Ministers Speeches by G20 TII Ministerial Meeting (TIIMM) Co-Chairs</strong></p><ul><li>Zulkifli Hasan, Minister of Trade of Republic of Indonesia</li><li>Bahlil Lahadalia, Minister of Investment of Republic of Indonesia</li><li>Agus Gumiwang Kartasasmita, Minister of Industry of Republic of Indonesia</li></ul></td></tr></table><table><tr><td width="104"><p>19:50 &ndash; 20:50</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Panel Discussion</strong></p><p><strong>Moderator:&nbsp;</strong>Rahma Alia, News Anchor</p><ul><li>Achieving Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) via Stronger, Inclusive and Transparent WTO and Multilateral Trading System (MTS)</li><li>The Role of Sustainable and Innovative Investment on Addressing Global Economic and Environment Challenges</li><li>Ensuring Sustainable and Resilient Industry through Industry 4.0 to Support Economic Recovery</li></ul><p><strong>Panelist:</strong></p><ul><li>Jerry Sambuaga, Vice Minister of Trade of Republic of Indonesia</li><li>Piyush Goyal, Minister of Commerce and Industry of India (TBC)</li><li>Mary Ng, Minister of Small Business, Export Promotion, and International Trade of Canada&nbsp;</li><li>Ebrahim Patel, Minister of Trade, Industry and Competition of Republic of South Africa</li><li>James Zhan, Director of Division on Investment and Enterprise of UNCTAD</li><li>Jaime Moll de Alba, Director of the Department of Programme and Partnership Coordination of UNIDO</li></ul></td></tr></table><p><strong>DAY 2 : Wednesday, 27 July 2022</strong></p><table><tr><td width="104"><p>09:00 &ndash; 10:00</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Session I</strong></p><p>Subtheme: Economic Recovery: New Normal</p><p><strong>Chair:</strong>&nbsp;M. Chatib Basri, Minister of Finance of Indonesia (2013-2014)</p><p><strong>Panelist:</strong></p><ul><li>Vera Songwe, Executive Secretary of the United Nations Economic Commission for Africa (UNECA)</li><li>Maurice Obstfeld, Professor of Economics, University of California, Berkeley</li><li>Jayati Ghosh, Professor, University of Massachusetts Amherst, USA</li></ul><p>Q&amp;A session</p></td></tr><tr><td width="104"><p>10:00 - 11:00</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Session II</strong></p><p>Subtheme: Digital Transformation: New Technologies</p><p><strong>Chair:</strong>&nbsp;Dani Rodrik, Professor of International Political Economy at Harvard University, and President of the International Economic Association (IEA)</p><p><strong>Panelist:</strong></p><ul><li>Lili Yan Ing, Lead Advisor (Southeast Asia Region), ERIA</li><li>Zia Qureshi, Senior Fellow in the Global Economy and Development Program, Brookings Institute</li><li>Albert Park, Chief Economist, Asian Development Bank (ADB)</li></ul><p>Q&amp;A session</p></td></tr></table><table><tr><td width="104"><p>11:00 &ndash; 12:00</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Lunch Break</strong></p></td></tr></table><table><tr><td width="104"><p>12:00 &ndash; 13:00</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Session III</strong></p><p>Subtheme: Energy Transition: New Financing</p><p><strong>Chair:</strong>&nbsp;Fauziah Zen, Senior Economist, ERIA</p><p><strong>Panelist:</strong></p><ul><li>Justin Yifu Lin, Professor of Economics, Peking University</li><li>Ishac Diwan, Professor of Economics, Paris School of Economic</li><li>Robert Seung, Chairman of Korindo Group</li></ul><p>Q&amp;A session</p></td></tr></table><table><tr><td width="104"><p>13:00 &ndash; 13:15</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Closing Remarks</strong></p><ul><li>Djatmiko Bris Witjaksono, Chair of G20 TIIWG Indonesia and Director General of International Trade Negotiation, Ministry of Trade of the Republic of Indonesia</li></ul></td></tr></table><p><strong><a class="bluebtn" title="Click here to register via Eventbrite" href="https://g20sideevents.id/register" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Register Now!</a></strong></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:23:"Ms Catherin Nur Safitri";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-07-26";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2022-07-27";s:8:"keywords";s:12629:"The High-Level Forum on Trade, Investment, and Industry (HLF on TII): G20 Trade, Investment, and Industry Working Group (TIIWG) The High-Level Forum on Trade, Investment, and Industry (HLF on TII): G20 Trade, Investment, and Industry Working Group (TIIWG) The High-Level Forum on Trade, Investment, and Industry (The HLF on TII) is a side event that will support the discussion on the priority issues of the G20 Trade, Investment, and Industry Working Group (TIIWG) Indonesia. Under the G20 Indonesia Presidency, the G20 Members hold the privilege to shape global trade policies for sustainable and inclusive recovery and growth, representing interests within and beyond its member countries. As reflected in Indonesia presidency theme of 'Recover Together, Recover Stronger', we must ensure that the achievement of Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) is the forefront agenda for G20 members.
In the two years after the pandemic, the global economy has continued to recover, but many factors are impacting the pace of the recovery. This includes the rising food and energy prices, the spread of COVID-19 variants, supply chain disruptions, and growing geopolitical tensions. Moreover, the COVID-19 pandemic has wiped-out years of progress in achieving the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). While global recovery continues, it remains uneven and insufficient to reverse the economic and social consequences of the pandemic, especially for people living in vulnerable situations.
As the foundation of collective economic recovery, this event will take the opportunity to cooperate and discuss in a fruitful way with all G20 Members to align the Trade, Investment, and Industry agenda with the achievement of Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).
The event will gather prominent people from the government and business sector including leading international organizations that will promote constructive discussion on better strategies to promote economic recovery by aligning trade, investment, and industry policies. The outcome of the discussion will strengthen the achievement of G20 TIIWG Indonesia deliverables this year.
Aside from discussing future economic challenges, the HLF on TII will also discuss enhancing the role of the WTO and Multilateral Trading System (MTS) in achieving Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Additionally, it will discuss on how sustainable investment supports the resilience of the global economic recovery as well as how Industry 4.0 can lead to more inclusive and sustainable industrialization. The forum will also highlight the importance of digital transformation and sustainable development.&nbsp;
Event Details

Date &amp; Time : Tuesday, 26 July&nbsp; 2022, 19:00 - 20:50 PM and Wednesday, 27 July 2022, 9:00 AM - 13:15 PM (Jakarta time, UTC+7)

YouTube Livestream
Day 1

Day 2

Agenda
DAY 1 : Tuesday, 26 July&nbsp; 2022




19:00 &ndash; 19:10


Keynote Speeches

Airlangga Hartarto, Coordinating Minister for Economic Affairs of the Republic of Indonesia





19:10 - 19:20


Opening Remarks

19:20 &ndash; 19:35


Remarks

Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala, Director General of WTO: 'The outcome of WTO&rsquo;s 12th Ministerial Conference' (TBC)









19:35 &ndash; 19:50


Ministers Speeches by G20 TII Ministerial Meeting (TIIMM) Co-Chairs

Zulkifli Hasan, Minister of Trade of Republic of Indonesia
Bahlil Lahadalia, Minister of Investment of Republic of Indonesia
Agus Gumiwang Kartasasmita, Minister of Industry of Republic of Indonesia









19:50 &ndash; 20:50


Panel Discussion
Moderator:&nbsp;Rahma Alia, News Anchor

Achieving Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) via Stronger, Inclusive and Transparent WTO and Multilateral Trading System (MTS)
The Role of Sustainable and Innovative Investment on Addressing Global Economic and Environment Challenges
Ensuring Sustainable and Resilient Industry through Industry 4.0 to Support Economic Recovery

Panelist:

Jerry Sambuaga, Vice Minister of Trade of Republic of Indonesia
Piyush Goyal, Minister of Commerce and Industry of India (TBC)

James Zhan, Director of Division on Investment and Enterprise of UNCTAD
Jaime Moll de Alba, Director of the Department of Programme and Partnership Coordination of UNIDO

ehT";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-06-30 10:48:55";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-07-27 08:47:02";s:11:"modified_by";s:1:"4";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:25:"catherin.safitri@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:12;O:8:"stdClass":48:{s:19:"article_category_id";s:5:"13190";s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6855";s:11:"category_id";s:3:"243";s:9:"short_des";N;s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:138:"t20-side-event-webinar-on-emerging-economies-towards-net-zero-emission-challenges-and-opportunities-on-technology-innovation-and-financing";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:141:"T20 side event webinar on 'Emerging Economies towards Net Zero Emission: Challenges and Opportunities on Technology Innovation and Financing'";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-07-20";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"7";s:7:"content";s:9048:"<p data-key="92"><img src="http://www.eria.org/uploads/media/2022-07-20-TF3-workshop-flyer-800x450.jpg" alt="" width="850" height="425" /></p><p data-key="92"><span data-key="93">The 2022 G20 Indonesia Presidency&rsquo;s Energy Transition pillar of &lsquo;Global cleaner energy systems and just transitions&rsquo; aims at achieving a global deal to accelerate the energy transition. G20 Indonesia Presidency has opted, therefore, for its pathway to achieve the carbon neutrality target by accelerating the just process of reducing energy-related greenhouse gas emissions through various forms of decarbonisation. Such decarbonisation means an additional investment is necessary. Nevertheless, the question remains: how to finance the energy transition, especially in the context of reaching carbon neutrality pledges that vary across G20 countries?</span></p><p data-key="94"><span data-key="95">Apart from traditional financial and policy instruments, countries need also to fully employ new and innovative schemes to support clean energy financing and markets. This virtual workshop aims to explore workable financing mechanisms in each technology cluster (including renewable energy resources and their carriers, CCS/CCUS, and Direct Air Capture technologies) that play important roles in the energy transition with an emphasis on the ASEAN countries.</span></p><p data-key="99" data-slate-fragment=""><span data-key="100">This Virtual Workshop is jointly organised by the Institute of Economic and Social Research Faculty of Economics and Business, University of Indonesia (LPEM-FEB UI) and Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA). </span></p><h2>Event Details</h2><ul><li>Date: Wednesday, 20 July 2022</li><li>Time: 2 PM -&nbsp; 4:15 PM (Jakarta time, UTC+7)&nbsp;</li></ul><h2>Agenda</h2><p><strong>Opening Remarks:</strong> Ms Moekti Handajani Soejachmoen (Kuki), Lead Co-Chair of the T20-Task Force 3: Governing Climate Target, Energy Transition, and environmental Protection</p><p>Keynote speech 1: Carbon Neutral Pathway of Indonesia</p><p>Keynote Speech 2: Global Low Carbon Energy Transition by Prof Jun Arima, Senior Policy Fellow of ERIA and Co-Chair of TF3</p><p><strong>Presentations and Panel Discussion</strong></p><p>Moderator: Dr. Alin Halimatussadiah, LPEM FEB University of Indonesia</p><p><strong>Presentation 1: Energy Technology Perspective (Battery electric storage, Hydrogen/ Ammonia, CCS/CCUS, and Direct Air Capture)</strong></p><ul><li>Battery electric storage: Akira Yasugi, P.E. Engineering manager, I&amp;C and Electrical Engineering Team, Power Plant engineering Group, Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Ltd</li><li>Hydrogen/Ammonia: Jitendra Roychoudhury, King Abdullah Petroleum Studies and Research Center (KAPSARC), Riyadh, Saudi Arabia</li><li>CCS (Capture)</li><li>CCS (Storage): Dr. Ziqiu Xue, Research Institute for Innovative Technologies for the Earth (RITE)</li><li>Direct Air Capture: Ryohei Numaguchi, Ph.D., Researcher, Energy System Research Department, Corporate Technology Division, Kawasaki Heavy Industry, Ltd.</li></ul><p><strong>Presentation 2: Energy Financing (Public, Private and Climate Finance Mechanisms)</strong></p><ul><li>Public Finance : Darshak Mehta, Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department of the Asian Development Bank (ADB)</li><li>Private Finance: Yukimi Shimura, Director, Sustainable Business Origination team, Sustainable Business Office, Solution Products Division, MUFJ Bank, Ltd.</li><li>Climate Financing: Frank Jotzo (Australian National University)</li><li>Carbon Credit: Kikuko Shinchi, Senior Researcher, Climate Change Solution Group, Sustainability Division, Mitsubishi Research Institute, Inc.</li></ul><p>Panel Discussion: Dialogue between Energy Technology and Financing Group, with topics:</p><ul><li>Role of financing for supporting energy technology development and deployment</li><li>Expectations to Governments</li><li>Comments from the energy technology group</li><li>Comments from the financing group</li></ul><p>Closing Remarks: Mr Koji Hachiyama, Chief Operating Officer, ERIA</p><p><a class="bluebtn" title="Click here to register via Eventbrite" href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/t20-side-event-webinar-emerging-economies-towards-net-zero-emission-tickets-379522230207" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Register Now!</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:16:"Ms Dian Lutfiana";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-07-20";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:7905:"T20 side event webinar on 'Emerging Economies towards Net Zero Emission: Challenges and Opportunities on Technology Innovation and Financing' T20 side event webinar on 'Emerging Economies towards Net Zero Emission: Challenges and Opportunities on Technology Innovation and Financing' The 2022 G20 Indonesia Presidency&rsquo;s Energy Transition pillar of &lsquo;Global cleaner energy systems and just transitions&rsquo; aims at achieving a global deal to accelerate the energy transition. G20 Indonesia Presidency has opted, therefore, for its pathway to achieve the carbon neutrality target by accelerating the just process of reducing energy-related greenhouse gas emissions through various forms of decarbonisation. Such decarbonisation means an additional investment is necessary. Nevertheless, the question remains: how to finance the energy transition, especially in the context of reaching carbon neutrality pledges that vary across G20 countries?
Apart from traditional financial and policy instruments, countries need also to fully employ new and innovative schemes to support clean energy financing and markets. This virtual workshop aims to explore workable financing mechanisms in each technology cluster (including renewable energy resources and their carriers, CCS/CCUS, and Direct Air Capture technologies) that play important roles in the energy transition with an emphasis on the ASEAN countries.
This Virtual Workshop is jointly organised by the Institute of Economic and Social Research Faculty of Economics and Business, University of Indonesia (LPEM-FEB UI) and Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA). 
Event Details

Date: Wednesday, 20 July 2022
Time: 2 PM -&nbsp; 4:15 PM (Jakarta time, UTC+7)&nbsp;

Agenda
Opening Remarks: Ms Moekti Handajani Soejachmoen (Kuki), Lead Co-Chair of the T20-Task Force 3: Governing Climate Target, Energy Transition, and environmental Protection
Keynote speech 1: Carbon Neutral Pathway of Indonesia
Keynote Speech 2: Global Low Carbon Energy Transition by Prof Jun Arima, Senior Policy Fellow of ERIA and Co-Chair of TF3
Presentations and Panel Discussion
Moderator: Dr. Alin Halimatussadiah, LPEM FEB University of Indonesia
Presentation 1: Energy Technology Perspective (Battery electric storage, Hydrogen/ Ammonia, CCS/CCUS, and Direct Air Capture)

Battery electric storage: Akira Yasugi, P.E. Engineering manager, I&amp;C and Electrical Engineering Team, Power Plant engineering Group, Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Ltd
Hydrogen/Ammonia: Jitendra Roychoudhury, King Abdullah Petroleum Studies and Research Center (KAPSARC), Riyadh, Saudi Arabia
CCS (Capture)
CCS (Storage): Dr. Ziqiu Xue, Research Institute for Innovative Technologies for the Earth (RITE)
Direct Air Capture: Ryohei Numaguchi, Ph.D., Researcher, Energy System Research Department, Corporate Technology Division, Kawasaki Heavy Industry, Ltd.

Presentation 2: Energy Financing (Public, Private and Climate Finance Mechanisms)

Public Finance : Darshak Mehta, Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department of the Asian Development Bank (ADB)
Private Finance: Yukimi Shimura, Director, Sustainable Business Origination team, Sustainable Business Office, Solution Products Division, MUFJ Bank, Ltd.
Climate Financing: Frank Jotzo (Australian National University)
Carbon Credit: Kikuko Shinchi, Senior Researcher, Climate Change Solution Group, Sustainability Division, Mitsubishi Research Institute, Inc.

Panel Discussion: Dialogue between Energy Technology and Financing Group, with topics:

Role of financing for supporting energy technology development and deployment
Expectations to Governments
Comments from the energy technology group
Comments from the financing group

Closing Remarks: Mr Koji Hachiyama, Chief Operating Officer, ERIA
