02T";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-06-29 10:55:39";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-07-20 13:44:21";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"18";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:22:"dian.lutfiana@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:13;O:8:"stdClass":48:{s:19:"article_category_id";s:5:"13092";s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6843";s:11:"category_id";s:3:"243";s:9:"short_des";N;s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:64:"dare-to-start-addressing-gender-gaps-in-entrepreneurship-in-asia";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:65:"Dare to Start: Addressing Gender Gaps in Entrepreneurship in Asia";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-07-05";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"7";s:7:"content";s:12150:"<p data-key="193"><img src="http://www.eria.org/uploads/media/Events/2022_July_Dare%20to%20Start-%20Addressing%20Gender%20Gaps%20in%20Entrepreneurship%20in%20Asia_flyer_rev2.jpg" alt="" width="800" height="400" /></p><p data-key="193">Entrepreneurs are an engine of economic growth (ERIA 2022). Addressing gaps between men and women entrepreneurs can increase innovation, create jobs, improve productivity, boost competitiveness, and grow wealth. In emerging Asia, recent rapid economic growth has led to remarkably improved socio-economic conditions, with expanded and enhanced employment opportunities, improved educational attainment, gradually rising wages and better living standards. Nevertheless, gender gap persists in many areas including entrepreneurship according to metrics such as self-employment rates and business creation rates. There are also gender differences, on average, in the nature of self-employment and entrepreneurship activities (ERIA 2021). This includes sector of operation, likelihood of creating additional jobs and more. Due consideration should be paid in terms of gender gaps in motivations or different barriers they face. Following the launch of ERIA&rsquo;s Entrepreneurship, Start-ups, and Innovation (E-S-I) Knowledge Lab as part of its ongoing efforts to engage the growing community of innovators, aspiring entrepreneurs, and start-uppers in the region, this seminar aims to convene a blend of expertise and knowledge regarding the region, data, policy, education and gender issues, to identify ways to address potential structural and emerging challenges that are hampering women&rsquo;s entrepreneurship. This will also set the path for the future work of E-S-I Knowledge Lab on women entrepreneurship.</p><p data-key="193"><span data-key="194"><strong data-slate-leaf="true">Agenda</strong></span></p><p data-key="195"><span data-key="196">Moderator: Jui Chakravorty, Special Projects Editor, Nikkei Asia</span></p><p data-key="197"><span data-key="198">Opening Remarks: Toru Furuichi, Director General for Research and Policy Design Administration, ERIA</span></p><p data-key="199"><span data-key="200">Moderated Panel Discussion </span></p><ul data-key="201"><li data-key="202"><span data-key="203">Giulia Ajmone Marsan, Director, Strategy and Partnership, ERIA </span></li><li data-key="204"><span data-key="205">Naoko Kawaguchi, Acting Head of the Tokyo Centre, OECD </span></li><li data-key="206"><span data-key="207">Natalie Au, Senior Associate, Gender Platform, Asian Ventre Philanthropy Network (AVPN) </span></li><li data-key="208"><span data-key="209">Kanyasorn Tansubhapol, Assistant to the President for Special Affairs, Chulalongkorn University</span></li></ul><p data-key="210" data-slate-fragment=""><span data-key="211">Wrap up: Jui Chakravorty, Special Projects Editor, Nikkei Asia</span></p><p data-key="210" data-slate-fragment=""><a class="bluebtn" title="Click here to register via Eventbrite" href="https://bit.ly/3QUh1um" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Register Now!</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:19:"Mr Fusanori Iwasaki";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:26:"ERIA and OECD Tokyo Centre";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-07-05";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:4757:"Dare to Start: Addressing Gender Gaps in Entrepreneurship in Asia Dare to Start: Addressing Gender Gaps in Entrepreneurship in Asia Entrepreneurs are an engine of economic growth (ERIA 2022). Addressing gaps between men and women entrepreneurs can increase innovation, create jobs, improve productivity, boost competitiveness, and grow wealth. In emerging Asia, recent rapid economic growth has led to remarkably improved socio-economic conditions, with expanded and enhanced employment opportunities, improved educational attainment, gradually rising wages and better living standards. Nevertheless, gender gap persists in many areas including entrepreneurship according to metrics such as self-employment rates and business creation rates. There are also gender differences, on average, in the nature of self-employment and entrepreneurship activities (ERIA 2021). This includes sector of operation, likelihood of creating additional jobs and more. Due consideration should be paid in terms of gender gaps in motivations or different barriers they face. Following the launch of ERIA&rsquo;s Entrepreneurship, Start-ups, and Innovation (E-S-I) Knowledge Lab as part of its ongoing efforts to engage the growing community of innovators, aspiring entrepreneurs, and start-uppers in the region, this seminar aims to convene a blend of expertise and knowledge regarding the region, data, policy, education and gender issues, to identify ways to address potential structural and emerging challenges that are hampering women&rsquo;s entrepreneurship. This will also set the path for the future work of E-S-I Knowledge Lab on women entrepreneurship.
Agenda
Moderator: Jui Chakravorty, Special Projects Editor, Nikkei Asia
Opening Remarks: Toru Furuichi, Director General for Research and Policy Design Administration, ERIA
Moderated Panel Discussion 

Giulia Ajmone Marsan, Director, Strategy and Partnership, ERIA 
Naoko Kawaguchi, Acting Head of the Tokyo Centre, OECD 
Natalie Au, Senior Associate, Gender Platform, Asian Ventre Philanthropy Network (AVPN) 
Kanyasorn Tansubhapol, Assistant to the President for Special Affairs, Chulalongkorn University

Wrap up: Jui Chakravorty, Special Projects Editor, Nikkei Asia

:tratS ot eraD aisA ni pihsruenerpertnE ni spaG redneG gnisserddA :tratS ot eraD";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-06-27 12:47:29";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-07-05 12:11:53";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"13";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:25:"fusanori.iwasaki@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:14;O:8:"stdClass":48:{s:19:"article_category_id";s:5:"13093";s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6840";s:11:"category_id";s:3:"243";s:9:"short_des";N;s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:83:"data-release-of-the-2018-longitudinal-study-of-ageing-and-health-in-the-philippines";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:83:"Data release of the 2018 Longitudinal Study of Ageing and Health in the Philippines";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-07-07";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"7";s:7:"content";s:4069:"<p><img src="http://www.eria.org/uploads/media/Events/2022-07-07-Data-release-flyer-rev.jpg" alt="" width="800" height="450" /></p><p><span style="font-size: 16px;"><a class="bluebtn" href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/longitudinal-study-of-ageing-and-health-in-the-philippines-data-release-tickets-373063913207" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Register Now!</a></span></p><p>The Longitudinal Study of Ageing and Health in the Philippines (LSAHP) in 2018 is the first multi-actor longitudinal study on ageing in the Philippines with information coming from older Filipinos, their caregivers, and adult children. It was conducted by ERIA and the Demographic Research and Development Foundation, Inc. (DRDF).</p><p>The 2018 baseline data provides comprehensive information on the health, economic status, and overall well-being of a nationally representative sample of elderly Filipinos aged 60 and above. These data have been a valuable resource for the crafting of evidence-based policies and programmes for this sector of the population.</p><p>Now, ERIA and DRDF are releasing the data of the baseline survey with researchers and policymakers in order to further develop this data to achieve a better society. This webinar is being held to explain the details of the survey and data, with an introduction on how to use it. Some examples of policy-related research will be shared, encouraging participants to utilise the data for impactful achievements. The data is expected to be released soon after the event, to those who the organiser approves after submitting a proposal and signed data usage agreement. The data request form will be activated as soon as this seminar has ended.</p><h2>Date and Time</h2><p>7 July 2022 / 2 PM to 3 PM&nbsp;(GMT+7)</p><h2>Co-host</h2><p>Demographic Research and Development Foundation, Inc. (DRDF)</p><h2>&nbsp;Agenda</h2><p>Hosted by the Healthcare Unit and Communications Department of ERIA and DRDF, the virtual conference will last 1 hour via Zoom platform with a 10-minute introduction and short Q&amp;A at the end.</p><p>During the presentations, the audience may post questions through Q&amp;A. (Chat will be locked.)</p><p>Moderator: Dr Joy Cruz, PhDcip</p><table style="width: 612px;"><tr style="height: 43px;"><td style="height: 43px; width: 158.248px;"><p><strong>TIME </strong>(WIB)</p></td><td style="height: 43px; width: 439.752px;"><p><strong>AGENDA</strong></p></td></tr><tr style="height: 41px;"><td style="height: 41px; width: 158.248px;"><p>2&nbsp;PM to 2:10 PM</p></td><td style="height: 41px; width: 439.752px;"><p>Opening remarks:</p><ul><li>Dr Takuma Kato, Director of Healthcare Unit, ERIA</li><li>Dr&nbsp;Yasuhiko Saito, Senior Advisor on Population Ageing, ERIA</li></ul></td></tr><tr style="height: 210px;"><td style="height: 210px; width: 158.248px;"><p>2:10 PM to 2:35 PM</p></td><td style="height: 210px; width: 439.752px;"><p>Seminar Part 1: Dr. Grace T. Cruz, LSAHP Principal Investigator</p><ul><li>LSAHP Objectives</li><li>Description of LSAHP Baseline Data (2018)</li><li>Data Collection Procedure</li><li>Study Instruments</li><li>Introduction of LSAHP Publications</li><li>Introduction of On-going Research</li><li>LSAHP Findings as Policy and Program Inputs</li></ul><p><strong>&nbsp;</strong></p></td></tr><tr style="height: 167px;"><td style="height: 167px; width: 158.248px;"><p>2:35 PM to 2:45 PM</p></td><td style="height: 167px; width: 439.752px;"><p>Seminar Part 2: Video presentation</p><p>Introduction to the LSAHP Data Request Portal</p><ul><li>Data User Agreement and Research Proposal</li><li>LSAHP Sampling Weights</li></ul></td></tr><tr style="height: 43px;"><td style="height: 43px; width: 158.248px;"><p>2:45 PM to 3 PM</p></td><td style="height: 43px; width: 439.752px;"><p>Question and answer (15 min)</p></td></tr></table><h2>Reference:</h2><p>DRDF website, in which data request forms will be uploaded to after the seminar</p><p><a class="bluebtn" href="https://www.drdf.org.ph/lsahp">DRDF WEBSITE</a></p><p>Follow @ERIAorg and @DRDFinc on Twitter for updates.</p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:14:"Ms Nanda Putri";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-07-07";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:6007:"Data release of the 2018 Longitudinal Study of Ageing and Health in the Philippines Data release of the 2018 Longitudinal Study of Ageing and Health in the Philippines Register Now!
The Longitudinal Study of Ageing and Health in the Philippines (LSAHP) in 2018 is the first multi-actor longitudinal study on ageing in the Philippines with information coming from older Filipinos, their caregivers, and adult children. It was conducted by ERIA and the Demographic Research and Development Foundation, Inc. (DRDF).
The 2018 baseline data provides comprehensive information on the health, economic status, and overall well-being of a nationally representative sample of elderly Filipinos aged 60 and above. These data have been a valuable resource for the crafting of evidence-based policies and programmes for this sector of the population.
Now, ERIA and DRDF are releasing the data of the baseline survey with researchers and policymakers in order to further develop this data to achieve a better society. This webinar is being held to explain the details of the survey and data, with an introduction on how to use it. Some examples of policy-related research will be shared, encouraging participants to utilise the data for impactful achievements. The data is expected to be released soon after the event, to those who the organiser approves after submitting a proposal and signed data usage agreement. The data request form will be activated as soon as this seminar has ended.
Date and Time
7 July 2022 / 2 PM to 3 PM&nbsp;(GMT+7)
Co-host
Demographic Research and Development Foundation, Inc. (DRDF)
&nbsp;Agenda
Hosted by the Healthcare Unit and Communications Department of ERIA and DRDF, the virtual conference will last 1 hour via Zoom platform with a 10-minute introduction and short Q&amp;A at the end.
During the presentations, the audience may post questions through Q&amp;A. (Chat will be locked.)
Moderator: Dr Joy Cruz, PhDcip




TIME (WIB)


AGENDA




2&nbsp;PM to 2:10 PM


Opening remarks:

Dr Takuma Kato, Director of Healthcare Unit, ERIA
Dr&nbsp;Yasuhiko Saito, Senior Advisor on Population Ageing, ERIA





2:10 PM to 2:35 PM


Seminar Part 1: Dr. Grace T. Cruz, LSAHP Principal Investigator

LSAHP Objectives
Description of LSAHP Baseline Data (2018)
Data Collection Procedure
Study Instruments
Introduction of LSAHP Publications
Introduction of On-going Research
LSAHP Findings as Policy and Program Inputs

&nbsp;




2:35 PM to 2:45 PM


Seminar Part 2: Video presentation
Introduction to the LSAHP Data Request Portal

Data User Agreement and Research Proposal
LSAHP Sampling Weights





2:45 PM to 3 PM


Question and answer (15 min)




Reference:
DRDF website, in which data request forms will be uploaded to after the seminar
DRDF WEBSITE
Follow @ERIAorg and @DRDFinc on Twitter for updates. ETISBEW FDRD
ranimes eht retfa ot dedaolpu eb lliw smrof tseuqer atad hcihw ni ,etisbew FDRD
:ecnerefeR




)nim 51( rewsna dna noitseuQ


MP 3 ot MP 54:2

lasoporP hcraeseR dna tnemeergA resU ataD

latroP tseuqeR ataD PHASL eht ot noitcudortnI
noitatneserp oediV :2 traP ranimeS


MP 54:2 ot MP 53:2

stupnI margorP dna yciloP sa sgnidniF PHASL
hcraeseR gniog-nO fo noitcudortnI

stnemurtsnI ydutS

MP 53:2 ot MP 01:2

MP 01:2 ot MP;psbn&2




ADNEGA


)BIW( EMIT




picDhP ,zurC yoJ rD :rotaredoM
).dekcol eb lliw tahC( .A;pma&Q hguorht snoitseuq tsop yam ecneidua eht ,snoitatneserp eht gniruD
.dne eht ta A;pma&Q trohs dna noitcudortni etunim-01 a htiw mroftalp mooZ aiv ruoh 1 tsal lliw ecnerefnoc lautriv eht ,FDRD dna AIRE fo tnemtrapeD snoitacinummoC dna tinU erachtlaeH eht yb detsoH
adnegA;psbn&
)FDRD( .cnI ,noitadnuoF tnempoleveD dna hcraeseR cihpargomeD
tsoh-oC
)7+TMG(;psbn&MP 3 ot MP 2 / 2202 yluJ 7
emiT dna etaD
.dedne sah ranimes siht sa noos sa detavitca eb lliw mrof tseuqer atad ehT .tnemeerga egasu atad dengis dna lasoporp a gnittimbus retfa sevorppa resinagro eht ohw esoht ot ,tneve eht retfa noos desaeler eb ot detcepxe si atad ehT .stnemeveihca luftcapmi rof atad eht esilitu ot stnapicitrap gnigaruocne ,derahs eb lliw hcraeser detaler-ycilop fo selpmaxe emoS .ti esu ot woh no noitcudortni na htiw ,atad dna yevrus eht fo sliated eht nialpxe ot dleh gnieb si ranibew sihT .yteicos retteb a eveihca ot atad siht poleved rehtruf ot redro ni srekamycilop dna srehcraeser htiw yevrus enilesab eht fo atad eht gnisaeler era FDRD dna AIRE ,woN
.noitalupop eht fo rotces siht rof semmargorp dna seicilop desab-ecnedive fo gnitfarc eht rof ecruoser elbaulav a neeb evah atad esehT .evoba dna 06 dega sonipiliF ylredle fo elpmas evitatneserper yllanoitan a fo gnieb-llew llarevo dna ,sutats cimonoce ,htlaeh eht no noitamrofni evisneherpmoc sedivorp atad enilesab 8102 ehT
.)FDRD( .cnI ,noitadnuoF tnempoleveD dna hcraeseR cihpargomeD eht dna AIRE yb detcudnoc saw tI .nerdlihc tluda dna ,srevigerac rieht ,sonipiliF redlo morf gnimoc noitamrofni htiw senippilihP eht ni gniega no yduts lanidutignol rotca-itlum tsrif eht si 8102 ni )PHASL( senippilihP eht ni htlaeH dna gniegA fo ydutS lanidutignoL ehT
!woN retsigeR senippilihP eht ni htlaeH dna gniegA fo ydutS lanidutignoL 8102 eht fo esaeler ataD senippilihP eht ni htlaeH dna gniegA fo ydutS lanidutignoL 8102 eht fo esaeler ataD";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-06-24 07:53:01";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-07-05 15:45:50";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"13";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:20:"nanda.putri@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:15;O:8:"stdClass":48:{s:19:"article_category_id";s:5:"13014";s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6824";s:11:"category_id";s:3:"243";s:9:"short_des";N;s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:73:"unpacking-the-rcep-agreement-public-private-dialogue-series-4--investment";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:75:"Unpacking the RCEP Agreement: Public-Private Dialogue Series #4- Investment";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-06-29";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"6";s:7:"content";s:3892:"<p><strong>Unpacking the RCEP Agreement: Public-Private Dialogue Series - Dialogue #4</strong></p><p><img src="http://www.eria.org/uploads/media/2022_June_Unpacking-RCEP-Agreement-Public-Private-Dialogue-4_1.jpg" alt="" width="850" height="425" /></p><p>The Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) marks the establishment of a free trade agreement among the 15 member states. The RCEP Investment Provisions aims to foster the investment ecosystem across ASEAN and relevant RCEP participating countries. Investment has become a significant driver of economic growth over the years, especially when most RCEP countries face economic fallout due to COVID-19. Thus, facilitating a conducive investment ecosystem for all stakeholders is crucial to fostering the region&rsquo;s more attractive and viable market. The ERIA&rsquo;s Capacity Building Programme with the Secretary-General of the Council for the Development of Cambodia (CDC) will co-host a &lsquo;Public-Private Dialogues: Unpacking the RCEP Agreement#4- Investment&#039; on 29 June. This dialogue will discuss the RCEP Investment Provision in order to unpack different business interests in assessing their level of preparedness and understanding of how the RCEP chapter on investment could be a game-changer in the services industry. Join us to glean insights from the line-up of government officials and private sectors.</p><table><tr><td width="104"><p>09:00 &ndash; 09:25</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Opening Remarks:</strong></p><ul><li>Mr Koji Hachiyama, Chief Operating Officer, Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA)</li><li><p>H.E. Sok Chenda Sophea, Minister attached to the Prime Minister, Secretary-General of the Council for the Development of Cambodia (CDC)</p></li></ul></td></tr><tr><td width="104"><p>09:25 - 10:00</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Session 1: Setting the scene: The RCEP Investment Provisions </strong></p><p><strong>Moderator:&nbsp;</strong>Mr Sven Callebaut, International Trade Consultant, ERIA</p><p><strong>Presenters:</strong></p><ul><li>Ms Deborah ELMS, Founder and CEO, Asian Trade Centre</li><li>Dr. SAR Senera, Director, Department of Legal Affairs and Investment Law, Council for the Development of Cambodia (CDC)</li></ul><p>Q&amp;A with the audience.</p><p>This session will provide a precise description of what the RCEP provisions on investment are, how they apply to future investors in Cambodia and how Cambodia&rsquo;s legal and regulatory environment for FDI is fit-for-purpose.</p></td></tr><tr><td width="104"><p>10:00 &ndash; 11:00</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Session 2: Private sector perspectives on opportunities for Investing in Cambodia through RCEP provisions</strong></p><p><strong>Moderator:&nbsp;</strong>Mr Sven Callebaut, International Trade Consultant, ERIA</p><p><strong>Panellists:</strong></p><ul><li>Mr Paul Clements, Executive Chairperson, IBC</li><li>Mr Soreasmey Ke Bin, CEO Confluences and Chairman CCIFC</li><li>Mr Kenneth Tang, CEO Dynamic Group and Chairman, Auscham Cambodia</li><li>Mr Harrison White, CEO, Cambodia Investment Review</li></ul><p>Q&amp;A with the audience.</p><p>This session will explore how the RCEP chapter on investment could be a game changer for Cambodia to attract FDI in priority sectors from RCEP members.</p></td></tr><tr><td width="104"><p>11:05 -11:15</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Session 3: Summary of discussions and key items of a continued Public-Private Dialogue on Investment in Cambodia</strong></p><ul><li>Mr Clint O&rsquo;Connell, DFDL.</li></ul><p>Q&amp;A with the audience.<strong>&nbsp;</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td width="104">&nbsp;</td><td width="497">&nbsp;</td></tr></table><p><a class="bluebtn" href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/unpacking-the-rcep-agreement-4-investment-tickets-367339019897" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">REGISTER NOW</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:17:"Ms Lina Maulidina";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-06-29";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2022-06-29";s:8:"keywords";s:6539:"Unpacking the RCEP Agreement: Public-Private Dialogue Series #4- Investment Unpacking the RCEP Agreement: Public-Private Dialogue Series #4- Investment Unpacking the RCEP Agreement: Public-Private Dialogue Series - Dialogue #4

The Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) marks the establishment of a free trade agreement among the 15 member states. The RCEP Investment Provisions aims to foster the investment ecosystem across ASEAN and relevant RCEP participating countries. Investment has become a significant driver of economic growth over the years, especially when most RCEP countries face economic fallout due to COVID-19. Thus, facilitating a conducive investment ecosystem for all stakeholders is crucial to fostering the region&rsquo;s more attractive and viable market. The ERIA&rsquo;s Capacity Building Programme with the Secretary-General of the Council for the Development of Cambodia (CDC) will co-host a &lsquo;Public-Private Dialogues: Unpacking the RCEP Agreement#4- Investment' on 29 June. This dialogue will discuss the RCEP Investment Provision in order to unpack different business interests in assessing their level of preparedness and understanding of how the RCEP chapter on investment could be a game-changer in the services industry. Join us to glean insights from the line-up of government officials and private sectors.




09:00 &ndash; 09:25


Opening Remarks:

Mr Koji Hachiyama, Chief Operating Officer, Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA)

H.E. Sok Chenda Sophea, Minister attached to the Prime Minister, Secretary-General of the Council for the Development of Cambodia (CDC)






09:25 - 10:00


Session 1: Setting the scene: The RCEP Investment Provisions 
Moderator:&nbsp;Mr Sven Callebaut, International Trade Consultant, ERIA
Presenters:

Ms Deborah ELMS, Founder and CEO, Asian Trade Centre
Dr. SAR Senera, Director, Department of Legal Affairs and Investment Law, Council for the Development of Cambodia (CDC)

Q&amp;A with the audience.
This session will provide a precise description of what the RCEP provisions on investment are, how they apply to future investors in Cambodia and how Cambodia&rsquo;s legal and regulatory environment for FDI is fit-for-purpose.




10:00 &ndash; 11:00


Session 2: Private sector perspectives on opportunities for Investing in Cambodia through RCEP provisions
Moderator:&nbsp;Mr Sven Callebaut, International Trade Consultant, ERIA
Panellists:

Mr Paul Clements, Executive Chairperson, IBC
Mr Soreasmey Ke Bin, CEO Confluences and Chairman CCIFC
Mr Kenneth Tang, CEO Dynamic Group and Chairman, Auscham Cambodia
Mr Harrison White, CEO, Cambodia Investment Review

Q&amp;A with the audience.
This session will explore how the RCEP chapter on investment could be a game changer for Cambodia to attract FDI in priority sectors from RCEP members.




11:05 -11:15


Session 3: Summary of discussions and key items of a continued Public-Private Dialogue on Investment in Cambodia

Mr Clint O&rsquo;Connell, DFDL.

Q&amp;A with the audience.&nbsp;



&nbsp;
&nbsp;

:skrameR gninepO


52:90 ;hsadn& 00:90




.srotces etavirp dna slaiciffo tnemnrevog fo pu-enil eht morf sthgisni naelg ot su nioJ .yrtsudni secivres eht ni regnahc-emag a eb dluoc tnemtsevni no retpahc PECR eht woh fo gnidnatsrednu dna ssenderaperp fo level rieht gnissessa ni stseretni ssenisub tnereffid kcapnu ot redro ni noisivorP tnemtsevnI PECR eht ssucsid lliw eugolaid sihT .enuJ 92 no 'tnemtsevnI -4#tnemeergA PECR eht gnikcapnU :seugolaiD etavirP-cilbuP;ouqsl& a tsoh-oc lliw )CDC( aidobmaC fo tnempoleveD eht rof licnuoC eht fo lareneG-yraterceS eht htiw emmargorP gnidliuB yticapaC s;ouqsr&AIRE ehT .tekram elbaiv dna evitcartta erom s;ouqsr&noiger eht gniretsof ot laicurc si sredlohekats lla rof metsysoce tnemtsevni evicudnoc a gnitatilicaf ,suhT .91-DIVOC ot eud tuollaf cimonoce ecaf seirtnuoc PECR tsom nehw yllaicepse ,sraey eht revo htworg cimonoce fo revird tnacifingis a emoceb sah tnemtsevnI .seirtnuoc gnitapicitrap PECR tnaveler dna NAESA ssorca metsysoce tnemtsevni eht retsof ot smia snoisivorP tnemtsevnI PECR ehT .setats rebmem 51 eht gnoma tnemeerga edart eerf a fo tnemhsilbatse eht skram )PECR( pihsrentraP cimonocE evisneherpmoC lanoigeR ehT

4# eugolaiD - seireS eugolaiD etavirP-cilbuP :tnemeergA PECR eht gnikcapnU tnemtsevnI -4# seireS eugolaiD etavirP-cilbuP :tnemeergA PECR eht gnikcapnU tnemtsevnI -4# seireS eugolaiD etavirP-cilbuP :tnemeergA PECR eht gnikcapnU";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-06-15 14:42:00";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-06-24 16:09:19";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"18";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:23:"lina.maulidina@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:16;O:8:"stdClass":48:{s:19:"article_category_id";s:5:"12630";s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6749";s:11:"category_id";s:3:"243";s:9:"short_des";N;s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:44:"carbon-neutrality-roadmap-of-asean-countries";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:44:"Carbon Neutrality Roadmap of ASEAN Countries";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-05-31";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"5";s:7:"content";s:2229:"<p>IEEJ will present their analysis on the roadmap for ASEAN countries&rsquo; transition to carbon neutrality. Recently, with the COP26 as a trigger, the decarbonisation movement is spreading not only across developed countries but also to many other countries including the ASEAN region, and some ASEAN countries have declared carbon neutrality by the mid of this century. Such highly ambitious GHG emissions reductions require a fundamental transformation of energy systems. At the same time, the energy transition cannot be accomplished with a uniform measure. In particular, the ASEAN countries are still highly dependent on fossil fuels and experiencing high economic and energy demand growth. Given these circumstances, the study aims to quantitatively describe the pathway of energy transition necessary to realise carbon neutrality in ASEAN countries by using a cost-optimal technology selection model. The IEEJ conducted this study together with the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA), and fully discussed the outcomes with each of the ASEAN countries to reflect their views and realities.</p><p>The IEA is also expected to release its ASEAN Energy Outlook soon. It is our privilege that Tim Gould, Chief Energy Economist, the IEA will participate in this webinar as a commentator in the panel discussion.</p><h2>Speakers</h2><ul><li>Toshiyuki Sakamoto, Board Member, Director, IEEJ</li><li>Soichi Morimoto, Senior Researcher, Climate Change Group, IEEJ</li><li>Yuji Mizuno, Chief Researcher, CCUS Group, IEEJ</li></ul><h2>Guest Commentator</h2><p>Tim Gould, Chief Energy Economist, IEA</p><h2>Inquiries</h2><p>If you have any inquiries, please contact <a title="Send email to the IEEJ" href="mailto:ieej-mail@tky.ieej.or.jp" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">ieej-mail@tky.ieej.or.jp</a></p><p><a class="bluebtn" title="click here to register now" href="https://us02web.zoom.us/webinar/register/WN_e8kY-kvFTgWuzlSTIA0EBw" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Register Now</a></p><p><a class="bluebtn" title="Click here to view the agenda" href="https://eneken.ieej.or.jp/en/seminar/other/ieej_webinar_for_the_world220531.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Agenda</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:4:"Zoom";s:5:"major";s:4:"IEEJ";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:4:"IEEJ";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-05-31";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:3699:"Carbon Neutrality Roadmap of ASEAN Countries Carbon Neutrality Roadmap of ASEAN Countries IEEJ will present their analysis on the roadmap for ASEAN countries&rsquo; transition to carbon neutrality. Recently, with the COP26 as a trigger, the decarbonisation movement is spreading not only across developed countries but also to many other countries including the ASEAN region, and some ASEAN countries have declared carbon neutrality by the mid of this century. Such highly ambitious GHG emissions reductions require a fundamental transformation of energy systems. At the same time, the energy transition cannot be accomplished with a uniform measure. In particular, the ASEAN countries are still highly dependent on fossil fuels and experiencing high economic and energy demand growth. Given these circumstances, the study aims to quantitatively describe the pathway of energy transition necessary to realise carbon neutrality in ASEAN countries by using a cost-optimal technology selection model. The IEEJ conducted this study together with the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA), and fully discussed the outcomes with each of the ASEAN countries to reflect their views and realities.
The IEA is also expected to release its ASEAN Energy Outlook soon. It is our privilege that Tim Gould, Chief Energy Economist, the IEA will participate in this webinar as a commentator in the panel discussion.
Speakers

Toshiyuki Sakamoto, Board Member, Director, IEEJ
Soichi Morimoto, Senior Researcher, Climate Change Group, IEEJ
Yuji Mizuno, Chief Researcher, CCUS Group, IEEJ

Guest Commentator
Tim Gould, Chief Energy Economist, IEA
Inquiries
If you have any inquiries, please contact ieej-mail@tky.ieej.or.jp
Register Now

woN retsigeR
pj.ro.jeei.ykt@liam-jeei tcatnoc esaelp ,seiriuqni yna evah uoy fI
seiriuqnI
AEI ,tsimonocE ygrenE feihC ,dluoG miT
rotatnemmoC tseuG

JEEI ,puorG SUCC ,rehcraeseR feihC ,onuziM ijuY
JEEI ,puorG egnahC etamilC ,rehcraeseR roineS ,otomiroM ihcioS
JEEI ,rotceriD ,rebmeM draoB ,otomakaS ikuyihsoT

srekaepS
.noissucsid lenap eht ni rotatnemmoc a sa ranibew siht ni etapicitrap lliw AEI eht ,tsimonocE ygrenE feihC ,dluoG miT taht egelivirp ruo si tI .noos kooltuO ygrenE NAESA sti esaeler ot detcepxe osla si AEI ehT
.seitilaer dna sweiv rieht tcelfer ot seirtnuoc NAESA eht fo hcae htiw semoctuo eht dessucsid ylluf dna ,)AIRE( aisA tsaE dna NAESA rof etutitsnI hcraeseR cimonocE eht htiw rehtegot yduts siht detcudnoc JEEI ehT .ledom noitceles ygolonhcet lamitpo-tsoc a gnisu yb seirtnuoc NAESA ni ytilartuen nobrac esilaer ot yrassecen noitisnart ygrene fo yawhtap eht ebircsed ylevitatitnauq ot smia yduts eht ,secnatsmucric eseht neviG .htworg dnamed ygrene dna cimonoce hgih gnicneirepxe dna sleuf lissof no tnedneped ylhgih llits era seirtnuoc NAESA eht ,ralucitrap nI .erusaem mrofinu a htiw dehsilpmocca eb tonnac noitisnart ygrene eht ,emit emas eht tA .smetsys ygrene fo noitamrofsnart latnemadnuf a eriuqer snoitcuder snoissime GHG suoitibma ylhgih hcuS .yrutnec siht fo dim eht yb ytilartuen nobrac deralced evah seirtnuoc NAESA emos dna ,noiger NAESA eht gnidulcni seirtnuoc rehto ynam ot osla tub seirtnuoc depoleved ssorca ylno ton gnidaerps si tnemevom noitasinobraced eht ,reggirt a sa 62POC eht htiw ,yltneceR .ytilartuen nobrac ot noitisnart ;ouqsr&seirtnuoc NAESA rof pamdaor eht no sisylana rieht tneserp lliw JEEI seirtnuoC NAESA fo pamdaoR ytilartueN nobraC seirtnuoC NAESA fo pamdaoR ytilartueN nobraC";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-05-11 11:46:30";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-05-11 15:12:14";s:11:"modified_by";s:1:"4";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:24:"ieej-mail@tky.ieej.or.jp";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:17;O:8:"stdClass":48:{s:19:"article_category_id";s:5:"12677";s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6736";s:11:"category_id";s:3:"243";s:9:"short_des";N;s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:81:"unpacking-the-rcep-agreement-public-private-dialogue-series-3---trade-in-services";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:84:"Unpacking the RCEP Agreement: Public-Private Dialogue Series  #3 - Trade in Services";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-05-23";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"5";s:7:"content";s:3730:"<p><strong>Unpacking the RCEP Agreement: Public-Private Dialogue Series - Dialogue #3</strong></p><p><strong><img src="/uploads/media/Events/2022_May_Trade-in-Services.jpg" alt="" width="800" height="450" /></strong></p><p>ERIA&rsquo;s Capacity Building Programme is organising a series of five Public-Private Dialogues, <em>&#039;Unpacking the RCEP Agreement&#039;</em>. The Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) marks the establishment of a free trade agreement amongst the 15 member states. RCEP will create new business opportunities and change the shape of trade in the region. Dialogue 3 will discuss the &lsquo;Trade in Services&rsquo; and how it will also facilitate the cross-border trade and speeds up delivery amongst RCEP participating countries.</p><p>With Trade in Services, RCEP will opens up services amongst member countries for professional services for instance telecommunications and financial services. There will also be mutual recognition of professional qualifications, with obligations and frameworks for increased cooperation. This sector has also become the largest recipient of the inflow for foreign direct investment (FDI) across ASEAN Member States (AMS) over the past 15 years with 38% to 69% contribution of gross domestic product (GD) of AMS. Glean insights with us to unlock its utmost potential of how RCEP could leverage the growth of trade in services in Cambodia.</p><table><tr><td width="104"><p>9:00 &ndash; 9:10</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Opening Remarks: </strong></p><ul><li>Mr Jeremy Gross, Director of Capacity Building, ERIA</li><li>H.E. Sim Sokheng,&nbsp;Secretary of State, Ministry of Commerce, Cambodia</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td width="104"><p>9:10 - 09:40</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Session 1: Setting the scene: The RCEP Trade in Services Provisions </strong></p><p><strong>Moderator: </strong>Mr Sven Callebaut, International Trade Consultant, CBP, ERIA</p><p><strong>Presenters:</strong></p><ul><li>Ms Deborah Elms,&nbsp;Executive Director, Asian Trade Center</li><li>Mr Clint O&rsquo;Connell, Partner and Head of Tax and Customs, DFDL</li></ul><p>Q&amp;A with the audience.</p><p>This session will provide a precise description of what the RCEP provisions are and whether Cambodia&rsquo;s legal and regulatory system is ready for the trade in services.</p></td></tr><tr><td width="104"><p>09:40 &ndash; 11:00</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Session 2: Private Sector Perspectives on Opportunities for Cambodia in RCEP</strong></p><p><strong>Moderator: </strong>Mr Sven Callebaut, International Trade Consultant, CBP, ERIA</p><ul><li>Mr Kay Lot, Entrepreneur, Business Owner&nbsp;</li><li>Ms Phurik Ratana, Private Sector and Investment Specialist&nbsp;</li><li>Mr Harrison White, CEO, CIR Media&nbsp;</li><li>Mr Ashley Irving, Principal, IDP Cambodia, Vice-President Auscham Cambodia&nbsp;</li></ul><p>Q&amp;A with the audience.</p><p>This session will enable different business interests to assess their level of preparedness and understanding of how the RCEP trade in services could be a game changer in the services industry.</p></td></tr><tr><td width="104"><p>11:00 -11:15</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Session 3: Summary of discussions and key items of a continued Public-Private Dialogue on Trade in Services </strong></p><ul><li>HE Sok Siphana, Senior Adviser to the Royal Government of Cambodia</li></ul><p>Q&amp;A with the audience.<strong>&nbsp;</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td width="104"><p>11:15 &ndash; 11:30</p></td><td width="497"><p><strong>Closing remarks by MoC and ERIA</strong></p></td></tr></table><p><a class="bluebtn" href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/trade-in-services-tickets-337168519117">REGISTER NOW</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:17:"Ms Lina Maulidina";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-05-23";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:6409:"Unpacking the RCEP Agreement: Public-Private Dialogue Series  #3 - Trade in Services Unpacking the RCEP Agreement: Public-Private Dialogue Series  #3 - Trade in Services Unpacking the RCEP Agreement: Public-Private Dialogue Series - Dialogue #3

ERIA&rsquo;s Capacity Building Programme is organising a series of five Public-Private Dialogues, 'Unpacking the RCEP Agreement'. The Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) marks the establishment of a free trade agreement amongst the 15 member states. RCEP will create new business opportunities and change the shape of trade in the region. Dialogue 3 will discuss the &lsquo;Trade in Services&rsquo; and how it will also facilitate the cross-border trade and speeds up delivery amongst RCEP participating countries.
With Trade in Services, RCEP will opens up services amongst member countries for professional services for instance telecommunications and financial services. There will also be mutual recognition of professional qualifications, with obligations and frameworks for increased cooperation. This sector has also become the largest recipient of the inflow for foreign direct investment (FDI) across ASEAN Member States (AMS) over the past 15 years with 38% to 69% contribution of gross domestic product (GD) of AMS. Glean insights with us to unlock its utmost potential of how RCEP could leverage the growth of trade in services in Cambodia.




9:00 &ndash; 9:10


Opening Remarks: 

Mr Jeremy Gross, Director of Capacity Building, ERIA
H.E. Sim Sokheng,&nbsp;Secretary of State, Ministry of Commerce, Cambodia





9:10 - 09:40


Session 1: Setting the scene: The RCEP Trade in Services Provisions 
Moderator: Mr Sven Callebaut, International Trade Consultant, CBP, ERIA
Presenters:

Ms Deborah Elms,&nbsp;Executive Director, Asian Trade Center
Mr Clint O&rsquo;Connell, Partner and Head of Tax and Customs, DFDL

Q&amp;A with the audience.
This session will provide a precise description of what the RCEP provisions are and whether Cambodia&rsquo;s legal and regulatory system is ready for the trade in services.




09:40 &ndash; 11:00


Session 2: Private Sector Perspectives on Opportunities for Cambodia in RCEP
Moderator: Mr Sven Callebaut, International Trade Consultant, CBP, ERIA

Mr Kay Lot, Entrepreneur, Business Owner&nbsp;
Ms Phurik Ratana, Private Sector and Investment Specialist&nbsp;
Mr Harrison White, CEO, CIR Media&nbsp;
Mr Ashley Irving, Principal, IDP Cambodia, Vice-President Auscham Cambodia&nbsp;

Q&amp;A with the audience.
This session will enable different business interests to assess their level of preparedness and understanding of how the RCEP trade in services could be a game changer in the services industry.




11:00 -11:15


Session 3: Summary of discussions and key items of a continued Public-Private Dialogue on Trade in Services 

HE Sok Siphana, Senior Adviser to the Royal Government of Cambodia

Q&amp;A with the audience.&nbsp;




11:15 &ndash; 11:30


Closing remarks by MoC and ERIA

.aidobmaC ni secivres ni edart fo htworg eht egarevel dluoc PECR woh fo laitnetop tsomtu sti kcolnu ot su htiw sthgisni naelG .SMA fo )DG( tcudorp citsemod ssorg fo noitubirtnoc %96 ot %83 htiw sraey 51 tsap eht revo )SMA( setatS rebmeM NAESA ssorca )IDF( tnemtsevni tcerid ngierof rof wolfni eht fo tneipicer tsegral eht emoceb osla sah rotces sihT .noitarepooc desaercni rof skrowemarf dna snoitagilbo htiw ,snoitacifilauq lanoisseforp fo noitingocer lautum eb osla lliw erehT .secivres laicnanif dna snoitacinummocelet ecnatsni rof secivres lanoisseforp rof seirtnuoc rebmem tsgnoma secivres pu snepo lliw PECR ,secivreS ni edarT htiW
.seirtnuoc gnitapicitrap PECR tsgnoma yreviled pu sdeeps dna edart redrob-ssorc eht etatilicaf osla lliw ti woh dna ;ouqsr&secivreS ni edarT;ouqsl& eht ssucsid lliw 3 eugolaiD .noiger eht ni edart fo epahs eht egnahc dna seitinutroppo ssenisub wen etaerc lliw PECR .setats rebmem 51 eht tsgnoma tnemeerga edart eerf a fo tnemhsilbatse eht skram )PECR( pihsrentraP cimonocE evisneherpmoC lanoigeR ehT .'tnemeergA PECR eht gnikcapnU' ,seugolaiD etavirP-cilbuP evif fo seires a gnisinagro si emmargorP gnidliuB yticapaC s;ouqsr&AIRE

3# eugolaiD - seireS eugolaiD etavirP-cilbuP :tnemeergA PECR eht gnikcapnU secivreS ni edarT - 3#  seireS eugolaiD etavirP-cilbuP :tnemeergA PECR eht gnikcapnU secivreS ni edarT - 3#  seireS eugolaiD etavirP-cilbuP :tnemeergA PECR eht gnikcapnU";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-05-10 18:25:27";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-05-19 10:57:20";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"13";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:23:"lina.maulidina@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:18;O:8:"stdClass":48:{s:19:"article_category_id";s:5:"12675";s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6734";s:11:"category_id";s:3:"243";s:9:"short_des";N;s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:60:"pandemic-best-policy-strategies-balancing-health-and-economy";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:61:"Pandemic Best Policy Strategies: Balancing Health and Economy";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-05-19";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"5";s:7:"content";s:4457:"<p><strong>First regional conference on sharing pandemic best practices &ndash; virtual</strong></p><p><img src="http://www.eria.org/uploads/media/Events/2022_May_HCU.jpg" alt="" width="800" height="400" /></p><p>The COVID-19 pandemic for the past two years has transformed health systems and battled economies across the globe. Much COVID-19-focused research and development innovation, alongside the persevering efforts of political leaders to safeguard and sustain economic progress, has been undertaken. Within the diverse community of ERIA Member States alone, a variety of measures have been tackled to survive through attempts to balance each nation&rsquo;s health and economy. A first of its kind, this regional conference answers requests heard through regional meetings for such a gathering, and offers EMSs the opportunity to share with neighbors what they have learned to be most effective for them, in order to more smoothly exit this pandemic as well as better prepare for upcoming ones.</p><p>Experts have thus been invited to present their government&rsquo;s best policy strategy/ies that have had the greatest impact on balancing economy and health under the COVID-19 pandemic. This year&rsquo;s ASEAN chair, Cambodia, will open, introducing the hard-hit populous and developing archipelagos of Indonesia and the Philippines, the peninsular Thailand, the ASEAN neighbor India with its population of over one billion, and the technologically advanced Japan in East Asia. Articles, Op-Eds, policy papers, and academic publications (commentaries) are expected to arise from the presentations.</p><h2>Event Details</h2><ul><li>Date: Thursday, 19 May&nbsp; 2022</li><li>Time: 2 PM- 4 PM (Jakarta time, UTC+7)</li></ul><h2>Agenda</h2><table><tr><td width="118"><p><strong>TIME (UTC+7)</strong></p></td><td width="486"><p><strong>AGENDA</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td rel="noopener noreferrer">REGISTER NOW</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:14:"Ms Nanda Putri";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-05-19";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:6717:"Pandemic Best Policy Strategies: Balancing Health and Economy Pandemic Best Policy Strategies: Balancing Health and Economy First regional conference on sharing pandemic best practices &ndash; virtual

The COVID-19 pandemic for the past two years has transformed health systems and battled economies across the globe. Much COVID-19-focused research and development innovation, alongside the persevering efforts of political leaders to safeguard and sustain economic progress, has been undertaken. Within the diverse community of ERIA Member States alone, a variety of measures have been tackled to survive through attempts to balance each nation&rsquo;s health and economy. A first of its kind, this regional conference answers requests heard through regional meetings for such a gathering, and offers EMSs the opportunity to share with neighbors what they have learned to be most effective for them, in order to more smoothly exit this pandemic as well as better prepare for upcoming ones.
Experts have thus been invited to present their government&rsquo;s best policy strategy/ies that have had the greatest impact on balancing economy and health under the COVID-19 pandemic. This year&rsquo;s ASEAN chair, Cambodia, will open, introducing the hard-hit populous and developing archipelagos of Indonesia and the Philippines, the peninsular Thailand, the ASEAN neighbor India with its population of over one billion, and the technologically advanced Japan in East Asia. Articles, Op-Eds, policy papers, and academic publications (commentaries) are expected to arise from the presentations.
Event Details

Date: Thursday, 19 May&nbsp; 2022
Time: 2 PM- 4 PM (Jakarta time, UTC+7)

Agenda




TIME (UTC+7)


AGENDA




&nbsp;14:00-14:05


&nbsp;Welcome Remarks:

Taizo Hara, Director-General of Research and Policy Design, ERIA





14:05-14:10


Opening Address:

Dr Songheang Ai, Director, Southeast Asian Ministers of Education Organization Regional Centre for Technical Education Development (SEAMEO TED)





&nbsp;14:10-14:50


Part 1: Managing ASEAN Member States&rsquo; Health and Economy during the Pandemic
Moderator:

Dr Antonio Villanueva, Senior Advisor on Healthcare Policy

Experts:

Prof Tjandra Yoga Aditama, former Director of Communicable Diseases at WHO SEARO, for Indonesia
Dr Maria Rosario Singh-Vergeire, Undersecretary of Health, the Philippines
Prof Prasit Watanapa, Dean, Faculty of Medicine Siriraj Hospital, Mahidol University, Bangkok, Thailand





14:50-15:00


Break




15:00-15:40


Part 2: Managing East Asia Summit States during the Pandemic
Moderator:

Ms Asuka Nagatani, Senior Policy Officer of Healthcare Unit

Experts:

Dr Vijay Murali, COVID-19 Task Force and Ministry of Health, India
Dr Norio Ohmagari, Head of COVID-19 Task Force and Director of Disease Control and Prevention Center, National Center for Global Health and Medicine, Tokyo, Japan
Dr Aladdin Rillo, Senior Economic Advisor, ERIA




15:40-15:55

Q&amp;A:

Ms Isabella Italia Gentajaya, Information and Communications, ERIA




15:55-16:00

&nbsp;Summary and Closing Remarks:

Dr Takuma Kato, Director of Healthcare Unit, ERIA

)DET OEMAES( tnempoleveD noitacudE lacinhceT rof ertneC lanoigeR noitazinagrO noitacudE fo sretsiniM naisA tsaehtuoS ,rotceriD ,iA gnaehgnoS rD

sliateD tnevE edarT lanoitanretnI ni serusaeM ffiraT-noN dna ffiraT :erutceL cilbuP aisenodnI satisrevinU edarT lanoitanretnI ni serusaeM ffiraT-noN dna ffiraT :erutceL cilbuP aisenodnI satisrevinU";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-04-11 09:07:03";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-04-11 09:58:44";s:11:"modified_by";s:1:"4";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:25:"catherin.safitri@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:20;O:8:"stdClass":48:{s:19:"article_category_id";s:5:"12483";s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6708";s:11:"category_id";s:3:"243";s:9:"short_des";N;s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:117:"unctad-eria-e-commerce-week-how-can-women-digital-entrepreneurs-boost-inclusion-peer-learning-dialogue-across-regions";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:120:"UNCTAD-ERIA E-commerce Week:  How Can Women Digital Entrepreneurs Boost Inclusion? Peer learning dialogue across regions";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-04-28";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"4";s:7:"content";s:3738:"<p><strong>The Thematic Session in Partnership with UNCTAD during E-commerce Week</strong></p><p>The digital transformation has created new opportunities for developing and emerging economies, allowing businesses to access global markets and increase their level of transactions. The COVID-19 pandemic has catalysed and accelerated the transition towards economic activity online. According to the <a href="https://unctad.org/system/files/official-document/dtlstict2020d13_en.pdf">Covid-19 and e-Commerce Global Review</a>, the share of e-commerce of global retail trade is estimated to have surged from 14 per cent in 2019 to about 17 per cent in 2020. However, in spite of the economic growth generated by the increased use of digital tools and technologies, important inequalities remain with and within countries. Some categories, such as women, are still excluded from large chunks of the digital economy. A situation that has worsened during the COVID-19 pandemic, which significantly impacted women, and slowed down years of economic and social progress. Calculations by the World Economic Forum revealed that the pandemic situation of the two last years has increased the global gender gap by 36 years, resulting today in a gender divide that is not expected to close for another 136 years.</p><p data-subtype="normal">Reducing the gender gap in the digital space will not only benefit women, but societies and economies as a whole. According to an <a href="https://pressroom.ifc.org/all/pages/PressDetail.aspx?ID=26366">International Finance Corporation report</a>&nbsp;issued in 2021, women could add over $14.5 billion to e-commerce markets in Africa alone and $280 billion in South-East Asia, between 2025 and 2030. Similarly, in Southeast Asia, <a href="/uploads/media/policy-brief/Women%E2%80%99s-Participation-in-the-Digital-Economy_1203.pdf">according to ERIA research</a>, a better inclusion of women in fast growing digital economies can have significant social and economic benefits, especially by providing access to entrepreneurship opportunity, STEM skills and careers and leadership position in the digital economy. By providing relevant support, stakeholders of the digital sector can help women tackle the challenges related to the gender digital divide and contribute to more inclusive economic growth, generating opportunities for everyone.&nbsp;This session is part of series of events highlighting the positive impact of more inclusive digital economies.</p><p data-subtype="normal">After a High-Level session dedicated to discussing how fostering more inclusive digital entrepreneurship can be a force for development, this session will pursue the discussion and gather different actors who, at their level, are taking concrete actions to address the gender digital divide and contribute to sustainable development. With the objective to facilitate cross-fertilization and peer learning across different regions, the session will enable the exchange of good practices among different stakeholders of the digital economy and encourage partnership-building at a regional and a global level, to help increase women&#039;s participation in the digital sector.</p><h2>Event Details</h2><ul><li>Date: Thursday, 28 April 2022</li><li>Time: 7 PM - 8 PM (Jakarta time, UTC+7)</li><li>RSVP :&nbsp;<a title="Click here to register" href="https://unctadeweek2022.pathable.co/meetings/virtual/2fkWEeGyLYo4Tar93" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">UNCTAD eCommerce Week: Virtual Meeting Details (pathable.co)</a></li></ul><p><a class="bluebtn" title="Click here to register" href="https://unctadeweek2022.pathable.co/meetings/virtual/2fkWEeGyLYo4Tar93" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Register Now</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:17:"Ms Lina Maulidina";s:16:"article_keywords";s:6:"UNCTAD";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-04-28";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:6743:"UNCTAD-ERIA E-commerce Week:  How Can Women Digital Entrepreneurs Boost Inclusion? Peer learning dialogue across regions UNCTAD-ERIA E-commerce Week:  How Can Women Digital Entrepreneurs Boost Inclusion? Peer learning dialogue across regions The Thematic Session in Partnership with UNCTAD during E-commerce Week
The digital transformation has created new opportunities for developing and emerging economies, allowing businesses to access global markets and increase their level of transactions. The COVID-19 pandemic has catalysed and accelerated the transition towards economic activity online. According to the Covid-19 and e-Commerce Global Review, the share of e-commerce of global retail trade is estimated to have surged from 14 per cent in 2019 to about 17 per cent in 2020. However, in spite of the economic growth generated by the increased use of digital tools and technologies, important inequalities remain with and within countries. Some categories, such as women, are still excluded from large chunks of the digital economy. A situation that has worsened during the COVID-19 pandemic, which significantly impacted women, and slowed down years of economic and social progress. Calculations by the World Economic Forum revealed that the pandemic situation of the two last years has increased the global gender gap by 36 years, resulting today in a gender divide that is not expected to close for another 136 years.
Reducing the gender gap in the digital space will not only benefit women, but societies and economies as a whole. According to an International Finance Corporation report&nbsp;issued in 2021, women could add over $14.5 billion to e-commerce markets in Africa alone and $280 billion in South-East Asia, between 2025 and 2030. Similarly, in Southeast Asia, according to ERIA research, a better inclusion of women in fast growing digital economies can have significant social and economic benefits, especially by providing access to entrepreneurship opportunity, STEM skills and careers and leadership position in the digital economy. By providing relevant support, stakeholders of the digital sector can help women tackle the challenges related to the gender digital divide and contribute to more inclusive economic growth, generating opportunities for everyone.&nbsp;This session is part of series of events highlighting the positive impact of more inclusive digital economies.
After a High-Level session dedicated to discussing how fostering more inclusive digital entrepreneurship can be a force for development, this session will pursue the discussion and gather different actors who, at their level, are taking concrete actions to address the gender digital divide and contribute to sustainable development. With the objective to facilitate cross-fertilization and peer learning across different regions, the session will enable the exchange of good practices among different stakeholders of the digital economy and encourage partnership-building at a regional and a global level, to help increase women's participation in the digital sector.
Event Details

Date: Thursday, 28 April 2022
Time: 7 PM - 8 PM (Jakarta time, UTC+7)
RSVP :&nbsp;UNCTAD eCommerce Week: Virtual Meeting Details (pathable.co)

Register Now       Virtual Room Ms Lina Maulidina lina.maulidina@eria.org UNCTAD  2022-04-28 0000-00-00 2022-04-28 28 April 2022 2202 lirpA 82 82-40-2202 00-00-0000 82-40-2202  DATCNU gro.aire@anidiluam.anil anidiluaM aniL sM mooR lautriV       woN retsigeR

)oc.elbahtap( sliateD gniteeM lautriV :keeW ecremmoCe DATCNU;psbn&: PVSR

.rotces latigid eht ni noitapicitrap s'nemow esaercni pleh ot ,level labolg a dna lanoiger a ta gnidliub-pihsrentrap egaruocne dna ymonoce latigid eht fo sredlohekats tnereffid gnoma secitcarp doog fo egnahcxe eht elbane lliw noisses eht ,snoiger tnereffid ssorca gninrael reep dna noitazilitref-ssorc etatilicaf ot evitcejbo eht htiW .tnempoleved elbaniatsus ot etubirtnoc dna edivid latigid redneg eht sserdda ot snoitca etercnoc gnikat era ,level rieht ta ,ohw srotca tnereffid rehtag dna noissucsid eht eusrup lliw noisses siht ,tnempoleved rof ecrof a eb nac pihsruenerpertne latigid evisulcni erom gniretsof woh gnissucsid ot detacided noisses leveL-hgiH a retfA
.seimonoce latigid evisulcni erom fo tcapmi evitisop eht gnithgilhgih stneve fo seires fo trap si noisses sihT;psbn&.enoyreve rof seitinutroppo gnitareneg ,htworg cimonoce evisulcni erom ot etubirtnoc dna edivid latigid redneg eht ot detaler segnellahc eht elkcat nemow pleh nac rotces latigid eht fo sredlohekats ,troppus tnaveler gnidivorp yB .ymonoce latigid eht ni noitisop pihsredael dna sreerac dna slliks METS ,ytinutroppo pihsruenerpertne ot ssecca gnidivorp yb yllaicepse ,stifeneb cimonoce dna laicos tnacifingis evah nac seimonoce latigid gniworg tsaf ni nemow fo noisulcni retteb a ,hcraeser AIRE ot gnidrocca ,aisA tsaehtuoS ni ,ylralimiS .0302 dna 5202 neewteb ,aisA tsaE-htuoS ni noillib 082$ dna enola acirfA ni stekram ecremmoc-e ot noillib 5.41$ revo dda dluoc nemow ,1202 ni deussi;psbn&troper noitaroproC ecnaniF lanoitanretnI na ot gnidroccA .elohw a sa seimonoce dna seiteicos tub ,nemow tifeneb ylno ton lliw ecaps latigid eht ni pag redneg eht gnicudeR
.sraey 631 rehtona rof esolc ot detcepxe ton si taht edivid redneg a ni yadot gnitluser ,sraey 63 yb pag redneg labolg eht desaercni sah sraey tsal owt eht fo noitautis cimednap eht taht delaever muroF cimonocE dlroW eht yb snoitaluclaC .ssergorp laicos dna cimonoce fo sraey nwod dewols dna ,nemow detcapmi yltnacifingis hcihw ,cimednap 91-DIVOC eht gnirud denesrow sah taht noitautis A .ymonoce latigid eht fo sknuhc egral morf dedulcxe llits era ,nemow sa hcus ,seirogetac emoS .seirtnuoc nihtiw dna htiw niamer seitilauqeni tnatropmi ,seigolonhcet dna sloot latigid fo esu desaercni eht yb detareneg htworg cimonoce eht fo etips ni ,revewoH .0202 ni tnec rep 71 tuoba ot 9102 ni tnec rep 41 morf degrus evah ot detamitse si edart liater labolg fo ecremmoc-e fo erahs eht ,weiveR labolG ecremmoC-e dna 91-divoC eht ot gnidroccA .enilno ytivitca cimonoce sdrawot noitisnart eht detarelecca dna desylatac sah cimednap 91-DIVOC ehT .snoitcasnart fo level rieht esaercni dna stekram labolg ssecca ot sessenisub gniwolla ,seimonoce gnigreme dna gnipoleved rof seitinutroppo wen detaerc sah noitamrofsnart latigid ehT
keeW ecremmoc-E gnirud DATCNU htiw pihsrentraP ni noisseS citamehT ehT snoiger ssorca eugolaid gninrael reeP ?noisulcnI tsooB sruenerpertnE latigiD nemoW naC woH  :keeW ecremmoc-E AIRE-DATCNU snoiger ssorca eugolaid gninrael reeP ?noisulcnI tsooB sruenerpertnE latigiD nemoW naC woH  :keeW ecremmoc-E AIRE-DATCNU";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2022-04-07 17:44:03";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2022-04-12 11:25:21";s:11:"modified_by";s:1:"4";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:23:"lina.maulidina@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";N;s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:21;O:8:"stdClass":48:{s:19:"article_category_id";s:5:"12545";s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6707";s:11:"category_id";s:3:"243";s:9:"short_des";N;s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:68:"asean-economic-outlook-prospects-for-growth-and-regional-cooperation";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:69:"ASEAN Economic Outlook: Prospects for Growth and Regional Cooperation";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2022-04-28";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2022";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"4";s:7:"content";s:6509:"<div data-lineheight="1.5"><img src="/uploads/media/Events/2022_April_ADB-Refinitiv-ERIA-webinar-banner.png" alt="" width="800" height="450" /></div><div data-lineheight="1.5">&nbsp;</div><div data-lineheight="1.5">After a challenging couple of years, there are signs that Southeast Asia is rising from the pandemic. In 2021, output growth in the region rebounded to 2.9% with projections to further strengthen to 4.9% in 2022 as the region continues to recover, helped by high vaccination rates and a sustained global economic recovery.</div><div data-lineheight="1.5">&nbsp;</div><div data-lineheight="1.5">However, global headwinds will continue to make policymaking difficult. The long term effects of the pandemic continue to disrupt global trade and supply chains and place stress on the labor supply through prolonged unemployment and the potential of new more transmissible COVID-19 variants emerging. On top of this, recent geopolitical events have raised inflation in the region through elevated oil, commodity and food prices that could impact consumption, exchange rates, and the current account balance in the region. In addition, the recent increase in the federal funds rate is another challenge that in the short run will raise the cost of borrowing for economies that need to continue priority spending to support the poor and vulnerable.</div><div data-lineheight="1.5">&nbsp;</div><div data-lineheight="1.5">As we look to the future, there is still hope for optimism in the region that may counterbalance the challenges. A focus on building partnerships to invest in green infrastructure, reduce carbon emission, and improve the sustainability and conservation of the region&rsquo;s oceans, water bodies, and marine ecosystems offer prospects for growth. Join this webinar to discover the prospects for growth in Southeast Asia, and the importance of trade and financial integration.&nbsp;</div><div data-lineheight="1.5">&nbsp;</div><div data-lineheight="1.5"><strong>During the webinar, our speakers will discuss:</strong></div><div data-lineheight="1.5">&nbsp;</div><ul><li data-lineheight="1.5"><strong>Economic outlook for the region</strong></li><li data-lineheight="1.5"><strong>The role of trade, trade disruptions, and trade agreements</strong></li><li data-lineheight="1.5"><strong>Financial connectedness &amp; financial integration</strong></li><li data-lineheight="1.5"><strong>Challenges facing central banks in the region&nbsp;</strong></li></ul><h2 data-lineheight="2.0">Event info</h2><div data-lineheight="2.0"><strong>Date:&nbsp;&nbsp;</strong>Thursday, 28 April 2022</div><div data-lineheight="2.0"><strong>Time: </strong>3 PM&nbsp;SGT (UTC+8)/ 2 PM Jakarta time (90 minutes)</div><div data-lineheight="2.0">RSVP: <a title="Click here to register" href="https://solutions.refinitiv.com/ASEANEconomicsWebinar2022?utm_campaign=618600_ADBWebinarQ2&amp;elqCampaignId=17775&amp;utm_source=ERIA&amp;utm_medium=Email&amp;utm_content=&amp;utm_term=" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Register at Refinitiv&#039;s website</a></div><div data-lineheight="2.0">&nbsp;</div><div data-lineheight="2.0"><h2 data-lineheight="1.5">Agenda</h2><div>Singapore time, UTC+8</div><div data-lineheight="1.5"><strong>3 PM&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Welcome &amp; Scene Setting by Refinitiv, an LSEG Business</strong></div><div data-lineheight="1.5"><strong>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;</strong>Nikita Puri, Investment Solutions Specialist, Refinitiv, an LSEG Business</div><div data-lineheight="1.5">&nbsp;</div><div data-lineheight="1.5"><strong>3:10 PM&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Opening Remarks by ADB</strong></div><div data-lineheight="1.5"><strong>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; </strong>Winfried Wicklein, Deputy Director General, Southeast Asia Department, ADB&nbsp;</div><div data-lineheight="1.5">&nbsp;</div><div data-lineheight="1.5"><strong>3:15&nbsp;PM&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Keynote Presentation: ADO 2022 Launch</strong></div><div data-lineheight="1.5"><strong>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; </strong>Henry Ma, Senior Country Economist, Indonesia Resident Mission, Asian Development Bank</div><div data-lineheight="1.5">&nbsp;</div><div data-lineheight="1.5"><strong>3:30 PM&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Panel Discussion:&nbsp;Prospects for Growth and Regional Cooperation Webinar</strong></div><div data-lineheight="1.5">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;- Moderator: Nikita Puri, Investment Solutions Specialist, Refinitiv, an LSEG Business</div><div data-lineheight="1.5">&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; -&nbsp;Anita Prakash, Senior Policy Advisor for International Economic Cooperation, ERIA&nbsp;</div><div data-lineheight="1.5"><strong>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; </strong>&nbsp; - Zeno Abenoja, Managing Director, Department of Economic Research, Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas</div><div data-lineheight="1.5">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;- Andrea Goldstein, Head of the Indonesia Desk, OECD</div><div data-lineheight="1.5"><p>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; - Anthony Tan, Deputy Group Head and Senior Economist, ASEAN+3 Macroeconomic Research Office (AMRO)</p></div><div data-lineheight="1.5">&nbsp;</div><div data-lineheight="1.5"><strong>4:15 PM&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Q&amp;A</strong></div><div data-lineheight="1.5">&nbsp;</div><div data-lineheight="1.5"><strong>4:25 PM&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Closing Remarks by ERIA</strong></div><div data-lineheight="1.5"><strong>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; </strong>Tiat Jin (TJ) OOI, Lead Consultant, E-S-I Knowledge Lab, ERIA&nbsp;</div><div data-lineheight="1.5">&nbsp;</div><div data-lineheight="1.5"><strong>4:30 PM&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;Event Close</strong></div></div><div data-lineheight="2.0">&nbsp;</div><div data-lineheight="2.0"><a class="bluebtn" title="Click here to register" href="https://solutions.refinitiv.com/ASEANEconomicsWebinar2022?utm_campaign=618600_ADBWebinarQ2&amp;elqCampaignId=17775&amp;utm_source=ERIA&amp;utm_medium=Email&amp;utm_content=&amp;utm_term=" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Register Now</a></div>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:17:"Ms Amelia Litania";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:27:"ERIA, ADB, SEADS, Refinitiv";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2022-04-28";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:8753:"ASEAN Economic Outlook: Prospects for Growth and Regional Cooperation ASEAN Economic Outlook: Prospects for Growth and Regional Cooperation &nbsp;
After a challenging couple of years, there are signs that Southeast Asia is rising from the pandemic. In 2021, output growth in the region rebounded to 2.9% with projections to further strengthen to 4.9% in 2022 as the region continues to recover, helped by high vaccination rates and a sustained global economic recovery.
&nbsp;
However, global headwinds will continue to make policymaking difficult. The long term effects of the pandemic continue to disrupt global trade and supply chains and place stress on the labor supply through prolonged unemployment and the potential of new more transmissible COVID-19 variants emerging. On top of this, recent geopolitical events have raised inflation in the region through elevated oil, commodity and food prices that could impact consumption, exchange rates, and the current account balance in the region. In addition, the recent increase in the federal funds rate is another challenge that in the short run will raise the cost of borrowing for economies that need to continue priority spending to support the poor and vulnerable.
&nbsp;
As we look to the future, there is still hope for optimism in the region that may counterbalance the challenges. A focus on building partnerships to invest in green infrastructure, reduce carbon emission, and improve the sustainability and conservation of the region&rsquo;s oceans, water bodies, and marine ecosystems offer prospects for growth. Join this webinar to discover the prospects for growth in Southeast Asia, and the importance of trade and financial integration.&nbsp;
&nbsp;
During the webinar, our speakers will discuss:
&nbsp;

Economic outlook for the region
The role of trade, trade disruptions, and trade agreements
Financial connectedness &amp; financial integration
Challenges facing central banks in the region&nbsp;

Event info
Date:&nbsp;&nbsp;Thursday, 28 April 2022
Time: 3 PM&nbsp;SGT (UTC+8)/ 2 PM Jakarta time (90 minutes)
RSVP: Register at Refinitiv's website
&nbsp;
