.ygolonhcet SUCC tuoba seussi dna saedi egnahcxE


.noiger NAESA ot seigolonhcet SUCC maertsniam fo noitacilppa fo noitaredisnoc rehtruf etareleccA


.noisses erutcel hguorht ygolonhcet SUCC tsetal eht no gnirahs egdelwonk eht etomorP


.swollof sa era spohskrow lacinhcet SUCC eht fo slaog ehT
.srerutcel hcton pot yb seiduts esac laer hguorht SUCC fo dnert tnerruc eht dna seigolonhcet tsetal tuoba egdelwonk llitsni ot ytinutroppo na sa evres ot smia NCA yb detsoh pohskrow sihT .1202 rebotcO eht ni SUCC tuoba pohskrow lacinhcet lautriv a ezinagro lliw )NCA( krowteN SUCC aisA eht ,evoba debircsed sa muroF krowteN SUCC aisA ts1 eht fo emoctuo eht nopu gnidliuB
.noiger naisA dna NAESA eht tsgnoma gnirahs ecneirepxe dna egdelwonk tnemelpmi ot dna pag eht egdirb ot deen a si ereht ,noiger NAESA ni SUCC fo tnemyolped eht etarelecca ot redro ni taht detcepxe si ti ,revoeroM .devloser eb ot deen stcejorp tolip hguorht krowemarf lacinhcet a dna ytilibail sserdda ot krowemarf lagel etauqeda na fo kcal eht sa hcus ,seussi ,egats noitazilaicremmoc ot stcejorp SUCC erom gnirb ot redro ni taht ,muroF eht ni detapicitrap taht sredlohekats eht yb dessucsid osla saw tI .erutuf eht ni snrecnoc ytiruces ygrene dna etamilc tsdima ytilartuen nobrac eveihca ot noiger NAESA eht rof seigolonhcet laicurc era gnilcyceR nobraC dna SUCC taht dedulcnoc saw ti ,1202 enuJ 32-22 no dleh muroF krowteN SUCC aisA ts1 eht tA
.noitavonni dna hcraeser fo noitaroballoc hguorht tnemyolped sti dna ygolonhcet SUCC fo tsoc eht rewol ot ytilibapac ;ouqsr&seirtnuoc dliub ot pleh yllautneve lliw taht pihsrentrap ygolonhcet noissime wol eht no etaroballoc dna krow ot noiger eht ni seirtnuoc rof seitinutroppo sedivorp krowteN SUCC aisA ehT .SUCC no pag egdelwonk eht egdirb ot spohskrow gniniart gnidliub yticapac gnidloh )iii( dna ;noiger SAE eht ni SUCC fo sdradnats lagel dna ,lacimonoce ,lacinhcet no seiduts hcraeser gnitcudnoc )ii( ;sgniteem dna ,spohskrow ,secnerefnoc ,murof launna na gnidloh hguorht gnirahs egdelwonk gnitomorp )i( :hguorht SUCC fo tnemyolped etatilicaf ot si krowten siht fo noissim ehT .SUCC fo tnemyolped dna tnempoleved no noitarepooc dna noitaroballoc hguorht aisA ni snoissime fo noitasinobraced eht ot etubirtnoc ot smia taht krowteN SUCC aisA eht fo noisiv eht erahs ot etapicitrap ot noitnetni rieht desserpxe evah srebmem krowteN ehT .noiger naisA eht tuohguorht tnempoleved SUCC fo noisiv eht erahs taht snoitutitsni hcraeser dna laicnanif ,seinapmoc ,snoitasinagro lanoitanretni 001 naht erom dna )napaJ dna ,ailartsuA ,setatS detinU eht ,seirtnuoc rebmem NAESA lla( Digital transformation and global connectivity have enabled entrepreneurs to be as borderless as their ideas can take them. Yet, the current pandemic has thrown to light both the pros and cons of such ecosystems. Borderless entrepreneurship &ndash; is that truly the future and way forward? </span></p><p data-key="43" data-slate-fragment=""><span data-key="44">Join us as we converse with speakers from 4 countries of diverse backgrounds. Let their perspectives challenge your paradigm and status quo!</span></p><p><strong>Date and Time:</strong></p><p>Tuesday, 31 August 2021, 2:00&nbsp;PM to 3:15 PM (UTC+7; Jakarta, Indonesia time)</p><p><strong>Location:</strong></p><p>Online (link to the meeting room to be provided after registration)</p><p><strong>Welcome Remark:</strong></p><ul><li>Giulia Ajmone Marsan, Director of Strategy and Partnership, ERIA</li></ul><p><strong>Speakers:</strong></p><ul><li>Laurent Tam Nguyen,&nbsp;Co-Founder and General Manager Digital Mekong, Vietnam</li><li>Haewon Rah,&nbsp;Engagement Manager Techstars, Korea</li><li>Jirut Wattoom,&nbsp;Technology Strategy Manager, Chemicals Business, SCG Partner SPRINT Accelerator, Thailand</li><li>Wisnu Nugrahadi,&nbsp;CEO and Co-Founder Sampingan, Indonesia</li></ul><p><a class="bluebtn" href="/uploads/media/ESI-7%20Agenda%20final.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">PROGRAMME AGENDA&nbsp;</a></p><p><a class="bluebtn" href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/borderless-entrepreneurship-is-that-the-future-tickets-167694888927" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">REGISTER NOW&nbsp;</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:17:"Ms Lina Maulidina";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2021-08-31";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2021-08-31";s:8:"keywords";s:3091:"E-S-I Episode 7 Borderless Entrepreneurship â€“ Is that the Future? E-S-I Episode 7 Borderless Entrepreneurship â€“ Is that the Future? ERIA Webinar Series #7 - 'Entrepreneurship, Start-Ups and Innovation (E-S-I) in ASEAN and East Asia for The Post-Pandemic Recovery'
Entrepreneurship has increasingly been unbounded by distance, geography and time zones. Digital transformation and global connectivity have enabled entrepreneurs to be as borderless as their ideas can take them. Yet, the current pandemic has thrown to light both the pros and cons of such ecosystems. Borderless entrepreneurship &ndash; is that truly the future and way forward? 
Join us as we converse with speakers from 4 countries of diverse backgrounds. Let their perspectives challenge your paradigm and status quo!
Date and Time:
Tuesday, 31 August 2021, 2:00&nbsp;PM to 3:15 PM (UTC+7; Jakarta, Indonesia time)
Location:
Online (link to the meeting room to be provided after registration)
Welcome Remark:

Giulia Ajmone Marsan, Director of Strategy and Partnership, ERIA

Speakers:

Laurent Tam Nguyen,&nbsp;Co-Founder and General Manager Digital Mekong, Vietnam
Haewon Rah,&nbsp;Engagement Manager Techstars, Korea
Jirut Wattoom,&nbsp;Technology Strategy Manager, Chemicals Business, SCG Partner SPRINT Accelerator, Thailand
Wisnu Nugrahadi,&nbsp;CEO and Co-Founder Sampingan, Indonesia

PROGRAMME AGENDA&nbsp;

In Singapore alone, there are reportedly more than 500 accelerators, incubators, and investors.</p><p>Has the pandemic dampened the importance of incubators and accelerators? Or are we looking at them becoming even more critical in shaping the future of E-S-I ecosystems? Join us, as we engage our regional experts to glean from their shared knowledge and perspectives.</p><p><strong>Date and Time:</strong></p><p>Thursday, 22 July 2021, 2:00&nbsp;PM to 3:15 PM (UTC+7; Jakarta, Indonesia time)</p><p><strong>Location:</strong></p><p>Online (link to the meeting room to be provided after registration)</p><p><strong>Welcome Remark:</strong></p><ul><li>Giulia Ajmone Marsan, Director of Strategy and Partnership, ERIA</li></ul><p><strong>Speakers:</strong></p><ul><li>Brian Koh, Director of NUS&nbsp; Enterprise, Singapore</li><li>Jayne Chan, Head of StartmeupHK, Invest HK, Hong Kong</li><li>Siah Hwee Ang, Professor of International Business and Strategy Chair in Business in Asia, Victoria University of Wellington, New Zealand</li><li>Cheryl Ng, Startup Ecosystem Support Consultant, UNDP, Cambodia&nbsp;</li></ul><p><a class="bluebtn" title="PROGRAMME AGENDA&nbsp;" href="/uploads/media/Events/2021-Agenda-ESI-Webinar-Episode-6.pdf" target="_blank" Australia.</p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Maulidina";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2021-07-22";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2021-07-22";s:8:"keywords";s:3897:"E-S-I Eps #6 Of Incubators and Accelerators â€“ Shaping the Future of E-S-I E-S-I Eps #6 Of Incubators and Accelerators â€“ Shaping the Future of E-S-I The tech boom and governmental push towards Industry 4.0 and digital transformation have led to an explosion of incubators and accelerators across ASEAN and East Asia over the past decade. In Singapore alone, there are reportedly more than 500 accelerators, incubators, and investors.
Has the pandemic dampened the importance of incubators and accelerators? Or are we looking at them becoming even more critical in shaping the future of E-S-I ecosystems? Join us, as we engage our regional experts to glean from their shared knowledge and perspectives.
Date and Time:
Thursday, 22 July 2021, 2:00&nbsp;PM to 3:15 PM (UTC+7; Jakarta, Indonesia time)
Location:
Online (link to the meeting room to be provided after registration)
Welcome Remark:

Giulia Ajmone Marsan, Director of Strategy and Partnership, ERIA

Speakers:

Brian Koh, Director of NUS&nbsp; Enterprise, Singapore
Jayne Chan, Head of StartmeupHK, Invest HK, Hong Kong
Siah Hwee Ang, Professor of International Business and Strategy Chair in Business in Asia, Victoria University of Wellington, New Zealand
Cheryl Ng, Startup Ecosystem Support Consultant, UNDP, Cambodia&nbsp;

PROGRAMME AGENDA&nbsp;
News and Event Materials&nbsp;

Mr Brian Koh, Director of NUS Enterprise

Ms Jayne Chan, Head of StartmeUp HK

Mr Siah Hwee Ang, Professor of International Business and Strategy Chair in Business in Asia, Victoria University of Wellington, NZ, and Director of the Centre of Asia-Pacific Excellence (CAPEs)

Ms Cheryl Ng, UNDP Cambodia Startup Ecosystem Consultant

ERIA&rsquo;s E-S-I webinar series is organised under ERIA&rsquo;s Strategy and Partnership Programme, funded by Australia. .srotsevni dna ,srotabucni ,srotarelecca 005 naht erom yldetroper era ereht ,enola eropagniS nI .edaced tsap eht revo aisA tsaE dna NAESA ssorca srotarelecca dna srotabucni fo noisolpxe na ot del evah noitamrofsnart latigid dna 0.4 yrtsudnI sdrawot hsup latnemnrevog dna moob hcet ehT I-S-E fo erutuF eht gnipahS “€â srotareleccA dna srotabucnI fO 6# spE I-S-E I-S-E fo erutuF eht gnipahS “€â srotareleccA dna srotabucnI fO 6# spE I-S-E";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2021-07-12 13:41:33";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2021-08-24 15:51:20";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"13";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:23:"lina.maulidina@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";s:0:"";s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:46;O:8:"stdClass":48:{s:19:"article_category_id";s:5:"10570";s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6300";s:11:"category_id";s:3:"243";s:9:"short_des";N;s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:72:"how-will-east-asias-digital-transformation-change-the-global-value-chain";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:74:"How will East Asia's Digital Transformation Change the Global Value Chain?";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2021-07-01";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2021";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"7";s:7:"content";s:1457:"<p>The wave of digital transformation is sweeping over the emerging economies of the East Asia region, transforming industries and societies in the member states of ASEAN at an even faster pace than in developed countries. At the same time,&nbsp; the US-China confrontation is fragmenting the global economy. What is going to happen next? How do we cope with these changes?<br /> <br /> In this seminar, global supply chain experts from Southeast&nbsp; Asia and Europe will give us a bird&#039;s eye view of what is happening in East Asia&#039;s digital transformation and how this may impact global trade. Dr. Luron Chen, an expert on the regional economy from Jakarta, will provide a perspective from ASEAN, and Dr. Satoshi Inomata from Paris will discuss the shape of global value chains under Industry 4.0</p><p><strong>Date and Time:</strong></p><ul><li>Thursday, 1 July, 10:15-11:25 (UTC+7) / 12:15-13:25 (UTC+9)</li></ul><p><strong>Welcome Remark:</strong></p><ul><li>Watanabe Tetsuya, Vice President, RIETI</li></ul><p><strong>Moderator:</strong></p><ul><li>Ota Yasu, Columnist, Nikkei</li></ul><p><strong>Speakers:</strong></p><ul><li><p>Lurong Chen,&nbsp;Senior Economist, ERIA</p></li><li><p>Inomata Satoshi,&nbsp;Senior Overseas Research Fellow, Institute of Developing Economies, JETRO</p></li></ul><p><a class="bluebtn" href="https://www.rieti.go.jp/en/events/21070101/info.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">REGISTER HERE</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:18:"Ms Isabella Italia";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:12:"RIETI - ERIA";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2021-07-01";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"0000-00-00";s:8:"keywords";s:2843:"How will East Asia's Digital Transformation Change the Global Value Chain? How will East Asia's Digital Transformation Change the Global Value Chain? The wave of digital transformation is sweeping over the emerging economies of the East Asia region, transforming industries and societies in the member states of ASEAN at an even faster pace than in developed countries. At the same time,&nbsp; the US-China confrontation is fragmenting the global economy. What is going to happen next? How do we cope with these changes?  In this seminar, global supply chain experts from Southeast&nbsp; Asia and Europe will give us a bird's eye view of what is happening in East Asia's digital transformation and how this may impact global trade. Dr. Luron Chen, an expert on the regional economy from Jakarta, will provide a perspective from ASEAN, and Dr. Satoshi Inomata from Paris will discuss the shape of global value chains under Industry 4.0
Date and Time:

Thursday, 1 July, 10:15-11:25 (UTC+7) / 12:15-13:25 (UTC+9)

Welcome Remark:

Watanabe Tetsuya, Vice President, RIETI

Moderator:

Ota Yasu, Columnist, Nikkei

Speakers:


Lurong Chen,&nbsp;Senior Economist, ERIA


Inomata Satoshi,&nbsp;Senior Overseas Research Fellow, Institute of Developing Economies, JETRO

woH";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2021-06-21 15:36:15";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2021-06-21 15:54:50";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"13";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:24:"isabella.italia@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";s:0:"";s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:47;O:8:"stdClass":48:{s:19:"article_category_id";s:5:"10771";s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6296";s:11:"category_id";s:3:"243";s:9:"short_des";N;s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:71:"eria--ciieco-online-roundtable-on-incubators-as-catalysts-of-innovation";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:72:"ERIA- CIIE.CO Online Roundtable on Incubators as Catalysts of Innovation";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2021-06-30";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2021";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"6";s:7:"content";s:2087:"<p><strong><img src="/uploads/media/Flyer.jpg" width="800" height="400" /></strong></p><p><strong>ERIA-CIIE.CO Webinar Series -&nbsp;</strong><strong>Building Prolific Entrepreneurship Ecosystems in ASEAN</strong><strong> with </strong><strong>Insights from India&nbsp;</strong><strong>Episode #1: Incubators as Catalysts of Innovation</strong></p><p>This online roundtable is conducted by CIIE.CO and ERIA. The goal is to open collaboration and peer learning between India and ASEAN as well as to share knowledge and relevant tools of entrepreneurship ecosystems in the South Asian region.</p><p>With this first of the series roundtable focusing on incubators, we aim to introduce the Indian innovation ecosystem and share relevant experiences for and from ASEAN, from the lens of startups as well as policy. Join us to learn together on the developments in the innovation ecosystem and its major milestones.</p><p><strong>Date and Time:</strong></p><p>Wednesday, 30 June 2021,&nbsp;2:30 - 4:00 pm, IST / 4:00 - 5:30 pm, WIB</p><p><strong>Location:</strong></p><p>Online (link to the meeting room to be provided after registration)</p><p><strong>Welcome Remark:</strong></p><ul><li>Giulia Ajmone Marsan, Director of Strategy and Partnership, ERIA</li></ul><p><strong>Speakers:</strong></p><ul><li>Chintan Bakshi, Partner - Incubation, CIIE.CO, India&nbsp;</li><li>Mudit Narain, Technology Officer, Office of the Principal Scientific Adviser to the Government of India&nbsp;</li><li>Michelle Ng, Senior Associate, Quest Ventures, Singapore</li><li>Mel Nava, CEO, 1 Export, Philippines&nbsp;</li><li><p>Chintan Vaishnav,&nbsp;Mission Director, Atal Innovation Mission, India</p></li></ul><p><a class="bluebtn" href="/uploads/media/ConceptNote2106_2.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">AGENDA</a></p><p><a class="bluebtn" href="/uploads/media/ConceptNote2506.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">CONCEPT NOTE</a></p><h2>Relive the Webinar</h2><p><iframe src="//www.youtube.com/embed/wZamqaep6PM" width="560" height="314" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:17:"Ms Lina Maulidina";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2021-06-30";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2021-06-30";s:8:"keywords";s:3285:"ERIA- CIIE.CO Online Roundtable on Incubators as Catalysts of Innovation ERIA- CIIE.CO Online Roundtable on Incubators as Catalysts of Innovation ERIA-CIIE.CO Webinar Series -&nbsp;Building Prolific Entrepreneurship Ecosystems in ASEAN with Insights from India&nbsp;Episode #1: Incubators as Catalysts of Innovation
This online roundtable is conducted by CIIE.CO and ERIA. The goal is to open collaboration and peer learning between India and ASEAN as well as to share knowledge and relevant tools of entrepreneurship ecosystems in the South Asian region.
With this first of the series roundtable focusing on incubators, we aim to introduce the Indian innovation ecosystem and share relevant experiences for and from ASEAN, from the lens of startups as well as policy. Join us to learn together on the developments in the innovation ecosystem and its major milestones.
Date and Time:
Wednesday, 30 June 2021,&nbsp;2:30 - 4:00 pm, IST / 4:00 - 5:30 pm, WIB
Location:
Online (link to the meeting room to be provided after registration)
Welcome Remark:

Giulia Ajmone Marsan, Director of Strategy and Partnership, ERIA

Speakers:

Chintan Bakshi, Partner - Incubation, CIIE.CO, India&nbsp;
Mudit Narain, Technology Officer, Office of the Principal Scientific Adviser to the Government of India&nbsp;
Michelle Ng, Senior Associate, Quest Ventures, Singapore
Mel Nava, CEO, 1 Export, Philippines&nbsp;

Chintan Vaishnav,&nbsp;Mission Director, Atal Innovation Mission, India


AGENDA
CONCEPT NOTE

font-size: 14px;">The OECD together with the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) is pleased to invite you to join the 14<sup>th</sup>&nbsp;of a series of webinars with prominent international experts.&nbsp;</span></p><p class="xmsonormal"><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular; font-size: 14px;">In a 45-minute event (including Q&amp;A), we will discuss with Eric about innovative approaches to higher education, new goals, and innovative skills bundles.</span></p><p class="xmsonormal"><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular; font-size: 14px;">This meeting will be held in English.</span></p><h2>About the Speaker&nbsp;</h2><p><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular; font-size: 14px;"><em>Rejected by Princeton for its Ph.D. program, Eric Sim, CFA, was devastated that he couldn&#039;t embark on an academic career. After 20 years in banking, he founded the <a href="https://eur02.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.iol.life%2F&amp;data=04%7C01%7CRaffaele.TRAPASSO%40oecd.org%7C1f94d65f83f043d0ad7f08d91ff15195%7Cac41c7d41f61460db0f4fc925a2b471c%7C0%7C1%7C637575943601436964%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C0&amp;sdata=Ro%2Fdpbbl44UZGSUZ2qxY55uvz1kIY78C8rzzFK%2FSqjo%3D&amp;reserved=0"><strong>Institute of Life (IOL)</strong></a>, whose mission is to train young professionals to become successful at work and in life.&nbsp;</em></span></p><p class="xmsonormal"><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular; font-size: 14px;"><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular;"><em>Previously, when based in Hong Kong, Mr Sim served as a managing director at UBS Investment Bank and as an Adjunct Associate Professor of Finance at Hong Kong University of Science and Technology. Currently based in Singapore, he writes about career and life skills for his 2 million followers on LinkedIn. More about Mr Sim: <a href="https://eur02.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Fin%2Fsimeric%2F&amp;data=04%7C01%7CRaffaele.TRAPASSO%40oecd.org%7C1f94d65f83f043d0ad7f08d91ff15195%7Cac41c7d41f61460db0f4fc925a2b471c%7C0%7C1%7C637575943601436964%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C0&amp;sdata=H%2BTtM1GutCKixHj3HIhyzc4HN0rzA7EQwlZd8cBMgbA%3D&amp;reserved=0">https://www.linkedin.com/in/simeric/</a></em>&nbsp;</span></span></p><h2>Date and Time&nbsp;</h2><p><span style="font-family: sf_compact_textregular; font-size: 14px;">Wednesday, 16 June 2021, 12.00 CEST&nbsp;</span></p><p><a class="bluebtn" title="REGISTER NOW&nbsp;" href="https://meetoecd1.zoom.us/meeting/register/tJUkdemprDMiHdGu35pz8ywrhUu4-DtCZcK2" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">REGISTER NOW&nbsp;</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:17:"Ms Sheila Fathiya";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2021-06-16";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2021-06-16";s:8:"keywords";s:2723:"OECD-ERIA GoHE in Conversation with Eric Sim OECD-ERIA GoHE in Conversation with Eric Sim The OECD together with the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) is pleased to invite you to join the 14th&nbsp;of a series of webinars with prominent international experts.&nbsp;
In a 45-minute event (including Q&amp;A), we will discuss with Eric about innovative approaches to higher education, new goals, and innovative skills bundles.
This meeting will be held in English.
About the Speaker&nbsp;
Rejected by Princeton for its Ph.D. program, Eric Sim, CFA, was devastated that he couldn't embark on an academic career. After 20 years in banking, he founded the Institute of Life (IOL), whose mission is to train young professionals to become successful at work and in life.&nbsp;
Previously, when based in Hong Kong, Mr Sim served as a managing director at UBS Investment Bank and as an Adjunct Associate Professor of Finance at Hong Kong University of Science and Technology. Currently based in Singapore, he writes about career and life skills for his 2 million followers on LinkedIn. More about Mr Sim: https://www.linkedin.com/in/simeric/&nbsp;
Date and Time&nbsp;
Wednesday, 16 June 2021, 12.00 CEST&nbsp;
REGISTER NOW&nbsp;       Virtual Room Ms Sheila Fathiya sheila.fathiya@eria.org   2021-06-16 2021-06-16 2021-06-16 16 June 2021 1202 enuJ 61 61-60-1202 61-60-1202 61-60-1202   gro.aire@ayihtaf.aliehs ayihtaF aliehS sM mooR lautriV       ;psbn&WON RETSIGER
;psbn&TSEC 00.21 ,1202 enuJ 61 ,yadsendeW
;psbn&emiT dna etaD

Whilst there were historically barriers between public and private organisations, the modus operandi in this digitally transformed era is &ldquo;Tripartite Partnerships&rdquo; &ndash; where collaborations between public, private and people become integral and crucial ingredients for success.</p><p>Come join us as we explore this topic of growing importance, not just within the developed countries, but more so, the developing nations. We share candidly on what has worked and also what more needs to be done to foster such critical partnerships for success.</p><p><strong>Date and Time:</strong></p><p>Thursday, 24 June 2021, 2:00&nbsp;PM to 3:15 PM (UTC+7; Jakarta, Indonesia time)</p><p><strong>Location:</strong></p><p>Online (link to the meeting room to be provided after registration)</p><p><strong>Welcome Remark:</strong></p><ul><li>Giulia Ajmone Marsan, Director of Strategy and Partnership, ERIA</li></ul><p><strong>Speakers:</strong></p><ul><li><p>Shanti Jagannathan, Principal Education Specialist, Asian Development Bank (ADB)</p></li><li><p>Dhabit Firdaus, CEO and Founder, BP Media, Brunei Darussalam</p></li><li><p>Kris R. Villanueva Libunao, Executive Director and Chief Sustainability Officer SmartCT (SmartCitiesPH,Inc.) Philippines</p></li><li><p>Dwina M. Putri, Co-Founder and COO, MauBelajarApa, Indonesia</p></li></ul><p><a class="bluebtn" href="/uploads/media/Agenda%20ESI%20Webinar%20Episode%205.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Programme Agenda&nbsp;</a></p><p><a class="bluebtn" href="/news-and-views/public-private-and-people-partnerships-are-critical-for-the-success-of-innovation-eco-systems-the-eria-e-s-i-5/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">News and Event Materials</a></p><h2>Relive the Webinar</h2><p><iframe src="//www.youtube.com/embed/MSgKuwSl5as" width="560" height="314" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe></p><h2>Shanti Jagannathan, Principal Education Specialist, Asian Development Bank (ADB)</h2><p><iframe src="//www.youtube.com/embed/2lqwRqDb9kY" width="560" height="314" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe></p><h2><strong></strong>Dhabit Firdaus, CEO and Founder, BP Media, Brunei Darussalam</h2><p><iframe src="//www.youtube.com/embed/wlCJaMs3PNE" width="560" height="314" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe></p><h2>Kris R. Philippines</h2><p><iframe src="//www.youtube.com/embed/nE9mketYGQo" width="560" height="314" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe></p><h2>Dwina M. Putri, Co-Founder and COO, MauBelajarApa, Indonesia</h2><p><iframe src="//www.youtube.com/embed/heUcf7k-PlM" width="560" height="314" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe></p><p>ERIA&rsquo;s E-S-I webinar series is funded by Australia, through ERIA Strategy and Partnership programme.</p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:17:"Ms Lina Maulidina";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2021-06-24";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2021-06-24";s:8:"keywords";s:4373:"E-S-I Eps #5  Critical Partnerships for Success - Public, Private, and People E-S-I Eps #5  Critical Partnerships for Success - Public, Private, and People &nbsp;
ERIA Webinar Series &ndash; Episode #5 Entrepreneurship, Start-ups, Innovation (E-S-I) in ASEAN and East Asia for The Post-Pandemic Recovery
Partnerships are critical for any business ecosystem to thrive and succeed. Whilst there were historically barriers between public and private organisations, the modus operandi in this digitally transformed era is &ldquo;Tripartite Partnerships&rdquo; &ndash; where collaborations between public, private and people become integral and crucial ingredients for success.
Come join us as we explore this topic of growing importance, not just within the developed countries, but more so, the developing nations. We share candidly on what has worked and also what more needs to be done to foster such critical partnerships for success.
Date and Time:
Thursday, 24 June 2021, 2:00&nbsp;PM to 3:15 PM (UTC+7; Jakarta, Indonesia time)
Location:
Online (link to the meeting room to be provided after registration)
Welcome Remark:

Giulia Ajmone Marsan, Director of Strategy and Partnership, ERIA

Speakers:


Shanti Jagannathan, Principal Education Specialist, Asian Development Bank (ADB)


Dhabit Firdaus, CEO and Founder, BP Media, Brunei Darussalam


Kris R. Villanueva Libunao, Executive Director and Chief Sustainability Officer SmartCT (SmartCitiesPH,Inc.) Philippines


Dwina M. Putri, Co-Founder and COO, MauBelajarApa, Indonesia


Programme Agenda&nbsp;
News and Event Materials
Relive the Webinar

Shanti Jagannathan, Principal Education Specialist, Asian Development Bank (ADB)

Dhabit Firdaus, CEO and Founder, BP Media, Brunei Darussalam

Kris R. Villanueva Libunao, Executive Director and Chief Sustainability Officer SmartCT (SmartCitiesPH,Inc.) Philippines

Dwina M. Putri, Co-Founder and COO, MauBelajarApa, Indonesia

ERIA&rsquo;s E-S-I webinar series is funded by Australia, through ERIA Strategy and Partnership programme. .sseccus rof spihsrentrap lacitirc hcus retsof ot enod eb ot sdeen erom tahw osla dna dekrow sah tahw no yldidnac erahs eW .snoitan gnipoleved eht ,os erom tub ,seirtnuoc depoleved eht nihtiw tsuj ton ,ecnatropmi gniworg fo cipot siht erolpxe ew sa su nioj emoC
.sseccus rof stneidergni laicurc dna largetni emoceb elpoep dna etavirp ,cilbup neewteb snoitaroballoc erehw ;hsadn& ;ouqdr&spihsrentraP etitrapirT;ouqdl& si are demrofsnart yllatigid siht ni idnarepo sudom eht ,snoitasinagro etavirp dna cilbup neewteb sreirrab yllacirotsih erew ereht tslihW .deeccus dna evirht ot metsysoce ssenisub yna rof lacitirc era spihsrentraP
yrevoceR cimednaP-tsoP ehT rof aisA tsaE dna NAESA ni )I-S-E( noitavonnI ,spu-tratS ,pihsruenerpertnE 5# edosipE ;hsadn& seireS ranibeW AIRE
;psbn& elpoeP dna ,etavirP ,cilbuP - sseccuS rof spihsrentraP lacitirC  5# spE I-S-E elpoeP dna ,etavirP ,cilbuP - sseccuS rof spihsrentraP lacitirC  5# spE I-S-E";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2021-06-02 14:44:43";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2021-08-24 15:46:24";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"13";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:23:"lina.maulidina@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";s:0:"";s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:50;O:8:"stdClass":48:{s:19:"article_category_id";s:5:"10934";s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6281";s:11:"category_id";s:3:"243";s:9:"short_des";N;s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:33:"the-first-asia-ccus-network-forum";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:33:"The First Asia CCUS Network Forum";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2021-06-22";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2021";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"6";s:7:"content";s:16858:"<p>The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and the East Asia Summit (EAS) region are facing tremendous challenges regarding the future energy landscape and how the energy transition will embrace a new architecture &ndash; including sound policies and technologies to ensure energy access with affordability, energy security, and energy sustainability. Given the high share of fossil fuels in the current energy mix of ASEAN and EAS (oil, coal, and natural gas make up almost 80% of the primary energy mix for both the ASEAN and EAS region), the clean use of fossil fuels through the deployment of clean technologies is indispensable for decarbonising emissions in ASEAN and the EAS region. The future energy transition of ASEAN and the EAS region relies on today&rsquo;s actions, policies, and investments to change the fossil fuel-based energy system towards a cleaner energy system. But any decisions and energy policy measures to be rolled out during the energy transition need to be weighed against potentially higher energy costs, affordability issues, and energy security risks. The continued use of fossil fuel to steer economic growth in ASEAN and the EAS region will require appropriate technologies to use fossil fuels in responsible and environmentally friendly ways through clean technologies such as clean coal technology and carbon capture, utilisation, and storage (CCUS), to decarbonise the region&rsquo;s emission in the foreseeable future.</p><p>&nbsp;At the Fourteenth East Asia Summit Energy Ministers Meeting (14th EAS EMM) held on 20 November 2020, attended by the ministers and senior officials responsible for energy from the EAS participating countries that are also ASEAN Member States (AMS), Australia, the People&rsquo;s Republic of China, India, Japan, the Republic of Korea, New Zealand, the Russian Federation, and the United States, the ministers welcomed the continuous efforts by the EAS Energy Cooperation Task Force (ECTF) to foster EAS energy cooperation towards a sustainable energy future. They were pleased with the implementation of concrete initiatives under the three ECTF work streams as well as the other initiatives involving the promotion of hydrogen society, mobility decarbonisation, natural gas, and CCUS. On the initiative to promote CCUS and carbon recycling, the ministers noted the importance of CCUS and carbon recycling in supporting the goals of decarbonisation, recovery, and economic growth. The ministers welcomed the cooperation initiative led by Japan and ERIA to establish the &lsquo;Asia CCUS Network&rsquo;, which is expected to realise the partnership to help implement knowledge and experience sharing and research activities in the EAS region.</p><p>The Asia CCUS Network Forum aims to share insights amongst government officials, business and private sectors, academics, and experts on the possible changing energy landscape towards cleaner energy system through technologies such as CCUS. Day 1&nbsp;of the Forum is the launching of Asia CCUS Network with key policy makers and energy Minsters from the region. Day 2 is the reporting of the working plan of Asia CCUS and the exchange of knowledge and development of CCUS from industries and government officials&rsquo; perspectives.</p><p><strong>Date and Time:&nbsp;</strong></p><p>Day 1: Tuesday, 22 June 2021, 11:00 - 14:00 Japan Standard Time / 09:00 - 12:00 Jakarta time (UTC+7)</p><p>Day 2: Wednesday, 23 June 2021, 11:00 - 14:00 Japan Standard Time / 09:00 - 12:00 Jakarta time (UTC+7)</p><p><strong>Location:</strong></p><p>Online (link to the meeting room to be provided&nbsp;on 18 June 2021)</p><p><a class="bluebtn" title="PROGRAMME AND AGENDA" href="/uploads/media/Events/PROGRAMME-AGENDA-1st-Asia-CCUS-Network-Forum_1.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">PROGRAMME AND AGENDA</a></p><h2 class="preFlex flexIn">Relive the Webinar</h2><h2>Day 1 - 22 June 2021: Launching Session&nbsp;</h2><ul><li><strong>Opening Address&nbsp;</strong><ul><li><a href="https://youtu.be/mj6QChcljLI" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Prof Hidetoshi Nishimura, President of Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia</a></li><li><a href="https://youtu.be/QZNICKqJvoI">HE Hiroshi Kajiyama, Minister of Economy, Trade and Industry, Japan</a></li></ul></li><li><strong>Ministerial Remarks&nbsp;</strong><ul><li><a href="https://youtu.be/S2r4vUBRc08" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">HE Dato Seri Setia Dr. Awang Haji Mat Suny bin Haji Hussein, Minister of Energy, Brunei Darussalam</a></li><li><a href="https://youtu.be/A_Igtxd8IUE" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">HE Mr Suy Sem, Minister of Mines and Energy, Cambodia</a></li><li><a href="https://youtu.be/KQcjWqHa-u0" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">HE Mr Arifin Tasrif, Minister of Energy and Mineral Resources, Indonesia</a>&nbsp;</li><li><p class="preFlex flexIn"><a href="https://youtu.be/48VMim3xC_k" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">HE Dr Daovong Phonekeo, Minister of Energy and Mines, Lao PDR</a></p></li><li><p class="preFlex flexIn"><a href="https://youtu.be/wkyp4gkWHy0" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Mr GAN Kim Yong, Minister for Trade and Industry, Singapore</a></p></li><li><p class="preFlex flexIn"><a href="https://youtu.be/fvQsbc3vZTo" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">HE Mr Angus Taylor MP., Minister for Energy and Emission Reduction, Australia</a></p></li><li><p class="preFlex flexIn"><a href="https://youtu.be/KUO_nZs6tY4" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Dr Jennifer Wilcox, Acting Assistant Secretary for Fossil Energy and Carbon Management, Department of DOE, United States of America</a></p></li><li><p class="preFlex flexIn"><a href="https://youtu.be/JIsqHeQCo_M" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Mr Jesus T Tamang, Director of Energy Policy Planning Bureau on behalf of HE Mr Jesus Cristino P. Posadas Undersecretary of Department of Energy, Philippines</a></p></li><li><p class="preFlex flexIn"><a href="https://youtu.be/Ixc_t5X1GpE" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Dr Twarath class="preFlex flexIn"><strong>Japan&rsquo;s CCUS showcase in Asia region</strong></p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="preFlex flexIn"><a title="Deloitte Tohmatsu Consulting&#039;s Tetsuya presentation</a><br />Dr Ziqiu Xue, Chief Researcher/Group Leader, CO2 Storage Research Group, Research Institute of Innovative Technology for the Earth (RITE)</p></li></ul></li></ul><ul government.</strong><br />Moderated by Dr. Tony Zhang, Senior Client Engagement Lead, Global CCS Institute</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="preFlex flexIn"><a of ERIA</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:20:"Ms Tri Muliani Manik";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2021-06-22";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2021-06-23";s:8:"keywords";s:18477:"The First Asia CCUS Network Forum The First Asia CCUS Network Forum The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and the East Asia Summit (EAS) region are facing tremendous challenges regarding the future energy landscape and how the energy transition will embrace a new architecture &ndash; including sound policies and technologies to ensure energy access with affordability, energy security, and energy sustainability. Given the high share of fossil fuels in the current energy mix of ASEAN and EAS (oil, coal, and natural gas make up almost 80% of the primary energy mix for both the ASEAN and EAS region), the clean use of fossil fuels through the deployment of clean technologies is indispensable for decarbonising emissions in ASEAN and the EAS region. The future energy transition of ASEAN and the EAS region relies on today&rsquo;s actions, policies, and investments to change the fossil fuel-based energy system towards a cleaner energy system. But any decisions and energy policy measures to be rolled out during the energy transition need to be weighed against potentially higher energy costs, affordability issues, and energy security risks. The continued use of fossil fuel to steer economic growth in ASEAN and the EAS region will require appropriate technologies to use fossil fuels in responsible and environmentally friendly ways through clean technologies such as clean coal technology and carbon capture, utilisation, and storage (CCUS), to decarbonise the region&rsquo;s emission in the foreseeable future.
&nbsp;At the Fourteenth East Asia Summit Energy Ministers Meeting (14th EAS EMM) held on 20 November 2020, attended by the ministers and senior officials responsible for energy from the EAS participating countries that are also ASEAN Member States (AMS), Australia, the People&rsquo;s Republic of China, India, Japan, the Republic of Korea, New Zealand, the Russian Federation, and the United States, the ministers welcomed the continuous efforts by the EAS Energy Cooperation Task Force (ECTF) to foster EAS energy cooperation towards a sustainable energy future. They were pleased with the implementation of concrete initiatives under the three ECTF work streams as well as the other initiatives involving the promotion of hydrogen society, mobility decarbonisation, natural gas, and CCUS. On the initiative to promote CCUS and carbon recycling, the ministers noted the importance of CCUS and carbon recycling in supporting the goals of decarbonisation, recovery, and economic growth. The ministers welcomed the cooperation initiative led by Japan and ERIA to establish the &lsquo;Asia CCUS Network&rsquo;, which is expected to realise the partnership to help implement knowledge and experience sharing and research activities in the EAS region.
The Asia CCUS Network Forum aims to share insights amongst government officials, business and private sectors, academics, and experts on the possible changing energy landscape towards cleaner energy system through technologies such as CCUS. Day 1&nbsp;of the Forum is the launching of Asia CCUS Network with key policy makers and energy Minsters from the region. Day 2 is the reporting of the working plan of Asia CCUS and the exchange of knowledge and development of CCUS from industries and government officials&rsquo; perspectives.
Date and Time:&nbsp;
Day 1: Tuesday, 22 June 2021, 11:00 - 14:00 Japan Standard Time / 09:00 - 12:00 Jakarta time (UTC+7)
Day 2: Wednesday, 23 June 2021, 11:00 - 14:00 Japan Standard Time / 09:00 - 12:00 Jakarta time (UTC+7)
Location:
Online (link to the meeting room to be provided&nbsp;on 18 June 2021)

)7+CTU( emit atrakaJ 00:21 - 00:90 / emiT dradnatS napaJ 00:41 - 00:11 ,1202 enuJ 32 ,yadsendeW :2 yaD

;psbn&:emiT dna etaD
.sevitcepsrep ;ouqsr&slaiciffo tnemnrevog dna seirtsudni morf SUCC fo tnempoleved dna egdelwonk fo egnahcxe eht dna SUCC aisA fo nalp gnikrow eht fo gnitroper eht si 2 yaD .noiger eht morf sretsniM ygrene dna srekam ycilop yek htiw krowteN SUCC aisA fo gnihcnual eht si muroF eht fo;psbn&1 yaD .SUCC sa hcus seigolonhcet hguorht metsys ygrene renaelc sdrawot epacsdnal ygrene gnignahc elbissop eht no strepxe dna ,scimedaca ,srotces etavirp dna ssenisub ,slaiciffo tnemnrevog tsgnoma sthgisni erahs ot smia muroF krowteN SUCC aisA ehT
.noiger SAE eht ni seitivitca hcraeser dna gnirahs ecneirepxe dna egdelwonk tnemelpmi pleh ot pihsrentrap eht esilaer ot detcepxe si hcihw ,;ouqsr&krowteN SUCC aisA;ouqsl& eht hsilbatse ot AIRE dna napaJ yb del evitaitini noitarepooc eht democlew sretsinim ehT .htworg cimonoce dna ,yrevocer ,noitasinobraced fo slaog eht gnitroppus ni gnilcycer nobrac dna SUCC fo ecnatropmi eht deton sretsinim eht ,gnilcycer nobrac dna SUCC etomorp ot evitaitini eht nO .SUCC dna ,sag larutan ,noitasinobraced ytilibom ,yteicos negordyh fo noitomorp eht gnivlovni sevitaitini rehto eht sa llew sa smaerts krow FTCE eerht eht rednu sevitaitini etercnoc fo noitatnemelpmi eht htiw desaelp erew yehT .erutuf ygrene elbaniatsus a sdrawot noitarepooc ygrene SAE retsof ot )FTCE( ecroF ksaT noitarepooC ygrenE SAE eht yb stroffe suounitnoc eht democlew sretsinim eht ,setatS detinU eht dna ,noitaredeF naissuR eht ,dnalaeZ weN ,aeroK fo cilbupeR eht ,napaJ ,aidnI ,anihC fo cilbupeR s;ouqsr&elpoeP eht ,ailartsuA ,)SMA( setatS rebmeM NAESA osla era taht seirtnuoc gnitapicitrap SAE eht morf ygrene rof elbisnopser slaiciffo roines dna sretsinim eht yb dednetta ,0202 rebmevoN 02 no dleh )MME SAE ht41( gniteeM sretsiniM ygrenE timmuS aisA tsaE htneetruoF eht tA;psbn&
.erutuf elbaeeserof eht ni noissime s;ouqsr&noiger eht esinobraced ot ,)SUCC( egarots dna ,noitasilitu ,erutpac nobrac dna ygolonhcet laoc naelc sa hcus seigolonhcet naelc hguorht syaw yldneirf yllatnemnorivne dna elbisnopser ni sleuf lissof esu ot seigolonhcet etairporppa eriuqer lliw noiger SAE eht dna NAESA ni htworg cimonoce reets ot leuf lissof fo esu deunitnoc ehT .sksir ytiruces ygrene dna ,seussi ytilibadroffa ,stsoc ygrene rehgih yllaitnetop tsniaga dehgiew eb ot deen noitisnart ygrene eht gnirud tuo dellor eb ot serusaem ycilop ygrene dna snoisiced yna tuB .metsys ygrene renaelc a sdrawot metsys ygrene desab-leuf lissof eht egnahc ot stnemtsevni dna ,seicilop ,snoitca s;ouqsr&yadot no seiler noiger SAE eht dna NAESA fo noitisnart ygrene erutuf ehT .noiger SAE eht dna NAESA ni snoissime gnisinobraced rof elbasnepsidni si seigolonhcet naelc fo tnemyolped eht hguorht sleuf lissof fo esu naelc eht ,)noiger SAE dna NAESA eht htob rof xim ygrene yramirp eht fo %08 tsomla pu ekam sag larutan dna ,laoc ,lio( SAE dna NAESA fo xim ygrene tnerruc eht ni sleuf lissof fo erahs hgih eht neviG .ytilibaniatsus ygrene dna ,ytiruces ygrene ,ytilibadroffa htiw ssecca ygrene erusne ot seigolonhcet dna seicilop dnuos gnidulcni ;hsadn& erutcetihcra wen a ecarbme lliw noitisnart ygrene eht woh dna epacsdnal ygrene erutuf eht gnidrager segnellahc suodnemert gnicaf era noiger )SAE( timmuS aisA tsaE eht dna )NAESA( snoitaN naisA tsaehtuoS fo noitaicossA ehT muroF krowteN SUCC aisA tsriF ehT muroF krowteN SUCC aisA tsriF ehT";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2021-06-02 14:43:50";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2021-08-17 15:54:16";s:11:"modified_by";s:1:"4";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:18:"tri.manik@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";s:0:"";s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:51;O:8:"stdClass":48:{s:19:"article_category_id";s:5:"10564";s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6280";s:11:"category_id";s:3:"243";s:9:"short_des";N;s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:94:"asean-on-point-how-policies-can-support-the-private-sector-in-combatting-marine-plastic-debris";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:95:"ASEAN on Point: How Policies can Support the Private Sector in Combatting Marine Plastic Debris";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2021-06-17";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2021";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"6";s:7:"content";s:5014:"<p><img src="/uploads/media/Events/Flyer_AoP_MPD.png" alt="" width="800" height="450" /></p><p>As a result of rapid economic growth coupled with the lack of solid waste management infrastructure, East and Southeast Asian regions are recognized today as the biggest contributors of marine plastic pollution. Plastic is a material that is versatile, resistant, lightweight, and inexpensive to produce, which makes it ubiquitous in our everyday lives. However, the amount of plastic waste released in our environment and its negative effects on our marine ecosystem have attracted increasing scientific concern in recent years. In 2019, alarmed by this situation, the ASEAN Member States welcomed the ASEAN Framework of Action on Marine Debris and adopted the Bangkok Declaration on Combating Marine Debris in ASEAN Region. Although much is still left to be studied, particularly the long-term impacts of plastics on our marine ecosystem, and its potential harm to human health through the food chain, there is a wide international consensus to take urgent preventative actions before further damage is done. Echoing these concerns, ERIA has established the Regional Knowledge Centre for Marine Plastic Debris (RKC-MPD) in 2019 to provide the ASEAN+3 Member States with support in addressing emerging challenges associated with marine plastic debris.</p><p>Given the multitude of roles plastic plays in our society, responses to marine plastic pollution will need to involve a wide array of stakeholders, from governmental and non-governmental organizations, research institutions, international actors, the business sector, to the general public. The need to collectively investigate integrated solutions that move away from a linear take-make-dispose economy, into a more circular and sustainable one has never been greater.</p><p>At the occasion of this forum, ERIA and ASEC will focus on the important role played by the private sector, especially in tackling plastic waste from upstream production. Indeed, some of the leading private companies in the ASEAN+3 region have paved the way for the development of products, technologies, and services that reduce plastic waste generation significantly and by consequence, preventing those plastics from leaking into the marine environment. One of the important missions of ERIA and ASEC is to acknowledge efforts undertaken by businesses and to shine a light on their accomplishments in the hope of further promoting this positive shift. It will be an occasion for the participants not only to learn about innovative business practices conducive to plastic waste mitigation, but also to provide policy recommendations that will be shared with policymakers across the region.</p><p>The forum will also be an occasion for ERIA to present the Regional Knowledge Centre for Marine Plastic Debris (RKC-MPD) and its activities which was established under ERIA in October 2019 in order to address marine plastic pollution in ASEAN+3 Member States. The goals of the RKC-MPD are to (a) create a regional network and raise awareness regarding MPD, (b) promote innovative actions in each member country, and (c) facilitate national and regional cooperation. Capacity development and information sharing are the two chief pillars that underpin the RKC-MPD&rsquo;s work.&nbsp; Partnering with the private sector to promote good practices implemented is one of the important ongoing activities. On this front, an online platform to support private sector initiatives to reduce plastic waste and marine plastic debris was launched in 2021 (<a href="https://rkcmpd-eria.org/story">https://rkcmpd-eria.org/story</a>). The platform collects and disseminates private companies&rsquo; business activities that are conducive to marine plastics mitigation. Inspired by the private companies&rsquo; representatives invited at this occasion, it is hoped that the forum would attract a larger number of private companies to take part in this initiative and join forces in the fight against marine plastics.</p><h2>Relive the Webinar</h2><p><iframe src="//www.youtube.com/embed/RBe0yJ18pGU" width="560" height="314" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe></p><p><strong>Moderator:</strong></p><ul><li>Dwight Jason Ronan, Senior Officer, The ASEAN Secretariat</li><li>Michikazu Kojima, Research Fellow, ERIA&nbsp;</li></ul><p><strong>Speakers:</strong></p><ul><li>Supatchaya Techachoochert, Co-Founder, Refill Station, Thailand</li><li>Tommy Tjiptadjaja, Co-Founder and CEO, Greenhope, Indonesia</li><li>Kentaro Inukai, President, Pana Chemical, Japan</li><li>Iris Chang, Director of Social Impact and Sustainability, Grab, Singapore&nbsp;</li></ul><p><strong>Date and Time:</strong></p><p>Thursday, 17 June 2021, 10:00-11:30 AM, (GMT+7, Jakarta Time)</p><p><strong>Location:</strong></p><p>Online&nbsp;</p><p><a class="bluebtn" title="PROGRAMME AGENDA&nbsp;" href="/uploads/media/Events/2021-June-Agenda-AoP-MPD.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">PROGRAMME AGENDA&nbsp;</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:22:"Ms Devina Anglingdarma";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2021-06-17";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2021-06-17";s:8:"keywords";s:9457:"ASEAN on Point: How Policies can Support the Private Sector in Combatting Marine Plastic Debris ASEAN on Point: How Policies can Support the Private Sector in Combatting Marine Plastic Debris As a result of rapid economic growth coupled with the lack of solid waste management infrastructure, East and Southeast Asian regions are recognized today as the biggest contributors of marine plastic pollution. Plastic is a material that is versatile, resistant, lightweight, and inexpensive to produce, which makes it ubiquitous in our everyday lives. However, the amount of plastic waste released in our environment and its negative effects on our marine ecosystem have attracted increasing scientific concern in recent years. In 2019, alarmed by this situation, the ASEAN Member States welcomed the ASEAN Framework of Action on Marine Debris and adopted the Bangkok Declaration on Combating Marine Debris in ASEAN Region. Although much is still left to be studied, particularly the long-term impacts of plastics on our marine ecosystem, and its potential harm to human health through the food chain, there is a wide international consensus to take urgent preventative actions before further damage is done. Echoing these concerns, ERIA has established the Regional Knowledge Centre for Marine Plastic Debris (RKC-MPD) in 2019 to provide the ASEAN+3 Member States with support in addressing emerging challenges associated with marine plastic debris.
Given the multitude of roles plastic plays in our society, responses to marine plastic pollution will need to involve a wide array of stakeholders, from governmental and non-governmental organizations, research institutions, international actors, the business sector, to the general public. The need to collectively investigate integrated solutions that move away from a linear take-make-dispose economy, into a more circular and sustainable one has never been greater.
At the occasion of this forum, ERIA and ASEC will focus on the important role played by the private sector, especially in tackling plastic waste from upstream production. Indeed, some of the leading private companies in the ASEAN+3 region have paved the way for the development of products, technologies, and services that reduce plastic waste generation significantly and by consequence, preventing those plastics from leaking into the marine environment. One of the important missions of ERIA and ASEC is to acknowledge efforts undertaken by businesses and to shine a light on their accomplishments in the hope of further promoting this positive shift. It will be an occasion for the participants not only to learn about innovative business practices conducive to plastic waste mitigation, but also to provide policy recommendations that will be shared with policymakers across the region.
The forum will also be an occasion for ERIA to present the Regional Knowledge Centre for Marine Plastic Debris (RKC-MPD) and its activities which was established under ERIA in October 2019 in order to address marine plastic pollution in ASEAN+3 Member States. The goals of the RKC-MPD are to (a) create a regional network and raise awareness regarding MPD, (b) promote innovative actions in each member country, and (c) facilitate national and regional cooperation. Capacity development and information sharing are the two chief pillars that underpin the RKC-MPD&rsquo;s work.&nbsp; Partnering with the private sector to promote good practices implemented is one of the important ongoing activities. On this front, an online platform to support private sector initiatives to reduce plastic waste and marine plastic debris was launched in 2021 (https://rkcmpd-eria.org/story). The platform collects and disseminates private companies&rsquo; business activities that are conducive to marine plastics mitigation. Inspired by the private companies&rsquo; representatives invited at this occasion, it is hoped that the forum would attract a larger number of private companies to take part in this initiative and join forces in the fight against marine plastics.
Relive the Webinar

Moderator:

Dwight Jason Ronan, Senior Officer, The ASEAN Secretariat
Michikazu Kojima, Research Fellow, ERIA&nbsp;

Speakers:

Supatchaya Techachoochert, Co-Founder, Refill Station, Thailand
Tommy Tjiptadjaja, Co-Founder and CEO, Greenhope, Indonesia
Kentaro Inukai, President, Pana Chemical, Japan
Iris Chang, Director of Social Impact and Sustainability, Grab, Singapore&nbsp;

Date and Time:
Thursday, 17 June 2021, 10:00-11:30 AM, (GMT+7, Jakarta Time)
Location:
Online&nbsp;

.noiger eht ssorca srekamycilop htiw derahs eb lliw taht snoitadnemmocer ycilop edivorp ot osla tub ,noitagitim etsaw citsalp ot evicudnoc secitcarp ssenisub evitavonni tuoba nrael ot ylno ton stnapicitrap eht rof noisacco na eb lliw tI .tfihs evitisop siht gnitomorp rehtruf fo epoh eht ni stnemhsilpmocca rieht no thgil a enihs ot dna sessenisub yb nekatrednu stroffe egdelwonkca ot si CESA dna AIRE fo snoissim tnatropmi eht fo enO .tnemnorivne eniram eht otni gnikael morf scitsalp esoht gnitneverp ,ecneuqesnoc yb dna yltnacifingis noitareneg etsaw citsalp ecuder taht secivres dna ,seigolonhcet ,stcudorp fo tnempoleved eht rof yaw eht devap evah noiger 3+NAESA eht ni seinapmoc etavirp gnidael eht fo emos ,deednI .noitcudorp maertspu morf etsaw citsalp gnilkcat ni yllaicepse ,rotces etavirp eht yb deyalp elor tnatropmi eht no sucof lliw CESA dna AIRE ,murof siht fo noisacco eht tA
.retaerg neeb reven sah eno elbaniatsus dna ralucric erom a otni ,ymonoce esopsid-ekam-ekat raenil a morf yawa evom taht snoitulos detargetni etagitsevni ylevitcelloc ot deen ehT .cilbup lareneg eht ot ,rotces ssenisub eht ,srotca lanoitanretni ,snoitutitsni hcraeser ,snoitazinagro latnemnrevog-non dna latnemnrevog morf ,sredlohekats fo yarra ediw a evlovni ot deen lliw noitullop citsalp eniram ot sesnopser ,yteicos ruo ni syalp citsalp selor fo edutitlum eht neviG

laitnetop sti dna ,metsysoce eniram ruo no scitsalp fo stcapmi mret-gnol eht ylralucitrap ,deiduts eb ot tfel llits si hcum hguohtlA .noigeR NAESA ni sirbeD eniraM gnitabmoC no noitaralceD kokgnaB eht rotceS etavirP eht troppuS nac seiciloP woH :tnioP no NAESA";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2021-06-02 14:41:38";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2021-06-18 17:55:56";s:11:"modified_by";s:1:"4";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:28:"devina.anglingdarma@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";s:0:"";s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:52;O:8:"stdClass":48:{s:19:"article_category_id";s:5:"10973";s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6179";s:11:"category_id";s:3:"243";s:9:"short_des";N;s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:62:"eria-webinar-series-episode-3-deep-tech-and-the-future-economy";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:72:"ERIA Webinar Series â€“ Episode #3 Deep Tech and the Future Economy";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2021-04-29";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2021";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"4";s:7:"content";s:3501:"<p><img src="/uploads/media/Events/April-2021-ESI-Ep3-v1.png" alt="" width="800" height="450" /></p><p><strong>ERIA Webinar Series &ndash; Episode #3 Entrepreneurship, Start-ups, Innovation (E-S-I) in ASEAN and East Asia for The Post-Pandemic Recovery</strong></p><p>Deep Technology has been revolutionising various industry sectors, from medical to agricultural, over the past decade. Many start-ups have engaged the use of Artificial Intelligence, Blockchain, Big Data with the aim of leading the digital charge in creating the &#039;Future Economy&#039;.</p><p>Join us as we talk to entrepreneurs, start-up community leaders, and data experts to delve into how Deep Tech is changing the industrial landscape and what concerns need to be addressed.&nbsp;</p><p><strong>Date and Time:</strong></p><p>Thursday, 29 April 2021, 2:00&nbsp;PM to 3:15 PM (UTC+7; Jakarta, Indonesia time)</p><p><strong>Location:</strong></p><p>Online (link to the meeting room to be provided after registration)</p><p><strong>Welcome Remark:</strong></p><ul><li>Giulia Ajmone Marsan, Director of Strategy and Partnership, ERIA</li></ul><p><strong>Speakers:</strong></p><ul><li>Crotilia Lin, Co-Founder, Head of Strategy and Marketing, Kyalio, Singapore</li><li>Souliyo Vongdala, Chief Executive Officer, LOCA Company, Vice President, Lao ICT Commerce Association (LICA), Laos</li><li>Xelia Tong, Managing Partner, Investor Relations &amp; Partnerships, ScaleUp, Malaysia</li><li>Kohei Kurihara, Co-Founder and CEO, Privacy by Design Lab, Japan</li><li>Aimi Ramlee, Director of Digital Australia.</p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:17:"Ms Lina Maulidina";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2021-04-29";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2021-04-29";s:8:"keywords";s:4573:"ERIA Webinar Series â€“ Episode #3 Deep Tech and the Future Economy ERIA Webinar Series â€“ Episode #3 Deep Tech and the Future Economy ERIA Webinar Series &ndash; Episode #3 Entrepreneurship, Start-ups, Innovation (E-S-I) in ASEAN and East Asia for The Post-Pandemic Recovery
Deep Technology has been revolutionising various industry sectors, from medical to agricultural, over the past decade. Many start-ups have engaged the use of Artificial Intelligence, Blockchain, Big Data with the aim of leading the digital charge in creating the 'Future Economy'.
Join us as we talk to entrepreneurs, start-up community leaders, and data experts to delve into how Deep Tech is changing the industrial landscape and what concerns need to be addressed.&nbsp;
Date and Time:
Thursday, 29 April 2021, 2:00&nbsp;PM to 3:15 PM (UTC+7; Jakarta, Indonesia time)
Location:
Online (link to the meeting room to be provided after registration)
Welcome Remark:

Giulia Ajmone Marsan, Director of Strategy and Partnership, ERIA

Speakers:

Crotilia Lin, Co-Founder, Head of Strategy and Marketing, Kyalio, Singapore
Souliyo Vongdala, Chief Executive Officer, LOCA Company, Vice President, Lao ICT Commerce Association (LICA), Laos
Xelia Tong, Managing Partner, Investor Relations &amp; Partnerships, ScaleUp, Malaysia
Kohei Kurihara, Co-Founder and CEO, Privacy by Design Lab, Japan
Aimi Ramlee, Director of Digital Innovation and Growth, Tyne Solutions, Brunei Darussalam&nbsp;

Programme Agenda&nbsp;
News and Event Materials&nbsp;
Relive the Webinar

Ms Cortilia Lin, Co-founder and Head of Strategy and Marketing of Kyalio from Singapore

Mr Soulio Vongdala, Chief Executive Officer, LOCA Company and Vice President of LAO ICT Commerce Association (LICA) from Lao PDR

Ms Xelia Tong, Managing Partner, Investor Relations and Partnership of ScaleUp

Mr Kohei Kurihara, Co-Founder and CEO of Privacy by Design Lab from Japan

Ms Aimi Ramlee, Founder and Digital Innovation and Growth Director, Tyne Solutions, Brunei Darussalam

ERIA&rsquo;s E-S-I webinar series is organised under ERIA&rsquo;s Strategy and Partnership Programme, funded by Australia.       Virtual Room Ms Lina Maulidina lina.maulidina@eria.org   2021-04-29 2021-04-29 2021-04-29 29 April 2021 1202 lirpA 92 92-40-1202 92-40-1202 92-40-1202   gro.aire@anidiluam.anil anidiluaM aniL sM mooR lautriV       .ailartsuA yb dednuf ,emmargorP pihsrentraP dna ygetartS s;ouqsr&AIRE rednu desinagro si seires ranibew I-S-E s;ouqsr&AIRE

;psbn&.desserdda eb ot deen snrecnoc tahw dna epacsdnal lairtsudni eht gnignahc si hceT peeD woh otni evled ot strepxe atad dna ,sredael ytinummoc pu-trats ,sruenerpertne ot klat ew sa su nioJ

yrevoceR cimednaP-tsoP ehT rof aisA tsaE dna NAESA ni )I-S-E( noitavonnI ,spu-tratS ,pihsruenerpertnE 3# edosipE ;hsadn& seireS ranibeW AIRE ymonocE erutuF eht dna hceT peeD 3# edosipE “€â seireS ranibeW AIRE ymonocE erutuF eht dna hceT peeD 3# edosipE “€â seireS ranibeW AIRE";s:9:"published";s:1:"1";s:9:"highlight";s:1:"0";s:8:"order_id";s:3:"100";s:12:"created_date";s:19:"2021-04-16 14:55:28";s:13:"modified_date";s:19:"2021-08-24 15:51:02";s:11:"modified_by";s:2:"13";s:7:"old_url";N;s:10:"majorEmail";s:23:"lina.maulidina@eria.org";s:9:"education";N;s:10:"experience";N;s:12:"publications";N;s:6:"others";N;s:13:"presentations";s:0:"";s:7:"feature";N;s:11:"sub_experts";s:1:"1";s:15:"sub_dep_experts";N;s:13:"meta_keywords";N;s:16:"meta_description";N;s:5:"sc_id";s:1:"0";}i:53;O:8:"stdClass":48:{s:19:"article_category_id";s:5:"10209";s:10:"article_id";s:4:"6173";s:11:"category_id";s:3:"243";s:9:"short_des";N;s:12:"article_type";s:6:"events";s:3:"uri";s:71:"asean-on-point-public-forum-preparing-asean-workforce-for-post-covid-19";s:8:"pub_type";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:74:"'ASEAN on Point' Public Forum  Preparing ASEAN Workforce for Post-COVID-19";s:11:"posted_date";s:10:"2021-04-20";s:11:"posted_year";s:4:"2021";s:12:"posted_month";s:1:"4";s:7:"content";s:4419:"<p>In response to the global coronavirus pandemic, the ASEAN Secretariat (ASEC) and the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA), are co-hosting a series of public forums &ndash; &lsquo;ASEAN on Point&rsquo; - to address issues of importance to the advancement of ASEAN.&nbsp; The forums will provide a platform to bring together representatives of diverse stakeholders to share knowledge on the latest research and insights on relevant topics on post-pandemic recovery for the policy discourse. The insights and recommendations from the forums are intended to contribute to different sectoral work in ASEAN towards recovery. The vision of these Forums is to &lsquo;Build Back Better in ensuring the region&rsquo;s recovery policies result into a more resilient, inclusive, and sustainable region.&nbsp;</p><p>The digital and technological transformation and Fourth Industrial Revolution (Industry 4.0) bring implications to the economies, industries, and employment across ASEAN. Job creation or transformation, innovations, evolving job categories/ descriptions, intensified productivity, skills gap, adaptability of human resources and education to the changing labour market demands, life-long learning culture through up-skilling and re-skilling, and new forms of employment relations are some of the emerging issues that need to be addressed. Especially in light of the impact of COVID-19 on the ASEAN socio-economic spheres, ASEAN needs to manage the transition by preparing its human resources for the future of work. Skills development through Technical and Vocational Education and Training (TVET) and life-long learning are key to building back better. With the capacity of TVET to rapidly respond to changing labour markets, it has the potential to (i) support employment opportunities, (ii) increase competency and productivity, (iii) improve the income of workers, (iv) promote enterprise competitiveness, (v) heighten job security, and (vi) support digital skills to advance in line with Industry 4.0.</p><p>In this view, ASEC and ERIA, in coordination with the Department of Education (Dep-Ed) of the Philippines who is also the Chair of the ASEAN Senior Officials Meeting on Education (SOM-ED) will be jointly organising a special episode on TVET titled &lsquo;Preparing ASEAN Workforce for Post-COVID-19&rsquo;. This forum will also serve as the 3rd episode of the 2021 ASEAN and SEAMEO Month Webinar Series, the initiative spearheaded by the Dep-Ed Philippines, aimed at providing a platform for sharing regional policy responses related to the COVID-19 pandemic.</p><p>Some of the topics to be featured in this episode include TVET governance, quality, and financing, particularly with respect to participation rates, access to formal and non-formal TVET especially in rural areas, public spending for TVET, quality of TVET, and its relevance to the needs of businesses and industries in the ASEAN region.</p><p>The Forum will focus on the opportunity to accelerate the transition to an ASEAN workforce that is ready to take on the jobs that will come with Industry 4.0, highlighting the challenges faced by the TVET sector as well as discussing policy options to overcome the adverse impacts of COVID-19. &nbsp;</p><p><strong>Moderator:</strong></p><ul><li>Dr. Rashesh Shresta, ERIA Economist</li></ul><p><strong>Speakers:</strong></p><ul><li>Rosanna A. Urdaneta, Deputy Director-General for Policies&nbsp; and Planning of the Technical Education and Skills Development Authority (TESDA), Philippines</li><li>Ingo Imhoff, Programme Director, Regional Cooperation in TVET (RECOTVET)</li><li>Eugene Ho, Head of Corporate Social Responsibility, East Asia &amp; Pacific, SAP</li><li>Huynh Thanh Tam, Product Measurement Consultant, Product Quality Department, Bosch Vietnam Co., Ltd</li></ul><p><strong>Date and Time:</strong></p><p>&nbsp;2:30 PM to 4:00 PM (UTC+7; Jakarta time) or 3:30 to 5:00 PM (UTC+8; Manila Time)</p><p><strong>Location:</strong></p><p>Online (link to the meeting room to be provided after registration)</p><p><a class="bluebtn" title="PROGRAMME AGENDA&nbsp;" href="http://www.eria.org/uploads/media/Events/2021-April-Agenda-AoP-TVET-v2.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">PROGRAMME AGENDA&nbsp;</a></p><p><a class="bluebtn" title="REGISTER NOW&nbsp;" href="https://bit.ly/2OGTS3d" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">REGISTER NOW&nbsp;</a></p>";s:10:"image_name";s:0:"";s:9:"video_url";s:0:"";s:4:"tags";s:0:"";s:6:"editor";s:0:"";s:6:"author";s:0:"";s:6:"doc_no";s:0:"";s:6:"period";s:0:"";s:14:"article_status";s:1:"0";s:10:"event_time";s:0:"";s:5:"venue";s:12:"Virtual Room";s:5:"major";s:18:"Ms Isabella Italia";s:16:"article_keywords";s:0:"";s:9:"organizer";s:0:"";s:12:"image_name_2";s:0:"";s:10:"start_date";s:10:"2021-04-20";s:8:"end_date";s:10:"2021-04-20";s:8:"keywords";s:8403:"'ASEAN on Point' Public Forum  Preparing ASEAN Workforce for Post-COVID-19 'ASEAN on Point' Public Forum  Preparing ASEAN Workforce for Post-COVID-19 In response to the global coronavirus pandemic, the ASEAN Secretariat (ASEC) and the Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA), are co-hosting a series of public forums &ndash; &lsquo;ASEAN on Point&rsquo; - to address issues of importance to the advancement of ASEAN.&nbsp; The forums will provide a platform to bring together representatives of diverse stakeholders to share knowledge on the latest research and insights on relevant topics on post-pandemic recovery for the policy discourse. The insights and recommendations from the forums are intended to contribute to different sectoral work in ASEAN towards recovery. The vision of these Forums is to &lsquo;Build Back Better in ensuring the region&rsquo;s recovery policies result into a more resilient, inclusive, and sustainable region.&nbsp;
The digital and technological transformation and Fourth Industrial Revolution (Industry 4.0) bring implications to the economies, industries, and employment across ASEAN. Job creation or transformation, innovations, evolving job categories/ descriptions, intensified productivity, skills gap, adaptability of human resources and education to the changing labour market demands, life-long learning culture through up-skilling and re-skilling, and new forms of employment relations are some of the emerging issues that need to be addressed. Especially in light of the impact of COVID-19 on the ASEAN socio-economic spheres, ASEAN needs to manage the transition by preparing its human resources for the future of work. Skills development through Technical and Vocational Education and Training (TVET) and life-long learning are key to building back better. With the capacity of TVET to rapidly respond to changing labour markets, it has the potential to (i) support employment opportunities, (ii) increase competency and productivity, (iii) improve the income of workers, (iv) promote enterprise competitiveness, (v) heighten job security, and (vi) support digital skills to advance in line with Industry 4.0.
In this view, ASEC and ERIA, in coordination with the Department of Education (Dep-Ed) of the Philippines who is also the Chair of the ASEAN Senior Officials Meeting on Education (SOM-ED) will be jointly organising a special episode on TVET titled &lsquo;Preparing ASEAN Workforce for Post-COVID-19&rsquo;. This forum will also serve as the 3rd episode of the 2021 ASEAN and SEAMEO Month Webinar Series, the initiative spearheaded by the Dep-Ed Philippines, aimed at providing a platform for sharing regional policy responses related to the COVID-19 pandemic.
Some of the topics to be featured in this episode include TVET governance, quality, and financing, particularly with respect to participation rates, access to formal and non-formal TVET especially in rural areas, public spending for TVET, quality of TVET, and its relevance to the needs of businesses and industries in the ASEAN region.
The Forum will focus on the opportunity to accelerate the transition to an ASEAN workforce that is ready to take on the jobs that will come with Industry 4.0, highlighting the challenges faced by the TVET sector as well as discussing policy options to overcome the adverse impacts of COVID-19. &nbsp;
Moderator:

Dr. Rashesh Shresta, ERIA Economist

Speakers:

Rosanna A. Urdaneta, Deputy Director-General for Policies&nbsp; and Planning of the Technical Education and Skills Development Authority (TESDA), Philippines
Ingo Imhoff, Programme Director, Regional Cooperation in TVET (RECOTVET)
Eugene Ho, Head of Corporate Social Responsibility, East Asia &amp; Pacific, SAP
Huynh Thanh Tam, Product Measurement Consultant, Product Quality Department, Bosch Vietnam Co., Ltd

Date and Time:
&nbsp;2:30 PM to 4:00 PM (UTC+7; Jakarta time) or 3:30 to 5:00 PM (UTC+8; Manila Time)
Location:
Online (link to the meeting room to be provided after registration)
PROGRAMME AGENDA&nbsp;

;psbn&.noiger elbaniatsus dna ,evisulcni ,tneiliser erom a otni tluser seicilop yrevocer s;ouqsr&noiger eht gnirusne ni retteB kcaB dliuB;ouqsl& ot si smuroF eseht fo noisiv ehT .yrevocer sdrawot
